PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Stephen Martin) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
(1)We the undersigned wish to signify our strong opposition to any change in the design or colour of the Australian National Flag.
(2)We believe that the current flag has served Australia well and will continue to do so in the future and represents a true manifestation of the Nation's history.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Anderson (from 378 citizens) and Ms Moylan (from 12 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Bosnia-Herzegovina
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens and residents of Australia draws to the attention of the House that we are appalled of the atrocities that are taking place within Bosnia Hercegovina. It is Australia's duty in accordance with International Law to oppose genocide.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House, request that the Parliament Australia support the lifting of the arm's embargo against the Bosnian Government, and the bombing of military targets in Serbian held territories, and in Serbia itself.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale (from 153 citizens) and Mr Nugent (from 441 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Aged Family and Health Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the underfunding by the Federal Government to the value of $280,000 for assistance of specialised care for the residents of Strathdon Lodge (a dementia care facility of the Uniting Church in Australia).

Your petitioners therefore request the House to affirm the special need for dementia specific hostels as a necessary component in the residential care of the aged and the need for funding such hostels in accordance with their unique care needs and the desired outcome standards; and that the Minister for the Aged Family and Health services be asked to set up an independent committee including industry representatives to inquire into the care and cost benefits of specific hostels for dementia as an alternative to Nursing Home care. This committee to report to the Minister by June 30th 1993.

PETITION.TITLE: Deportation Order
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned shows:
That Mr Ah Hin Teoh of 7/45 Bradley Street, Lockridge, has been served with a deportation order.
Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should withdraw said deportation order against Mr Ah Hin Teoh.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia: Christian Commonwealth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we, the undersigned, call for the full and total recognition, by Federal Parliament and the High Court and all government agencies that Australia is a Christian Commonwealth according to law and its heritage, traditions and customs.

That as Australia prepares for the Centenary of Federation on 1st January, 2001 AD we celebrate our Centenary as a Christian Commonwealth as described by the Founders of Federation such as Sir John Downer, who said "The Commonwealth will be from its first stage a Christian Commonwealth and as stated in our Federal Constitution—"Relying of the Blessings of Almighty God. . .
That our Federal Parliament therefore implement the following policies before 1st January, 2001 AD, "In the Year of our Lord":-
1.The Adoption of a Christian National Anthem such as "God Bless Australia" to the tune of "Waltzing Matilda".
2.The Adoption of a Christian National Motto such as "One Nation Under God", for use on our coins, banknotes, etc.
3.The appointment of practising Christians as Vice Regal Representatives of our Christian Queen, Elizabeth II.
4.The retention of our Christian Prayers including the Lord's Prayer at the daily opening of Parliament in the standing respectful presence of all Members of Parliament.
5.The retention of "God Save the Queen" for Vice Regal Functions as our Royal Anthem and as our National Hymn for all other civic functions.
6.The retention of Christian Christmas Carols in our Schools and other civic functions during the Christmas Season.
7.Officially inform the United Nations and all the other nations of the world that Australia is a "Christian Commonwealth".
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will reaffirm our Christian Heritage as a Christian Commonwealth.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: United Vietnamese Buddhist Congregation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Federal Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that:

Since May 1992, the Government of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam (GOSRV) started a new campaign trying to stamp out the voice of the United Vietnamese Buddhist Congregation (UVBC), which is led by the Most Venerable Thich Huyen Quang, an Amnesty International's prisoner of conscience since his third arrest by the GOSRV in 1982.

The GOSRV has ignored the UVBC's moderate demands: the restoration of its structure and activities in the country, as clearly stated in the letter signed by Thich Huyen Quang on 25/6/1992 to the Hanoi authorities.

Instead of listening and considering the UVBC's genuine and sound desires, the GOSRV is continuing on their criminal path of repression and persecution: torturing till death Venerable Thich Thien An in late September 1992 in Chi Hoa prison, arresting Venerables Thich Khong Tanh and Thich Tri Luc in 2/10/1992, and carrying out other oppressive measures, such as threats, distortion, slander, preventing communication, searching of religious places and private homes, etc of Buddhist monks, nuns and lay people who support the UVBC.

In 1981, the GOSRV intervened by creating the Vietnam Buddhist Church (VBC), a puppet body, with the intent of dispossessing the Buddhist clergy and lay communities. Many clergy have been forced to join VBC, and threatened due to their support to the UVBC.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House make stronger representations to the GOSRV by:

1. Urging that, in order to enjoy good relations with Australia and to receive equitably Australian tax payers' aid, the GOSRV must respond, promptly, to two Motions passed by the Australian Senate in 24/6/1992 and by the House of Representatives in 20/8/1992 condemning the repressive actions of GOSRV.

2. Asking the Prime Minister of Australia to send his Diplomatic Note to the Prime Minister of the GOSRV, Mr Vo Van Kiet expressing the strongest disapproval of the religious intolerance and the intervention and oppression of religious organisations, especially the UVBC.

3. Requesting that the GOSRV restore and recognize independence of the UVBC's structure and activities; to release, from prison or home custody, the UVBC's clergy, ie. Venerables Huyen Quang, Quang Do, Duc Nhuan, Tue Sy, Tri Sieu, Nguyen Giac, Phuc Vien, Thien Tan, etc. including newly arrested monks Khong Tanh and Tri Luc (in 2/10/92) and all other political prisoners.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care Access
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:

PETITION.PARA: 1.That we the undersigned citizens wish to signify our strong support for everyone in the community having access to quality healthcare services when they need them.
2.That we believe because people are being discouraged from providing for their own healthcare that not everyone has equal access to quality healthcare services.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore request the House to:

PETITION.PARA: Ensure that the Federal Government provides tax credits or rebates to encourage people to have private healthcare funding where they can afford it, so that all Australians will have equal access to quality healthcare.

PETITION.TITLE: Genetic Engineering
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: We citizens of Australia and custodians of the Earth draw to the attention of the House, our concern at the continued use of genetic engineering and cloning of human beings, animals, plant life, microbes and foods. Along with the unknown consequences to the Earth's natural life forms and environment, in order for Individuals and Multi National Companies to patent and own the food resources of the world.

We request you to pass laws prohibiting the continued use of genetic engineering and cloning of human beings, animals, plant life, microbes and foods. We want you to protect Humanity from the patenting and owning, by Individuals and large Corporate Bodies, of unnatural life forms.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Yesterday the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) raised a matter of privilege as a result of comments by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) during Question Time concerning a report of the Auditor-General on government debt. The honourable member said that the Treasurer had claimed that changes had been made to the report as a result of a letter sent to the Auditor-General. The honourable member expressed the view that any attempt, particularly by the Executive Government, to interfere with such reports must represent a breach of privilege.

PARA.TAB: I have examined the Hansard green of the question asked by the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), and the Treasurer's response. The Treasurer said, among other things, that on 13 April his department was asked to comment on the report in question. The Treasurer then quoted from the department's response and stated that `to some extent the authors toned down the paragraph in question'.

I have considered the remarks of the honourable member for O'Connor and those of the Treasurer in light of the law and precedents relating to privilege and contempt. On the information available to me, the Treasurer's remarks do not indicate that a matter of privilege or contempt exists. A prima facie case has not been made out, and accordingly I am not willing to give precedence to a motion in relation to the matter.

Yesterday the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns) also raised a matter of privilege. His complaint concerned the alleged actions of the honourable member for O'Connor in entering the House to vote in a division, and he alleged that the honourable member had pushed past a staff member to gain entry to the chamber. I have made inquiries with regard to this matter and, on the information available to me, I do not believe that an issue of privilege or contempt is involved. However, the circumstances as alleged certainly, in my view, raise a serious issue of order or decorum.

I want to make it clear that I will not tolerate any mistreatment of the staff of this Parliament. They serve this House and its members loyally and well. In the particular case which has been raised, the attendant was carrying out the instructions of the Chair to lock the doors of the chamber prior to the holding of a division. Any mistreatment of that person in carrying out her duties is totally unacceptable.
Mrs Kelly—Her duties.
Mr Downer—That is a sexist interjection.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I find it quite extraordinary that on one hand we have members complaining about standards of behaviour and decorum in this place and, on the other, matters of this nature are alleged to have occurred.

PARA.TAB: Mrs Kelly—You are the greatest sexist in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister will come to order. I believe it would be in the best interests of the House if I gave the honourable member for O'Connor an opportunity to respond to the allegations that have been made.

PARA.TAB: Mr Griffiths interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable Minister will cease interjecting across the table.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Speaker, for the opportunity to speak on this matter. Standing orders 199 and 200 deal with the right of entry of members to the chamber in the case of a division. Standing order 199 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Before a division is taken, the Clerk shall ring the division bells and turn a 4 minute sand-glass, kept on the Table for that purpose, and the doors shall not be closed until after the lapse of 4 minutes, as indicated by such sand-glass.
Standing order 200 states:
The doors shall be closed and locked after the lapse of 4 minutes, and then no Member may enter or leave the Chamber until after the division.

It would be obvious, Mr Speaker, from these very clear orders that the right of a member to enter the chamber to undertake his duty to vote in this place is prevented only after the doors have actually been locked. It was my understanding of this standing order, and the obvious innocent misunderstanding of this rule by the attendant concerned, that caused the disagreement at the door which, considering my actual entry, clearly was not locked.

PARA.TAB: Nevertheless, it has been conveyed to me that the attendant concerned was upset by the incident. In the context that I certainly had no intention to cause her concern, or at that moment in time to explain the Standing Orders relating to the situation, I would like to say to her now that I am very sorry that she was upset by my action in demanding my rightful entry. I recognise that she acted in what was her interpretation of her duty; I sincerely hope she now understands that I acted in what was my interpretation of my duty.

The attendants of this chamber and the officers of this Parliament have my highest regard and respect, and I believe most would recognise the respect and politeness I openly offer them from time to time. This instance was an aberration caused by the simple fact of there being no time to explain my reasons when rushing to a division. Had the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns) not taken his precipitate action, it was my intention to have spoken to the attendant concerned to explain the Standing Orders and to reassure her that I understood her action in seeking to prevent me entering the Parliament. I proposed to do this, had things not been different, immediately after the division involved.

I believe this issue would have been prevented had all members of the attendant staff had a better understanding of the Standing Orders that relate to their duties. Of course, in my view their duty is to lock the door. Until it is locked, of course members may enter—

TALK.START.PARA: —They should not push their way in.

—I do not need intervention from the ex-Speaker, the honourable member for Watson (Mr McLeay), who clearly from his actions last night had no idea what the Standing Orders said or of the rights of honourable members. Mr Speaker, the circumstances relating to this are greatly unfortunate and I say to the young lady concerned that I am very sorry she was upset by the matter. It would have been resolved immediately after it occurred except for the action of the honourable member for Petrie, who has a record of getting things wrong in this place.
—When you hear the bells it does not mean you have to knock somebody out.

—The honourable member for Maribyrnong has proof of that. The simple facts are that other members, including the ex-Speaker, should possibly apologise. If this matter had gone its logical course we would have been discussing my rights of privilege regarding entry to this place. But that is to deal with people who try to politicise the issue. I am sorry for the young lady because of the circumstances but I hope that in future she understands, as I believe older members of the staff understand, that the standing order provides that a member can enter until the doors are locked and they should be opened for a member in that process.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Parliamentary Delegation to the South Pacific

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to the South Pacific, 24 July to 11 August 1989. It might seem ancient history to be presenting a report of a delegation from 1989 and the matter of this report has had its moments, I can tell you, Mr Speaker. Anyway, I am very pleased that it is now presented to the Parliament because it contains some important information, not least the contacts with the former Prime Minister of Fiji, Timoci Bavadra, and a statement by him that is contained in that report.

PARA.TAB: The delegation visited four South Pacific countries, namely the Solomon Islands, Fiji, Vanuatu and Western Samoa. It was, as I understand it, the first delegation from the Australian Parliament to make a thorough going visit to South Pacific countries. In the past, I think views had been taken that there were other countries that were more significant to Australia and in the competition for funds for delegations the South Pacific countries had not been highly rated.

Since that delegation there has been a number of such delegations and there is one leaving very shortly, as I understand it. I see this as a very important function of the Australian Parliament. The South Pacific nations on the whole are small and they are not countries that necessarily can afford to participate in a very wide ranging way in the affairs of visits to other countries and in making the necessary contacts that are so important in the flow of friendship and good relations between countries. Australia, therefore, has a very important role to play.

In the last Parliament, it was my privilege to be Deputy Leader of the Australian Delegation to the Inter-Parliamentary Union conferences and to participate in the grouping of Asia-Pacific nations. Of the countries in that, there were only two Pacific nations—Australia and New Zealand. Fiji had been eligible in the past but some time ago it lost its eligibility to attend because it did not have a parliament, following its second military coup.

On the whole, as I said, those small countries do not get the opportunity to participate and it was our privilege at that conference to make sure that, in that world forum of parliaments, proper attention was paid to the concerns of the Pacific. I instance that at one conference one of the two major subjects listed for discussion related to the environment and, of course, the subject of driftnet fishing is one that is very important to those small Pacific nations. It was one that was raised with the delegation on a number of occasions.

The more we know about our South Pacific neighbours and the better our relations, the better it is, I think, for proper consideration of world affairs. On the whole, our relations with South Pacific countries are excellent. There is the odd hiccup with a country or a leader here or there. We were having that sort of experience at the time with the Solomon Islands. Nevertheless, our contacts with parliamentarians from the Solomon Islands, from the Deputy Prime Minister down—because the Prime Minister would not agree to meet us—were excellent, and our discussions were very fruitful, cordial and warm.

I recommend that honourable members look at that statement by Timoci Bavadra, which appears as an appendix in the report, because I think it is a unique and quite valuable document. Since that time, Dr Bavadra has, of course, died and no longer is a figure in Fijian politics. But to read his point of view is an important step to take to understand modern day Fijian politics. There are no other honourable members of this Parliament—in this chamber anyway—who went on that delegation, so I have the privilege to be the only speaker. I am pleased to still be here to be able to present the report four years after the event.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Parliamentary Delegation to the 1992 ASEAN Inter-Parliamentary Organisation Conference

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to the 1992 ASEAN Inter-Parliamentary Organisation Conference, AIPO, Jakarta, Indonesia, incorporating bilateral visits to Papua New Guinea, Indonesia and Thailand, 15 September to 3 October 1992.

PARA.TAB: The 1992 parliamentary delegation to the AIPO conference was significant in a number of respects. The level of representation was higher than those previously sent to AIPO by Australia, consisting, as it did, of me as leader, Senator Grant Tambling, then shadow Minister for the community services, external territories and Northern Australia as deputy leader, Senator Mal Colston, Deputy President of the Senate, and two senior members, my colleague the honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) and the former long serving member for Franklin, Bruce Goodluck.

Such representation reflected Australia's heightened awareness and recognition of AIPO and, through it, ASEAN as well as Australia's role in the Asia-Pacific region. As I indicated in my opening statement to the AIPO Conference, ASEAN has become the most important organisation in South-East Asia. Its success in seeking cooperation on common problems and issues not only amongst member states but also with other countries in the Asia-Pacific region and beyond has grown from strength to strength.

I reiterated to the conference the view which had been expressed both prior to our visit and since in many fora by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) that Australia's future is linked to Asia, that Australia is actively seeking to integrate itself further in the region. Australia wishes to encourage and support more interactions between our peoples at all levels in society to continue to build people-to-people bridges. Annual meetings of AIPO are an important strand in strengthening these linkages with ASEAN.

As parliamentarians we represent various sections of our communities and contribute by providing feedback through our parliamentary duties to the policies of our governments. I also expressed my belief to AIPO, shared by the Government, that there are more issues which bind the countries of ASEAN and Australia together than those which divide us.

I commend the recommendations of the report to the House and particularly those relating to the main purpose of our visit, the AIPO Conference. I point out that the delegation has recommended that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade respond to the Parliament within three months of tabling this report in relation to particular recommendations.

I also draw the House's attention to recommendations relating to the bilateral visits to Papua New Guinea, Indonesia itself and Thailand. The delegation also made a bilateral visit to Papua New Guinea where we were honoured guests of the 17th Independence Day celebrations. We fulfilled a large number of appointments in Indonesia when time permitted between breaks at the AIPO Conference.

I was very impressed with the progress Indonesia is making and the stability of the government there. At a time when Australia is increasingly focusing on matters economic, I note that Indonesia has a 25-year planning period with five-year tranches. We subsequently made a bilateral visit to Thailand, where we were the first delegation from another country to meet the new Presiding Officers, other parliamentarians and Ministers, following the September 1992 election.

Mr Speaker, it was the desire of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay), to increase the profile of Australia at the AIPO Conference. The committee has made a number of recommendations in that regard. At the conference AIPO agreed on an enhanced role for observer countries such as Australia. The delegation has drawn attention in its recommendations to the degree and quality of support services provided to the delegation by the Australian post in Jakarta.

The delegation had a debriefing session and has corresponded with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade on matters of concern in the hope that future delegations might be a little better served. I hope this report will be of assistance to the next AIPO delegation.

I would like to thank my co-delegates and their spouses. I would especially like to thank, on my behalf and on behalf of all members of the delegation and our spouses, our delegation secretary, Mr Dan Barton. He did an outstanding job of organising, herding and negotiating. Whatever the difficulty or challenge, he was always able to overcome it. He never once lost his pleasant manner or sense of humour. The packed itinerary became much more tolerable because of his efforts. Lastly, I would also like to thank those at the Senate printing office who, at short notice, have done a splendid job. I commend the report to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training of the 36th Parliament entitled The literacy challenge: strategies for early intervention for literacy and learning for Australian children, together with the minutes of proceedings.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report which has just been tabled was released out of session on 2 February 1993, prior to the dissolution of the previous Parliament. The recommendations are not necessarily the views of the current committee, although I am sure the members of the committee would agree with most of the findings in the report. The report deals with strategies for early intervention for literacy and learning for Australian children. The committee's findings and recommendations should ensure that all but a tiny number of children will leave primary school with adequate skills.

PARA.TAB: A vast amount of interest has been shown in the area of the literacy skills of children since the committee's inquiry began in May 1992. The committee received hundreds of submissions, the majority of which were from primary schools which were concerned about the numbers of children not gaining adequate literacy skills.

Many adults with literacy problems were once children with literacy problems. It is appropriate, therefore, that this inquiry followed from the committee's earlier report entitled Words at work: A report on literacy needs in the workplace. That inquiry concluded that all students have the right to be literate when they leave school, regardless of their economic or social backgrounds, and that it is the responsibility of schools to see that this happens. A basic grounding in literacy is an essential prerequisite for future learning. Children with learning difficulties must be identified in the first years of schooling, and appropriate strategies must be implemented.

State and Territory education authorities variously estimated that between 10 and 20 per cent of children in the early years are in need of support through early intervention strategies for literacy. These figures, which have been somewhat controversial, are based on discussions which we had with a whole range of people who came before our committee. Those figures were very consistent.

During the inquiry, the committee talked to teachers and principals in each State. It is apparent that central education authorities do not realise the extent of the problem. The special needs of some groups are recognised, such as children from Aboriginal and non-English speaking backgrounds, but the system fails to realise that some children, irrespective of background, experience difficulties in learning to read and write in English.

The area of early education needs to be better resourced. We have made enormous demands upon our teaching force. Indeed, one has to ask why the funding per student for secondary or higher education students is higher than the funding per student for primary school children. Why do we spend $4,000 per student per year in the high school sector, $10,000 plus per student per year in the tertiary sector, but only $3,000 per student per year in the primary sector? Surely one would assume that the needs and demands of younger children who are less independent should be addressed.

It seems that our youngest children are almost invisible when it comes to the funding of these sectors. The committee, therefore, has recommended that funding arrangements for the school sectors be revised and that funding of the primary school sector be increased over the next three financial years to at least the per student funding levels of the secondary sector.

Increased funding will allow restructuring of the primary school sector. That funding has essentially remained the same for the last 50 years. The archaic structure results in impractical expectations of primary school teachers who are responsible for teaching across the crowded curriculum with limited non-contact time.

Indeed, primary school teachers are quick to point out that any problem that arises in the community is automatically put upon the school. People say, `The school can do it. The teachers can do it'. While some schools have employed specialist librarians, music, art and physical education teachers, changes to the primary school structure have not been made in any systemic way.

The committee maintains that innovative structures and teaching strategies can be achieved only with adequate resources. For most schools, current funding and staffing levels leave them with the choice of maintaining the traditional structure or employing specialist teachers and increasing class sizes to unacceptable levels.

The committee recommended that the Government finance a three-year pilot research program in primary schools to investigate and assess the effects of enhanced staffing arrangements, which do not reduce class size but which allow for specialisation and the provision of non-teaching time. Teacher aides who work in the classroom alongside the teacher seem to improve the literacy outcomes of children. The committee has recommended an investigation into the effects of the use of teacher aides.

The committee accepts the argument that no single teaching strategy or methodology works for all children. In fact, the majority of teachers use a range of strategies, adapting them to meet the needs of individual children. It is essential that teachers know which methods are likely to work with certain children.

Current pre-service education may not fully equip students for their role as effective classroom teachers. The committee found it disturbing that teachers of our youngest children no longer require special training, and early childhood courses are no longer compulsory. Also language and literacy components in primary teacher courses are often only a small part of the course. In typical diploma and degree courses, English language and literacy studies currently constitute one-seventh of the total program. The committee has recommended that teacher training be increased to four years, that literacy and language be a compulsory component and that all new teachers be trained in early education and undertake a unit of special education.

A disturbing factor regarding teachers was that many student teachers had poor literacy skills themselves. The committee considers that students entering teacher education courses should have a demonstrated efficiency in English and maths and an aptitude for teaching.

Ideally, all children should be screened for difficulties in literacy learning prior to or at the time of entry to primary school. The committee believes that screening should be done not only by teachers but also by health professionals, such as physiotherapists, occupational therapists, speech pathologists, medical officers and social workers. Unfortunately, in some areas we found that the opportunities to have children screened are negligible or too expensive, or that the facilities are so limited that some of these people may visit a school only once every couple of years.

The normal form of student assessment in schools is teacher observation against a checklist of attainments, which is an essential and effective part of teaching literacy. The form of assessment and the action taken on the results, however, were found to be inconsistent and fragmented. Indeed, in New South Wales, which does systemic testing, no action was taken upon the results which occurred.

The committee recommended that standard assessment tasks be developed which will integrate standardised pen and paper tests with performance measures undertaken by teachers as part of the day-to-day classroom practice. The prime purpose of assessment should surely be the improvement of teaching strategies for the children. Indeed, children who have potential learning problems must be placed in appropriate intervention programs.

The committee has recommended the introduction of two system-wide literary strategies. First steps, from Western Australia, is a whole class strategy which has proven successful. It is a literacy and learning class-based program targeted to support language development, especially in the early years of schooling. The program is based on a continuum of student development and the child's progress is monitored throughout the year and from year to year. First steps also provides in-service training and support for teachers. The committee was impressed with the enthusiasm of teachers and parents for the program and believes that the first steps program is an exciting development in the teaching of reading and writing to all young children.

The other program, reading recovery, is a program that is directed to an individual child who is experiencing difficulty at the end of one year of schooling. The lowest literacy performers in a class have intensive daily instruction in addition to classroom instruction. The committee received many submissions from primary schools and enthusiastic parents of children who had benefited from reading recovery. The committee is satisfied with the evidence of the success of reading recovery, despite some criticisms of the program.

The committee believes that first steps and reading recovery are effective programs and has recommended that the guidelines to the Commonwealth Government's school-based equity programs be revised to ensure that funds are directed to their introduction.

In summary, the committee believes that we need a nation dedicated to universal literacy—every Australian must be able to read and write in English; a national commitment to effective literacy education from the beginning years; appropriate resources for our early education years; highly trained and motivated teachers; teacher training and practice that embraces a range of strategies; and effective strategies for remediation where necessary. We cannot accept that large numbers of children will fail to learn to read and write at school. We are convinced that all but a small number can become successful readers and writers.

I would like to thank my deputy chairman, the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles), and other members of the committee who worked enormously hard and long. I particularly thank our secretary, John Cummins, who soldiered on under sometimes difficult circumstances. To Susan Cardell and Kerry Warner, who were workers on the committee, thank you very much.

We believe the report reflects the former committee's belief that the literacy needs of our young Australians are critical to the development of the Australian community and must be given the very highest priority. I commend the report to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to have this brief opportunity to join the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford), the chairman of our committee, in commending this report to the House, to the Minister and to the nation.

PARA.TAB: In my view this report represents the most significant contribution to the debate on literacy in Australia's history. There is no doubt that we have major problems with respect to early childhood literacy development. During the last parliament this committee, in its first report, inquired into and reported on literacy problems in the adult work force. During that inquiry I took the opportunity to ask every witness who appeared before the committee if we were still growing the problem or if, in fact, it was a problem that existed only in the adult community. I have to say that the teacher representatives, the union representatives and the bureaucracy representatives all said, `No, we do not have any existing problem in our school structure. We are not growing the problem'. However, a number of individual teachers, a number of literacy experts, a number of university professors and lecturers and a number of private citizens said that we have a very real problem.

As a result of that inquiry I pressed hard for the committee to go back and look at early childhood literacy development. The Minister agreed to that and it has resulted in this report. There are a number of major problems that we face with respect to early childhood literacy development. There has been a great deal of work done around the world in trying to come to grips with what the links are that transfer knowledge of the symbols that we use to represent language on a piece of paper through the mind and into speech, which then can be interpreted by someone at a remote place.

It is that transfer of information from speech to the printed word which no-one has ever truly defined the mechanisms of. When we go to impart the knowledge of how to read, how to write and how to spell to young children we encounter difficulty in methodology in trying to come to grips with how best to make their sight and speech patterns work in what is really not a natural habit at all.

We learn to speak naturally because we hear as we grow our parents speak and we hear others in the community speak. There is no similar mechanism with respect to reading. It is not habit that teaches us to read but the conventions that are transferred from the spoken sound into letters and combinations of letters which then we transfer back into sounds again. It is that link which is so important.

It is important that our teachers teach our young children how to read. If there is one critical aspect of primary schooling it is that we give children the opportunity at skills development which allows them at an early age to be able to read, to write, to speak, to spell properly and use structured grammar in a proper manner, and that they are grounded well and truly in these basic skills. It is certainly axiomatic that it is impossible that a child in grade 6 will be an excellent scholar in history if that child cannot read.

The committee's report in summary made seven major observations and I think it is important that we look briefly at them. The first of those is that the committee believes that we need a nation dedicated to universal literacy, that every Australian must be able to read and write in English. That is so important. In this day of modern communications it becomes increasingly important that we fail not one child because if that child cannot read and cannot write then that child surely has no opportunity to progress and to participate both in home life and in society in general.

We talk about equal opportunity. I will say that we really do our worst by our young children if we allow them to grow up without those skills. We need a nation dedicated to literacy and we have got to make it a priority. This report says that it is possible that 20 per cent of our young children at grade 3 or age seven have inadequate literacy skills, that they are either functionally illiterate or that their skill development is behind the development of their peers and they are at risk—at risk of failure.

Secondly, the committee has said that we need a national commitment to effective literacy education from the beginning years. It is certainly true that it must start at an early age and that it starts in the home. It would be terrific if we could come into this chamber and write a rule that says that young children should have their television access limited so that they have time to take more interest in reading real books instead of spending their time in front of the box hour after hour, day after day.

However, we cannot do that because this is a free society. So in some manner we must convey to parents that their role in their children's development is critical and that, if they participate with their children at an early age in reading simple books, in understanding sight and sound relationships and in experiencing the beauty and the warmth in the imagination that develops from reading, then they will have served their children well.

If we then take those children who have a rich background in reading into school and the teachers are properly trained in how to teach young children how to read and they follow through on that, and if we then determine whether or not they have succeeded or if they need more help, then we will advantage those children well.

The committee has said that we need appropriate resources for education in the early primary years. The thing that became abundantly clear is that the differential between spending per child in early primary years and the spending per child in secondary years is almost a national disgrace. For some reason we seem to think that, because they are little, because they do not have a loud voice and they have no political lobby group, our littlies do not deserve as much as those who are older. Well, we are wrong and we have got to fix it and it will take time, but we need the political will in this place to convince our colleagues at State government level that we have to address that spending differential.

We have said that we need highly trained and motivated teachers. That is certainly true. The committee took evidence in case after case that good teachers use a great range of strategies and methodology; they encourage their students and they teach them actively. They are the successful ones. As in any walk of life, as in any profession, there are those who are poor, those who are moderate or mediocre and those who are terrific. It will always be thus, but we need to do a better job, as the chairman of our committee pointed out earlier, in universities and training colleges in teaching teachers how to teach young children the basics of literacy.

We said that teacher training and practice must embrace a range of strategies including structured skill acquisition. In both inquiries we did find evidence that, as we moved to the whole word approach in the late 1970s and early 1980s in Australia, in some respects and in some States and in some systems we overbalanced, one might say. We went from one side of the canoe to the other so swiftly that we just about toppled over because we forgot that one of the basics of language teaching is a structured understanding of phonics, the sounds of letters.

We said that we need effective strategies for remediation. My colleague told you what some of those were. Last, we said assessment and reporting of literacy outcomes are important. In that respect I took a dissenting view and the committee itself was unwilling to support me in that I recommended that the Commonwealth Government finance the Australian Education Council for a national assessment of reading, writing and mathematic skill attainment of all primary students to completion of year 3 and that the results of the national assessment be reported. There is no way the community will ever support the increased spending, that I know is necessary, without national testing.

I would like to thank the committee secretary, John Cummins, Susan Cardell and Kerry Warner for the tremendous work that they did for us in the last parliament and over three very active years and four reports. I thank the House. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sawford Mr R.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a significant report, significant in that it is the very first report tabled in this Parliament that focuses on the needs of young children. I congratulate the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) for giving the reference to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Education, Employment and Training, ably chaired by the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford) and deputy chaired by the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles).

PARA.TAB: The committee secretariat, headed by John Cummins and supported by Susan Cardell and Kerry Warner, was, as the honourable member for La Trobe said, very professional, task oriented on the difficult and often misunderstood public agenda matter and extremely supportive of committee members, particularly when hearings and meetings were held interstate.

There are, of course, proven links between lack of educational attainment and long-term unemployment. There are proven links between lack of educational attainment and deviant behaviour. Prisons in this country are noted for the fact that 90 per cent of inmates are functionally illiterate. Other deviant behaviour, like violence, racism, harassment, vandalism, substance and drug abuse and so on, is exacerbated by the lack of success in educational attainment. It is estimated that at least one million adult Australians are functionally illiterate. All of those factors are largely unseen costs but, make no mistake, the costs are enormous and can be estimated not in the millions but in billions of dollars lost or imposed upon the Australian community.

If this nation continues to follow a fixative mode rather than a preventive one to deal with problems that essentially emanate from poor literacy and educational skills, the long-term costs will simply prove to be non-sustainable. Images that we have seen on televisions from overseas—urban riots in the United States, civil disobedience in the northern cities of the United Kingdom, racial tension in France and Germany—can and will happen in this country if appropriate action is not taken.

The simple fact that needs to be understood by all in this House and in this country is that the needs of young children are not being taken seriously. In fact, they are often trivialised and undervalued and, if given any acknowledgment, it is by negative comment.

We all appreciate that the main responsibility for funding the education of young children is with the States and not Federal government. However, it would be a cheap and inaccurate shot if blame were merely sheeted home to State governments. The raw figures that apply to funding programs for children in Australia are stark. In the 24 developed countries in the OECD, Australia has the third highest percentage of children, yet, when it comes to expenditure from all sources, not just government, on Australia's children, we have the third lowest expenditure, right down there with Turkey, Portugal, Greece and Luxembourg. That is not a clever recipe for a clever country.

I appreciate that significant achievements have been made by the Commonwealth in the past 10 years: retention rates to year 12 have doubled; university places have increased to a total of 36 per cent, the second highest in the world; and a commitment has been made to vocational training. Commitment to training, in particular, is planned to expand significantly by the year 2000. These achievements are indeed magnificent, yet the very basis and foundation for improved secondary retention rates, expanded vocational training and increased university places is largely totally ignored. I refer to our junior primary and primary schools. They are largely, as I said, the responsibility of State governments but equally ignored by the media, unions, business, church groups and the community, not to mention the vested interests in universities, TAFEs and secondary schools. A million adult Australians who are functionally illiterate, 700,000 of whom are Australian born, did not become illiterate at secondary school, TAFE, university or a labour market program. Adult illiterate Australians were first of all young children—very young children—that nearly all sectors have ignored. Commonsense would demand that preventive action is cheaper and more effective than expensive remedial action when it is often too late.

This report tells us that the literacy needs of up to 25 per cent of this nation's children are not being met. That is totally unacceptable. This report points to the cost-effective programs to deal with literacy problems when they occur, hence the early intervention in the junior primary schools by programs such as first steps and reading recovery. Early intervention works. This report tells us:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian language and literacy policy states that, while it is necessary to continue to improve the quality of learning for all children, school is not the biggest influence on their lives nor their learning.

That statement is nonsense. It flies completely in the face of a major longitudinal study conducted by the Inner London Education Authority in 1986 which stated quite categorically: For children between the ages of seven and 11, the effect of schooling can make a substantial difference to a child's future, progress and development and, more importantly, schooling is far more significant than the child's race, sex, age or background.

In other words, schooling for children aged from seven to 11 is the most significant determinant of future success, regardless of race, gender or socioeconomic status. The nation that actually learns that this is an absolute truth will, with a relatively small outlay in the short term, save money in the medium to long term, have a more coherent society and have an internationally competitive edge over all other nations.

PARA.TAB: This report, like all reports, is not perfect, but it is an important one, with its focus on the nation's future—our children. It is much more than a literacy challenge; it is a challenge to all Australians to plan for a better future. I commend the report to the House.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—The time allotted for statements on this report has expired.
Motion (by Ms Crawford) proposed:
That the House take note of the report.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Environment, Recreation and the Arts Committee

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts of the 36th Parliament, entitled Biodiversity: the role of protected areas, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Conserving biodiversity is one of the greatest challenges of our time. We are part of a complex web of life. No species, no matter how dominant, is independent of all others. The existence of each depends to some extent on the existence of all. By ensuring the survival of all forms of life on earth, we help to secure our own future. Conserving biodiversity is about recognising that species live in ecological communities, and preserving the conditions which allow these communities to continue to exist.

PARA.TAB: The report I am tabling today is the committee's second report on biodiversity. It brings together the expertise of Australia's foremost authorities on conservation biology and landscape ecology and proposes an action plan to apply this knowledge. The report is not only authoritative; it is timely because governments are under pressure to demonstrate their commitment to the conservation of biodiversity.

Australia joined 153 other nations in signing the international convention on biodiversity at the Earth Summit in Rio last June. We have been less successful in finalising our own national strategy to conserve biodiversity, but the Federal, State and Territory governments did agree last December to a national strategy for ecologically sustainable development. One of the goals of this strategy is to protect biological diversity.

The committee's recommendations have been formulated in the context of these wider policy developments. They provide a path from agreements on paper to action on the ground. Biodiversity can be conserved effectively only if a bioregional approach is adopted. Bioregions identify the ecological communities which need to be protected. A bioregion is a large area with interrelated ecological systems. Scientific factors, not existing administrative boundaries, identify the region.

The report I have tabled today recommends that ANZECC, the Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council, urgently develop and apply protocols and guidelines for the identification of bioregions on a nationwide basis, and that the Environment Resources Information Network, ERIN, be nominated as the agency responsible for developing standards and guidelines for collecting and recording information which can be used in identifying bioregions and in understanding ecological communities and processes and be given an additional $2.3 million a year for this purpose.

The greatest threat to biodiversity is the loss and fragmentation of natural habitat as a result of human activity. This threat can be effectively countered by carefully selecting significant examples of ecosystems, declaring them nature conservation reserves and managing them appropriately.

Worldwide, about 4.5 per cent of the earth's land area has been given some level of protection from development. Much of this area is not managed adequately. Even if it were, it would conserve only a small proportion of the world's biodiversity. If the amount of land set aside for conservation were doubled in size—that is if 10 per cent of the earth's natural lands were protected—only half of the biodiversity would be preserved.

Protected areas within Australia, where nature conservation objectives are paramount, cover 5.3 per cent of the total land area. Yet a glance at a map shows that, while some ecosystems are fairly well represented, many are not protected at all. Like many other countries, Australia has tended to establish national parks in scenic areas which were not otherwise in demand for human activity. Plant communities on high nutrient soil, however, are very poorly represented.

There are also large continent-wide belts of arid and semiarid lands, extending across the Northern Territory and four States, which are not represented in protected areas. This is not news to conservationists. For at least 25 years, successive organisations, conferences, individual experts and public inquiries have been calling for Australia's protected area system to be made more ecologically representative.

Governments have expanded the number and size of our national parks during this period, but it is still easy to produce a list of ecological communities which urgently require adequate protection. I have already mentioned arid zone communities. There is also a need to protect grasslands, grassy woodlands, herb fields, dry forest on fertile soil, coastal heath, the brigalow belt, estuarine and brackish wetlands, and subtropical and temperate mangrove systems. The list goes on.

Without immediate action, some of these communities will be lost forever. Of the 250,000 hectares of grassland that once spread from Canberra to the Victorian border, less than one per cent remains as natural grasslands today. Over 40 per cent of the forest types in the north-east of New South Wales have little or no representation in protected areas.

The committee considered the idea of recommending the IUCN target of 10 per cent of land in protected areas, but it rejected it. The amount of real estate preserved for natural conservation does not necessarily indicate how effectively biodiversity is being preserved. Instead, the committee has recommended that at least 80 per cent of the identified ecological communities in each bioregion should be represented in highly protected areas.

The committee has recommended a six-year program to significantly expand Australia's national park system. Working through the ministerial council, the Commonwealth would provide the States and Territories with $100 million over six years, on a two for one basis—giving a total of $150 million—specifically to protect ecosystems which are not yet adequately represented in our national parks and reserves.

The report identifies scientific principles which should be applied in selecting effective reserve networks within bioregions with minimal disruption to existing land uses. It stresses that the competing demands and aspirations of the community must be accommodated, where possible, without forfeiting the goal of preserving biodiversity. The committee has also recommended that, in conjunction with the land acquisition program, the Commonwealth should provide a further $50 million to meet the cost of establishing new reserves.

A significant development in park management is that the expertise of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders is now finally being widely acknowledged. The report addresses many of the issues concerning the involvement of Aboriginal people in nature conservation, and the link between traditional knowledge, culture and land.

The Committee has recommended a national policy framework for the joint management of protected areas, and an administrative framework for assisting Aboriginal and Islander communities generally in managing their land. I urge the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to take up these ideas, which emanated from the communities themselves.

This report was released three months ago. It was supported by all committee members. Recently, it was endorsed by the Species Survival Commission which has suggested that the solutions envisaged by the committee are relevant to other countries. State and Territory conservation Ministers have indicated support and there is such interest in the report in the United States that the University of Chicago Press has indicated that it would like to publish it.

The committee was delighted last December when the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) committed the Government to implementing a bioregional approach to the identification of protected areas. He also pledged $14 million over four years to maintain and expand protected areas. That funding is very welcome but it is not enough. It is little more than the NSW Parks Service alone gets each year for land acquisition and management. I urge therefore the Government to accept the committee's proposals and demonstrate that its commitment to protecting biodiversity is sincere.

The report was drafted with superb facility by Lindy Smith and David Brunckhorst with the help of Marlene Lyons. Their intelligent, thoughtful commitment was the key factor in enabling completion of the report before the previous Parliament was dissolved. All members of the committee worked together particularly cooperatively and effectively in preparing what we consider to be a crucial strategy for ensuring the survival of Australia's unique ecosystems. I commend the report to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the report of the Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts on biodiversity, the role of protected areas. I was not on this committee during the inquiry but have come onto it as Deputy Chairman in this term of the Parliament. However, I do want to make some comments in regard to this report which is now before the Parliament, brief though they may be.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting that, in regard to the Parliament, we have a report like this which is talking about the importance in Australia for us to recognise the natural web of life which occurs within Australia. It makes me reflect on the fact that the Australian Academy of Science actually put out a text book, The Web of Life, back in the mid 1970s. Australian young people have been taught about the web of life in biology courses at high schools for at least 15 to 18 years prior to the Parliament actually bringing in a report like this.

In many respects the Parliament is following where the educators have already been. But this report does recognise that there is a need in Australia for us to have a coordinated approach between the Commonwealth and the States. Also, in this report we refer to involving the community in ensuring that this actually happens.

In this way it is an exciting report because it does bring together all levels of involvement—Commonwealth Government, State Government and people at the community level. When we talk about the web of life or bioregional frameworks or ecological systems we have to recognise that everybody has to be involved if it is going to be effective. Particularly when we have a federal system of government there is this need for everybody to come to an ownership of a concept like this so that when we find an ecological system crossing over a State border, then we do get coordinated effort between those States that are involved.

Quite frankly, when the State boundaries were drawn up there was not very much thought given as to whether they crossed over ecological sustainable areas or not. That was irrelevant, it was a line on a map. This report recognises the fact that we need to be good stewards of our natural environment. I think many of us, on reflection, would say that we could have done it a lot better in the past. However, our responsibility as a Parliament is to make sure that we do it to the best of our knowledge and ability in the future.

It indicates to the Parliament the amount of money that we feel is important in sustaining this set-up, the framework for having bioregions and so on. So we believe that this report is something which government, hopefully at both Commonwealth and State levels—the respective Ministers—will look at and grab hold of in the belief that it can be a major contribution to a sustainable diversity of fauna and flora living within the bioregions throughout Australia so that we are not left with the feeling that some species will become extinct through the activities of human beings.

That is what it is about—it is about keeping up the genetic diversity that has been given to us in this great nation of ours. It is about being good stewards of what we have. Some has already been lost but what we have we ought to try to keep. To do that we ought to make sure our decisions are based on scientific evidence. If the Parliament allows scientific evidence to dictate in these areas and we keep the emotional side out of it, I am sure we will come to a very reasoned position, and that reasoned position will give security to the flora and fauna of this country. From that, all of us will benefit and we will enjoy that benefit, whether it is the beauty of the plants or whether it is the excitement which we get from many of the animals we have in this country.
As someone coming on to this committee, I say that I think it is an exciting report and I encourage the Government to adopt the recommendations. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —This report, Biodiversity: the role of protected areas, follows on from the report into the role of community based programs completed in June last year. There is a lot of interest in these matters in my electorate. In fact, some 55 per cent of all New South Wales endangered species are contained within the subtropical rainforests and other ecosystems of the Tweed Valley in northern New South Wales.

PARA.TAB: Throughout both of the ERA committee's inquiries three fundamental elements emerged as essential for action to maintain biodiversity and ecological processes. These are a bioregional approach to planning, an ecologically representative reserve system and community involvement. These elements are also vital to the national ecologically sustainable development strategy to which all governments have agreed.

An important aspect of the recommendations focuses on the need for quantifiable and accurate information. I would like particularly to commend the work of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service's environmental resource information network, ERIN. A key recommendation is to increase funding to ERIN from $2.3 million per annum to $4.6 million in the 1993-94 financial year. This would allow ERIN to extend its network, to increase its efforts in data collection and validation and to provide support to the States and the Territories to enable them to implement a bioregional framework.

Australia is in an enviable position in world terms. We still have the capacity to preserve a breadth of bioregional ecosystems that would be exceedingly difficult in the continents of Europe and North America, where population pressures have already played havoc with many fragile ecosystems.

In northern New South Wales we have seen the near destruction of the big scrub forests through years of farming and clearing. Community action, as identified in this committee's last report, has gone some way towards redressing this. The big scrub forest remnants are being repaired and nurtured and Commonwealth funding, through Greening Australia, is helping. As this current report recognises, information gathering by Greening Australia is playing a vital role in this.

This report recommends that the Commonwealth set as a minimum target the representation of at least 80 per cent of bioregional ecosystems in core protected areas by the turn of the century. It is recommended that the Australia and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council, ANZECC, establish a specific purpose task force to facilitate, through a bioregional framework, the identification, development and consolidation of a nationwide system of ecologically representative areas. I commend this report's recommendation that the Commonwealth provide $100 million over six years to establish a tied grants program specifically to acquire identified areas to consolidate the establishment of such a nationwide system.

Further, I would encourage the adoption of the recommendation to include the participation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. It is hoped that the draft national biodiversity strategy will be revised to reflect the complexity and sensitivity of seeking to identify unused Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander knowledge and practices in biodiversity research and conservation.

Earlier, I referred to the complex nature of the biodiversity in my electorate and, in the time allocated, I would like briefly to refer to that. In my electorate, there are some 13 species of plants, which fall within the 20 most rare and endangered plants in New South Wales. It is this concentration of biodiversity in small pockets and refuges which makes protection of our nation's flora and fauna both practicable and essential. It should not be forgotten that most modern drugs and chemicals are based on, or are based on synthesis from, natural compounds. Our future prosperity and, indeed, possibly our continuance on this planet is inextricably linked to biodiversity. Until we thoroughly understand all the links and interrelationships within the web of life, as mentioned by the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles), it is logical that we should exercise a degree of caution by preserving our nation's, and indeed the planet's, biodiversity.

The proclamation of world heritage areas, such as those within the Richmond electorate, is but one of the many steps required to protect our biodiversity. Already we are seeing the considerable success that ecotourism enterprises can generate. Our biodiversity is being recognised more and more as an economic asset and the future will only serve to raise this importance.

I would like to pay tribute to the staff of the committee, to David Brunckhorst, Lindy Smith and Marlene Lyons, for their assistance. In summing up, I refer to the comments made, quite rightly, by the honourable member for Braddon in regard to the involvement of all levels of government and the community in the preservation of biodiversity. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —When the environment committee commenced its work in the area of biodiversity some two years ago, `biodiversity' was a word that perhaps was not widely understood in the community. Indeed, I can recall my very first contacts with it on the committee. We actually spent some time ourselves trying to define what the term actually meant and what its significance was to Australia. One of the successes and one of the achievements of the two years of work that the environment committee has put into this particular field has been an enhancement of the community understanding of biodiversity issues and the importance of these matters for the future of our country. Indeed, it has enhanced community understanding of our responsibilities as this generation of custodians to hand on to future generations a proper representation of the biodiversity of our country.

PARA.TAB: There have been a lot of people associated with this work over the two years and, as the new committee has commenced its work in this Parliament, it is perhaps of note that many of the people associated with this report are no longer part of the committee. I begin by paying tribute to some of the former members of the committee, particularly Mr Webster, Mr Dubois, Mr Edwards, Mr Scott and Mr Fisher, all of whom have not returned to this Parliament and so will not be continuing their work on the committee. I mention, particularly, Mr Webster, the deputy chairman of the committee, who put a great deal of effort into the committee and who regarded environmental issues of great significance. His contribution to the committee will, of course, be missed.

I would like to mention my former colleague Peter Fisher, who has the remarkable record of 13 years of service to the committee. This will obviously be the last report to which he will be attached, as well. Peter put a lot of time and effort into the environment committee's work. He attended regularly and was involved in all of the inquiry's activities. I mention the honourable member for Cook (Mr Dobie) and the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus), who are also not continuing on the committee for various reasons. We compliment Mrs Gallus on her promotion in the area of environment. I know that her interest in this area will continue.

While paying tribute, I mention the previous chairman of the committee, the honourable member for Grayndler (Ms McHugh), who began as committee chair when we were working in the biodiversity field and who continues her interest in that area. There have been a lot of people involved in the preparation and development of this report, but I want to refer particularly to Dr David Brunckhorst, our technical officer and leading adviser in the field. He came for one report and stayed for two, and certainly helped, with his personal knowledge, to enhance the work of the committee. I mention Lindy Smith, who is also no longer with the committee, and Marlene Lyons, who is still with the committee, and thank them for the way in which they facilitated the work.

Of course, an involvement with and the development of a proper policy in the area of biodiversity is about more than just land acquisitions. It is true that we need to have representative areas, and the target set by the committee involves 80 per cent of our bioregions, but it is also important that we devote adequate resources to the management of these regions. It is not true to say that once the land has been acquired it can just be neglected and it will take care of itself. True, nature has great powers of healing and great powers to regenerate and rebuild itself, but we certainly need, as a country, to devote resources so that we can adequately manage the areas that we put aside as national parks and for national enjoyment.

It is sad that there are often conflicts that develop in relation to the acquisition of new areas. These are often urban and rural conflicts. Those who live in an area do not always appreciate its qualities because they have been there all their lives. Perhaps they have also put in a great deal of their own efforts to care for it and to ensure that it is adequately preserved, so that sometimes they resent the intrusion. On the other hand, urban visitors to an area that they seldom see may have a heightened admiration of what our country has to offer. It is important that these sorts of issues be resolved, that we each recognise the importance of an area to others, and that there is a recognition of the economic contribution that some of these areas are making. We have a national responsibility also to recognise everyone's interest in that regard. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —This report from the Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts is the second of two on biodiversity, and it brings out very clearly the need to maintain biodiversity, a bioregional approach and community involvement. Having said that, Mr Deputy Speaker, I just say how much I enjoyed the time that I spent on the environment committee and I know you too were a part of that committee for some of that time. The memories that I take away from the committee will stay with me for the time that I am in Parliament. I pay tribute to the present head of the committee, the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), who joined us on the last excursion we had. I remember very clearly my first impression of the new chairman: he got off the plane in some wilderness area in Western Australia, disappeared with his binoculars and was never seen again until the plane was revved up ready to go, when he emerged from the trees exactly at the right moment with his binoculars in hand. I think every bird in the area had been observed during that time.

PARA.TAB: Also on that excursion, I remind honourable members who were there, we took a trip out to Smith Point—I think that was the name of the place at the top of the Northern Territory—and on the way back the boat broke down. There was no radio on the boat and only one technician, who was both the captain of the boat and the repairer of the engines. We had one engine that was still going. As we putted along at a very slow rate heading for the mainland—which we would likely reach at about 2 o'clock in the morning—the boat captain had to repair the engines. He put the then member for Mallee, Mr Fisher, in charge of the boat and said, `Head towards the sun', and pointed to this large red orb in the distance. There was Mr Fisher heading towards the sun as the then member for Macquarie, Mr Webster, was down with the captain trying to fix the engine. We were all watching with bated breath to see what would happen when a small voice came from Mr Fisher sitting at the controls, and it said, `But what happens when the sun goes down?'.

Like the member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss), who spoke before me, I would like to pay tribute to the committee secretariat, Lindy Smith, David Bronckhorst and Marlene Lyons, and to people who are no longer with the committee, David Crawford, Ian Dundas—who I believe is back temporarily with the committee—and Grant Harrison, all of whom did such fantastic work for us on that committee. They took us all around Australia to some of its most beautiful places, made sure we got there on time and supplied substitute aircraft when the ones we were on broke down. I am not quite sure of the record of that committee, but I believe it is one of the few committees that have never brought down a minority report.

So to the new members of the committee: I wish you very well and hope that your success with the committee is as great as the success we had and that, for the environment committee, the sun never will go down.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! I join with my colleagues in not only the support of the report but also the comments that were made about previous members and the staff, Lindy, David and Marlene. Hopefully, the hard work and cooperative nature of the committee are reflected in the way that the recommendations of the report are received and acted upon. The allotted time for statements has expired.
Motion (by Mr Langmore) proposed:
That the House take note of the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with standing order 102B the debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)congratulates the UN Commission on Human Rights for adopting a resolution highly critical of the human rights situation in the Indonesian-occupied territory of East Timor;
(2)congratulates the Australian Government for supporting the resolution;

(3)calls upon the Australian Government to persuade the Indonesian Government to comply with paragraph 9 of the resolution by enabling the UN special rapporteurs on torture and on extrajudicial, summary or arbitrary executions and the UN working group on arbitrary detention and on enforced or involuntary disappearances to discharge their mandates in accordance with the terms of the resolution; and
(4)welcomes the resumption of talks under the auspices of the Secretary-General of the UN to arrive at a just, comprehensive and internationally acceptable solution to the question of East Timor.

This is the fifth speech in this place and the second motion that I have moved on the question of East Timor. When it came to preparing my notes in support of this motion, I reviewed what I had said on those previous occasions. It will come as no surprise to honourable members that, after reading these prior contributions and reviewing what has occurred in that time frame, I experienced a range of emotions in response.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, anger: I was angry that after 18 years of bloodshed, terror, torture and abuse suffered by East Timorese, 18 years of resolutions by the UN General Assembly and Security Council and other arms of the UN and 18 years of pontificating, posturing and preaching by a variety of national and international figures, Indonesia is still able to get away with thumbing its nose at the world while maintaining its chains of bondage around the territory of East Timor.

I was also frustrated that all the efforts of the many caring and compassionate people around the world who are genuinely seeking a fair resolution to this matter have not been able to advance the cause one inch. I was ashamed that my own party, along with our Opposition colleagues when they were in government, had allowed these actions to continue and had given official recognition to an act of invasion and a reign of terror. I was despairing for the thousands of East Timorese who still today live in fear because of the continuing repression and physical abuse that are the hallmarks of Indonesia's military occupation of East Timor. But, overwhelmingly, I was determined to maintain my efforts to pursue a just and lasting peace and resolution which fulfils the aspirations of the East Timorese people.
