The motion before the House today seeks to highlight the most recent international expression of opinion about Indonesia's policies in controlling East Timor. It joins a very long line of other resolutions, actions and decisions, severely criticising the Indonesian Government for maintaining a regime of official abuse, torture and murder, to control the population of East Timor.

Indonesia is probably second only to South Africa for racking up condemnatory resolutions around the world about its actions in East Timor—and that is not a very good record to achieve. The international community has once again expressed the view that the United Nations should insist on gaining access to the disputed territory to examine and report on the questions of torture, extrajudicial, summary or arbitrary executions, arbitrary detentions and disappearances.

I am pleased that the Australian Government finally agreed to support this resolution at the UN Commission on Human Rights in Geneva, in contrast to its previous position where it had tried desperately to prevent Indonesia's activities from being placed under the international spotlight. If, as Indonesian propaganda would have us believe, the situation in East Timor is now normal and there is little unrest or disturbance by resistance forces, why will Indonesia not allow objective, international investigators in to examine the situation? The reason, of course, is that there is still a lot to hide.

Australia must follow up its support for this resolution with some concerted efforts to achieve its implementation. It is very disappointing to witness the Australian Government—my government—now appearing to back-pedal from its previous commitment. I have constantly been advised that our positive relationship with the Indonesian Government enables us to have some influence over its actions and activities on human rights issues. I am afraid I have seen little evidence of the truth of this claim.

I believe the Indonesian authorities treat our protestations and pleadings with contempt and ridicule. I have not witnessed any lessening of the chains of bondage around, or the continuous harassment and abuse of, East Timorese people because of our special relationship. In fact, the last 18 months have probably been the worst in a decade for the inhabitants of this territory.

I remind honourable members of the arrests, beatings, torture and murder of hundreds of East Timorese that both preceded and followed the November 1991 Dili massacre. I remind honourable members of the massacre itself; the killing of over 100 innocent, unarmed civilians by Indonesian troops at Santa Cruz cemetery in Dili. I remind honourable members of the arrest and jailing of some of the East Timorese involved in these protests, and of the farcical slap on the wrist meted out to the troops who perpetrated this massive crime. I remind honourable members of the arrest, torture, trial and sentencing to life imprisonment of the East Timorese resistance leader Xanana Gusmao. Where have Australia's efforts had any impact on this record?

Indonesia does not support or respect human rights. Its political system is a mockery of democracy. Its military exercises unfettered power throughout Indonesian society. Its judicial system is a joke that denies any semblance of fairness or natural justice. Its continuing suppression of dissent and its ruthless use of violence and intimidation is contrary to all international conventions and treaties.

Xanana Gusmao has now been sentenced to life imprisonment for fighting for freedom for his people. East Timor was invaded by Indonesian troops in December 1975 and has been militarily occupied and suppressed since that time. Gusmao is a political prisoner—a leader of his people seeking justice, fair treatment and self-determination for East Timorese. Will Australia's good offices with Indonesia help Xanana Gusmao gain his freedom?

It is time for Australia and the other signatories to the UN Commission on Human Rights to back their words and protestations with some definitive action. Pleas for reconciliation will continue to fall on deaf ears in Indonesia, unless they are backed up by hard economic consequences. Due to its treatment of Xanana Gusmao and its continuing repression, Indonesia should no longer enjoy the respect of the international community.

If Indonesia fails to accede to the demands of the resolution of the UN Commission on Human Rights and the previous resolutions over the past 18 years of the General Assembly and the Security Council, it should be suspended from membership of the United Nations. The UN Security Council should act towards Indonesia in the same way that it has acted towards South Africa, Iraq, Yugoslavia and the Khmer Rouge when they have failed to implement Security Council decisions. It should impose economic sanctions against Indonesia.

The truth is that nothing less than this response will force Indonesia to the negotiating table to resolve the question of East Timor. Does Australia have the courage of its convictions on the importance of human rights and the commitment to the right of self-determination, as demonstrated in our position in other international conflicts, to stand up to Indonesia on this matter?

I conclude my comments with some extracts from Xanana Gusmao's defence plea to the Dili district court, a plea he was refused permission to deliver by the mockery of a legal system operating in Indonesia. He pleads:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) The question of East Timor is the responsibility of the international community, a question of international law. It is a case in which universal principles are at stake, a case where the decolonisation norms of the UN have been manipulated, a case where Indonesia has disregarded the resolutions of the UN, a case therefore of the flagrant violation of the principles of the Non-Aligned Movement, and of the universal pattern of law, peace and justice.

(2) This court claims that it is trying me for crimes committed against the Indonesian State and for the illegal possession of firearms. I know that everything has been arranged for me to be convicted.

(3) The ones who should be standing before an international court are, in the first place, the Indonesian government for crimes committed in the past 17 years in East Timor; the US administration which gave the green light to the invasion on 7 December 1975 and has since given military aid and political support for Indonesia's genocide in East Timor; the governments of Australia and western Europe for their policy of complicity towards Indonesia; and finally, the Portuguese government for its grave irresponsibility in the decolonisation of East Timor.

PARA.TAB: The UN recognises as legitimate all means of opposition to the colonial presence in any part of the world where people are fighting for liberation. My struggle and the resistance of my people and of Falintil. . . should be placed in this context, standing above Indonesian law.

SPEECH.PARA: (4) . . . the UN does not recognise Indonesian sovereignty over East Timor, a sovereignty which was imposed by the means of force, by the practice of violence and the systematic violation of the most fundamental human rights.

(5) I appeal to the international community to understand that it is time to show that the New World Order is about to begin. This requires acts that will bring to an end the situation inherited from the past.

(6) I appeal to all friends of East Timor, parliamentarians from Europe, America, Japan and Australia, to go on pressing their own governments to change the double standards applied to similar cases where systematic violations of UN resolutions occur, as in the cae of Indonesia's behaviour regarding East Timor.
(7) I appeal to the Secretary-General of the UN to ensure that the solution he seeks for East Timor is based on universal principles and international law. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support some of the sentiments expressed in the motion before the House. I was rather intrigued at the praise for the Government expressed in the motion, because the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson), in his speech, actually took a more robust line in relation to his attitude towards his government's performance in this area and, I think, a more correct line than he did in the motion before the House.

PARA.TAB: I do join with the honourable member for Moreton in the expressions that he has used, because we all remember that several weeks after the Dili massacre in November 1991, many members from both sides of this House rose to condemn the actions of the Indonesian Government in relation to that incident. It is often forgotten that some of the first boat people—in fact, the first boat people—to Australia, were people from East Timor bumping ashore in Darwin all those many years ago. A lot of people think that they were Indo-Chinese refugees, but in fact they were not.

Those of us who have had a longstanding interest and involvement in human rights issues were, and still are, appalled by the repeated human rights abuses sustained, over a very long period of time now, by the East Timorese people. I do not think there is any doubt that it is very clear by international standards that human rights had been breached in East Timor, and that Australia—quite legitimately—had a right to join in international condemnation of the actions of the military in its treatment of the citizens of East Timor on 12 November. This we did, without apology.

The Indonesian Government undertook an inquiry into the matter, and it is fair to say that many people were not very happy with the results of that inquiry. It was a step forward, but a fairly small step forward. Obviously, that step has got to be accelerated very greatly in the future. That inquiry concluded that the Indonesian troops overreacted to the demonstration. I think that is a nice way of putting it: `overreacted to the demonstration'. There were well over 100 people killed—shot, as the honourable member has mentioned—defenceless people. It certainly was an overreaction to the demonstration.

The result of that inquiry was that 10 soldiers were sentenced to up to 18 months in gaol for their role in the shootings. East Timorese involved in the demonstrations, by contrast, received sentences of from five years to life. We brought this matter up when we visited Indonesia last year as part of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. On a number of occasions we had the opportunity to raise with Indonesian authorities the extraordinary discrepancy in the sentencing of the civilians as against the military.

During his visit to Indonesia in May 1992 the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said that when speaking with President Suharto he repeated the Australian Government's view that the Indonesian Government's response to the Dili killings had been a credible one. But international concern about continued human rights abuses in East Timor led the United Nations Commission on Human Rights to move a resolution expressing its deep concern at the reports of continuing human rights violations in East Timor. That resolution, as we know, was passed by 22 votes to 12 on 10 March 1993. Unfortunately, that was not a majority of the votes; it was a majority of those who voted but, unfortunately, there were a lot of abstentions and it was not a majority of all the people who had the opportunity to vote.

The resolution was, among other things, gravely concerned about continuing allegations of serious human rights violations and noted with concern, in this context, the reports of the special rapporteur on the question of torture, of the special rapporteur on extra judicial summary or arbitrary executions and of the working group on enforced or involuntary disappearances. These are very serious concerns, and I joint with the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) in congratulating the United Nations Commission on Human Rights for adopting the resolution.

I then have to again draw attention to the second part of the honourable member's motion, where he does congratulate the Australian Government. The Australian Government was involved. It did add a rider to its vote—and I agree with it—which said that it would have been better if there had been a greater joining in the voting to ensure that there was a majority.

At this stage I draw the attention of the House once again to the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on a review of Australia's efforts to promote and protect human rights, which was tabled in this Parliament in December of last year. The members of that committee had the opportunity over several months to hear submissions from a very large number of people and a range of groups in relation to events in Indonesia and in East Timor in particular.

The section on East Timor, in chapter 6 of that report, really demonstrates the situation there more clearly and in a brief and understandable way. It is a description of the events and the situation there which I commend to all honourable members. I do not think it has received enough attention by the media in this country. In paragraph 6.24 it says the following about the present Australian Government. I inform the House that this is from this agreed committee report:

SPEECH.PARA: Given the situation in East Timor, its proximity to Australia and its historic and emotional ties for many Australians and, in particular, the scale of the massacre on 12 November and the injustices done to the victims of that incident, it would seem the incident and its outcome deserve much stronger condemnation. Furthermore, it is important that the Australian Government should be consistent in its reaction to human rights outrages of this kind. Australia has a laudable history of promoting human rights and condemning human rights abuses in distant parts of the world. By softening, as Australia did, the strongly worded resolution on the massacre which was drafted by the European Community, we have lessened our credibility and this, finally, is counterproductive to any future human rights responses we make.

That is a very important statement by the joint committee because we have a laudable record on human rights abuses around the world. But when it gets close to home, we get a bit pussyfooted about the whole thing, and this does lessen our credibility both within Australia and, particularly, internationally. It is something which I believe the Government must take much more notice of than has been the case in the past. It is interesting that there was a resolution by the committee in relation to Indonesia. It stated:

The Committee urges the Australian Government to support actively a new UN initiative to begin consultations with all the parties to the conflicts in East Timor, Irian Jaya and Aceh with a view to negotiating a settlement, and to draw to the attention of the Indonesian Government the gross injustice of the application of the anti-subversion law to those involved in peaceful protest.

Again, I think that is a measured, responsible report by the joint committee which should be taken most seriously by the Government. I want to join with the honourable member for Moreton in a quote from the defence of Gusmao, which unfortunately was not allowed to be read to the court. He has read one excerpt from that defence; I would like to read another excerpt from it. It states:

In the United Nations, Jakarta cannot suppress the fact that Portugal is an interested party in the solution of the problem. And so, Jakarta should also never forget that the Maubere people (the people of East Timor) have already demonstrated that the idea, the objective for which they have fought and resisted to this day can never die. People die but ideas stay alive.

I think that encapsulates the present situation in East Timor. I am strongly of the view that it would be very much in Indonesia's best interests for it to seek a political settlement to this ongoing festering sore which does a great deal to detract from the international reputation of Indonesia. I have a great deal of regard for the people of Indonesia and I think their progress has been remarkable in so many different areas, but internationally their reputation is being very gravely besmirched by the performance of their Government in relation to East Timor. I once again would urge the Australian Government to take up most strongly with the Indonesian Government the need for a negotiated settlement in relation to this tragic situation in East Timor. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Mr L.D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) has quite correctly pointed out that the tone of the mover of this motion today is somewhat more negative than the original motion. We do, of course, commend Australia's role in supporting the resolution mentioned in the motion because it does speak of continuing allegations of serious human rights violations. It notes with concern in this context the reports of the Special Rapporteur on the question of torture. It speaks of the improved access by international authorities to prisoners within East Timor, but it remains disappointed that such access is still frequently denied. The resolution of that United Nations body also regrets that the Indonesian investigation into the actions of the members of its security personnel on 12 November 1991, from which resulted loss of life, injuries and disappearances, failed to clearly identify all those responsible for these actions.

PARA.TAB: So the original resolution that we are supporting is thankful for small mercies, that the Australian Government, which has not had a commendable performance on this particular issue, has seen its way to supporting this United Nations body's resolution. However, these matters have been overshadowed by the sentencing of Xanana Gusmao in the last week. That sentencing followed a fairly discredited judicial process, a situation where a large number of people thought that his original televised confessions and admissions of wrongdoing were perhaps affected by doctoring of television broadcasts, and the fact that he was held incommunicado for 17 days without access by the Red Cross and that there were strong possibilities of torture during that period.

In that first statement he came up with amazing comments such as that East Timor is part of Indonesia, and he attacked Jose Ramos Horta as basically treating himself too importantly and not worrying about the Timorese. In that initial statement he basically denounced everything he ever stood for, and the statement which the Indonesian authorities refused to allow in the past week really puts into context that original forced statement.

That Indonesian legal process, of course, also involved a court appointed lawyer. It entailed the refusal of the court to allow the Indonesian legal aid institute access. As many have said, this past week it refused his right to make a defence statement which has been leaked to the rest of the world. So that situation has very much overshadowed the minimal effort that Australia has made in the Commission on Human Rights. The resolution itself represented the culmination of international concern about what the Indonesians have done in Timor since 1975.

In 1975 we saw an invasion which, on conservative estimates, eventually entailed the murder of 200,000 people. I think the Indonesian Government would accept that the Jakarta Post has some credibility. In 1992 the long term impacts of that invasion are shown in figures which indicate that, while the life expectancy of Indonesians is 56 years, that of the East Timorese is 42 years; the female literacy rate is 27 per cent while nationally it is 65 per cent; the infant mortality rate is 166 in 1,000 against 84 in 1,000 throughout Indonesia. That also puts in context Indonesia's constant references to what the Portuguese failed to do for 400 years. There have been improvements in road access, communications and other things which enforced the occupation, but there are grave problems still in the standard of living in that country.
I also want to cite part of the statement which Xanana made, but which, as I say, the Indonesians did not allow to be read. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: I acknowledge military defeat on the ground. I am not ashamed to say so. On the contrary, I am proud of the fact that a small guerrilla army was able to resist a large nation like Indonesia, a regional power which in a cowardly fashion invaded us and wants to dominate us by the law of terror and crime, by the law of violence, persecution, prison, torture and murder.
The moment has come for Jakarta to recognise its political defeat on the ground. I don't know if it was to impress me that they placed armed tentaras [soldiers] on the route. . . to the court.

I have been flattered in all kinds of ways in order to convince me to behave here like a docile Indonesian. I have had to behave like one, and the witnesses brought here have also had to behave in that fashion.
I commend the motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak reluctantly in support of this motion. I say `reluctantly' because the resolution of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights, which the motion endorses, speaks of the `violent incident of 12 November 1991 in Dili'. This is the muted language of diplomacy, yet this incident was in fact a massacre by Indonesian security forces of a large number of innocent, unarmed East Timorese. There can be no justification for what occurred. It is a measure of Indonesia's interest in investigating this crime that it is not known how many people were killed and that those responsible were not all identified.

PARA.TAB: Another shameful aspect of the affair was the subsequent trials. East Timorese civilians, not indicted for violent activities, received severe sentences while comparatively moderate sentences were meted out to only a few members of the security forces involved in the shooting. The truth is that the trials were a farce. The perpetrators of the crimes became the judges and declared the victims to be the criminals.

The United Nations resolution goes on to express `deep concern at the reports of continuing human rights violations in East Timor'. This again is a muted and inadequate reference to torture, summary executions, arbitrary imprisonment and disappearances that are a continuing feature of life for the East Timorese.

It has to be stressed that this is not happening in some place conveniently far away, but on Australia's northern doorstep: Timor is closer to Darwin than is Alice Springs. This motion borders on lip service in offering the congratulations of the House to the UN commission for its resolution. The Dili massacre happened 18 months ago; it has taken a long time for the United Nations to make a mildly critical statement.

The essential part of the motion concerns the pressure that must be brought to bear on the Indonesian authorities to allow UN officials to properly investigate human rights abuses in East Timor. As a close neighbour and a country with a very public concern for human rights, Australia has to be involved. Australia supported the UN resolution and now it has to follow up with direct approaches to the Indonesian Government to ensure its implementation.

We also need to atone for our complicity in what has occurred in East Timor for the last 18 years. The effective appeasement of Indonesia by the governments of the United States, Portugal, western Europe and ourselves has allowed Indonesia to progress from the original invasion to the Dili massacre, and now the subsequent show trials culminating in last week's travesty with the sentencing of the East Timorese leader. It was a trial with all the standard features of the judicial systems of military dictatorships from time immemorial—the false confession, the stifled defence, the secrecy.

In the face of seeming world acceptance of all this, the military dictatorship of Indonesia is now trying to cloak its actions under the guise of cultural sovereignty. The whole concept of human rights, as established under the United Nations Universal Declaration, is now under challenge from Indonesia and other authoritarian regimes in the Asia region in a sinister attempt to justify their actions in recent years.

What is at issue is the universality and the indivisibility of human rights. The UN conference on human rights to be held in Vienna next month will see an attempt to assert by these regimes that human rights have to be culturally adjusted to meet their society's particular traditions and needs. The regional conference held in Bangkok earlier this year, from which Australia was excluded, challenged the concept of universal human rights based on the primacy of rights of economic development, cultural needs and national sovereignty. If accepted, these self-serving justifications would mean that human rights, recognised as being the right of individuals under international law, could alter according to their nationality and cultural group—in other words, to provide carte blanche for any authoritarian regime.

There can be no pretence about this, as the people of Asia have made clear. More than 180 organisations in the Asia-Pacific region have signed a statement endorsing the indivisibility and independence of all human rights. The Government, through the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), has indicated it will support the UN commission at the Vienna conference. Indonesia needs to be clearly told that human rights are universal. They cannot be washed away by the sophistry of cultural sovereignty; neither can bullets, massacres or military dictatorships.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Truss)—Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made a order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)notes the visit of Mr Vo Van Kiet, Prime Minister of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam to Australia, and deplores his Government's record of substantial human rights abuses; and
(2)calls on the Government to:

PARA.TAB: (a)immediately and unconditionally release all political prisoners and prisoners of conscience, including the Venerable Thich Huyen Quang;
(b)introduce basic human rights to Vietnam, including freedom of assembly, religious worship and speech, a free press and free and open elections;
(c)provide for the creation of a pluralist free enterprise economy; and

(d)demonstrate to the Parliament of Australia how and where aid monies provided to Vietnam by Australia are spent and how that aid encourages the cultivation of a more democratic and free society in Vietnam.

SPEECH.PARA: The visit to Australia by the Prime Minister of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam is the first visit of a Vietnamese head of state since the fall of Saigon in 1975 and the tightening of the grip of communism over the peoples of Vietnam. The visit is a very important opportunity for Australia to let Mr Vo know of the serious concerns felt by many Australians—including, of course, a substantial Australian-Vietnamese community—about the continuing human rights abuses that are occurring within the Socialist Republic of Vietnam. They need to be addressed. I belatedly understand from the news that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has agreed to discuss these important issues of human rights with Mr Vo during the visit, after much pressure from the Australian-Vietnamese community.

PARA.TAB: Many acknowledge Mr Vo as being credited with the resurgence of the Vietnamese economy, after becoming Prime Minister in August 1991. But for many of the 150,000 Vietnamese Australians, the visit is one of some trepidation. Mr Vo's visit for many around Australia brings back painful memories of the oppression of the communist regime from which many of them fled in terror, in particular during the 1970s and the early part of the 1980s.

I noted on television last night, as I was watching the news, the painful expression, the signs of distress, on the part of one particular member of that community as they re-enacted the placement of prisoners in what was called the `tiger cage' during a demonstration yesterday of some of the techniques of oppression used by the Vietnamese regime against its own people.

As a result of those protests from around Australia we are today debating a motion calling for the Vietnamese Government—whose record of substantial human rights abuse is to be deplored—to immediately and unconditionally release all political prisoners and prisoners of conscience, including the Venerable Thich Huyen Quang; introduce basic human rights to Vietnam, including freedom of assembly, religious worship and freedom of speech and press and free and open elections; provide for the creation of a pluralist free enterprise economy and demonstrate to the Parliament of Australia how and where aid moneys provided to Vietnam by Australia are spent and how that aid encourages the cultivation of a more democratic and free society in Vietnam.

There would be many of those in the large contingent of protesters outside Parliament House today who could provide us with examples of allegations of ill-treatment, torture and human rights abuses in their former homeland. They would probably refer to instances such as the case of the 60-year-old poet Vu Hoang Chuong; the writer and mathematician, Ho Huu Tuong; 80-year-old Catholic priest Father Hoang Quynh; lawyer Tran Van Tuyen; and high dignitary of the United Buddhist Church of Vietnam, An Quang Pagoda. These people are alleged to have been punished and tortured as part of that campaign of oppression and terror that is meted out to those that are seen as a threat or in some way contrary to the interests of the communist regime.

Vietnamese communities cite these as examples of how Vietnamese religious communities are the target of government harassment and persecution, in many instances, simply for the quiet, non-violent exercise of their religious beliefs. This is the dark secret of Hanoi, and it is an issue that must not be glossed over during the visit by Mr Vo to Australia. With more than 60 million adherents to the Buddhist faith in Vietnam it is fundamental to their human rights that they are able to practise their religion in freedom from persecution or harassment.

Involving 85 per cent of Vietnam's population, the Buddhist church has deliberately refrained from taking an active involvement in political activities but, after 2,000 years of religious practice, it is unlikely that the campaign of persecution and harassment and the influence of torture or imprisonment would be likely to have intimidated those of that faith and to have prevented them from practising their faith. It is important that we in Australia provide them with the support to ensure that they are provided with the opportunity of practising their faith, free from persecution and harassment.

Against the backdrop of the background philosophy of socialism, organisations such as Amnesty International, the United Buddhist Church in Vietnam, the Sakyamuni Buddhist Centre and various branches of the Vietnamese community in Australia are calling for the release of all prisoners of conscience. I join them in that call and, of course, also call for the release of the Venerable Thich Huyen Quang, Acting Secretary of the United Buddhist Church in Vietnam and a nominee for the 1979 Nobel Peace Prize, who was arbitrarily arrested and tortured in 1977, released then rearrested in 1982 and then banished to his native village, where he is forbidden to exercise the practice of his cherished religion.

Obviously, the basic human right to practise one's religion freely without fear of reprisal must be reinstated, along with the freedom of assembly, freedom of speech, freedom of the press and fair and open elections. The reinstatement or provision of those freedoms must occur without delay. The token release of prisoners in a bid to secure Western donor aid is simply not enough. Immediate and lasting reforms are needed to improve Vietnam's much criticised human rights legacy.

As we know from our recent social history, the legacy of the Vietnam war, the subsequent torrent of human rights abuses and the Vietnam Government's systematic oppression of many of its people has been a steady flow of refugees to other parts of the world. Many of those refugees who came to Australia have become a very important part of the Australian community. In many cases they have done extremely well in Australia, having qualified themselves to become professionals. They have become doctors, teachers and lawyers, or have opened businesses and instituted community groups, clubs and associations that have become part of the fabric of Australian society.

In fact, there are two million Vietnamese refugees who have been resettled around the world. Like the 150,000 Vietnamese in Australia they refuse to accept the reign of communism in their former homeland. It is interesting to note that only 15,000 of these Australian Vietnamese have returned to Vietnam to seek out friends and family.

Let us turn briefly to the reasons for Mr Vo's visit. It is clear that the absence of the involvement of the United States in the Vietnamese economy—another legacy of the Vietnam war—has opened the door for Australian investment. By the time the United States lifts its trade embargoes, possibly even within the next few weeks, we will have already had a secure foothold in areas such as telecommunication and oil exploration through the involvement of OTC and BHP.

We also stand poised to play the role of a peace broker as Vietnam moves to mend fences with its former enemies. In fact, US government advisers believe Canberra could be at the very forefront in advising Washington on many aspects of strategic policy formulation and the normalisation of relations between the two countries.

But at this time, while the embargoes remain in place, Australia should be very careful to acknowledge the reasons behind the continuing enforcement of those sanctions by the United States. Like Australia, the United States is a signatory to many international treaties such as the Geneva accord and the Paris peace agreement, which advocate refraining from all acts of reprisal and discrimination against individuals and organisations and ensure their democratic liberties.

In conclusion, I would refer also to the alleged policy of normalisation, or doi moi, which has been seen somewhat as the perestroika of Vietnam—an analogy, of course, that does not go hand in hand with the other aspect of perestroika, glasnost, which was, in the case of the former Soviet Union, the movement towards some normalisation of political activity in line with the freeing up of its own domestic economy.

It is clear that we are seeing some freeing up of the Vietnamese economy and opportunities for trading with other nations and, in particular, our own opportunities for trading through our own companies. But it is important that we match this doi moi movement within Vietnam by insisting on the normalisation of human rights and the opportunity for the Vietnamese people to enjoy the same sorts of human rights that we enjoy in Australia. (Time expired)
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Truss)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion is seconded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grace Mr E.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak to the motion let me categorically state that I in no way support the abuse of human rights of any groups, religious or ethnic, in any country, and certainly not in Vietnam.

PARA.TAB: While we currently have the Prime Minister of Vietnam, Mr Vo, visiting our country, I believe we should take the opportunity to remind him of his country's obligations under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, to which it is a party. We not only have a duty to remind the honourable Prime Minister of that obligation but I believe we also have a right, a right borne of the closeness of our economic destinies.

While I am very proud to be associated today with the motion moved by my colleague the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing), I would disagree with a remark that he made in an otherwise excellent speech. He pointed out to the House that our Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is only bringing up human rights with the Prime Minister of Vietnam because of pressure from the Vietnamese community in Australia. As I understand it, that is not true, and I would like to put that on the record.

In many ways Australia has led the way in reintroducing Vietnam to the world community. That effort has not always been easy and it has drawn criticism from many who have long and not unwarranted bitter memories. Criticism has also come from those people for whom the ongoing abuse of human rights in Vietnam is an outrage.

Let me state here that I too feel outrage that the citizens of Vietnam do not enjoy the same freedoms that we enjoy and take for granted. We have the freedom to speak our minds, to express our thoughts, to practise our religions and to choose our government. We have the freedom to take an active part in a shared destiny.

However, in spite of the outrage that I feel, I believe a considered response to those problems is what the situation requires. By `considered' I mean that simple opposition to human rights abuse is not enough. More is needed to have a positive effect. And the realities in this situation are that there have been, and there continue to be, unacceptable abuses of basic human rights in Vietnam. I repeat: unacceptable basic human rights in Vietnam. The question is not whether the abuse of human rights is acceptable; quite simply it is not. The question must always be: what is the best course of action available to us that will bring about the change we desire? Our efforts should always be directed towards stopping these abuses and towards assisting the people of Vietnam to become more free.

As far as efforts in assisting the people of Vietnam to become more free, or at least assisting the people of Vietnam to be in a position to become more free, are concerned, I believe the Australian Government and the Australian business people have been playing a vital part. On Tuesday this week, there was an article in the Sydney Morning Herald which quoted Father Kevin Lee, from St Patrick's Cathedral in Parramatta. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Australia's expanding trade and aid links with Vietnam could serve to entrench the power of the Government and that human rights abuses would continue unless Western governments directly challenged the Vietnamese.

Please do not misunderstand me on this point; I fully support Father Lee's sentiments. However, I disagree with him on the best methods of gaining our desired result in Vietnam. I firmly believe that, rather than restricting us, our expanding trade links in Vietnam give us a greater right to challenge the Vietnamese government about its human rights record. We are doing that today, in debating this motion. The access that our diplomatic and trade ties allow us means that we can continually raise human rights in Vietnam.

PARA.TAB: Obviously, I am running out of time but I would like to reiterate the words of the mover of this motion in encouraging the Vietnamese government to free the people it has in captivity. We have already helped to release some people, including some very prominent Australian citizens. I refer to my friend Mr Ton, who was recently repatriated to Australia.

In conclusion, I reiterate my support for the motion and send a powerful signal to the Vietnamese government. The best signal we can send is that the world community would be delighted if the Vietnamese government released its political prisoners, including the Venerable Thich Huyen Quang. I commend the motion to the House. (Time expired).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Mr R.D.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this morning to speak on a very important motion that is close to the hearts of many new Vietnamese Australians. Australia has a long and important historical connection to Vietnam, with its foundations in defending the individual liberties of all people against the tyranny of an ideology that places the welfare of the state above that of the individual.

PARA.TAB: The continuing violation of human rights by the Hanoi administration should cast a dark shadow over the visit to Australia by the Prime Minister of Vietnam and prick the humanitarian consciousness of those dealing with him, for we find Vietnam's denial of basic human rights an affront to all humanity. Section 14c of the 1954 Geneva accord called upon all parties:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to refrain from all acts of reprisal and discrimination against individuals or organisations on account of their activities during the conflict, and undertakes to ensure their democratic liberties.

The Vietnamese government deliberately and consciously impedes the development of a community which respects and values the contribution of the individual and protects individuals from the excess of government control.

PARA.TAB: In impeding the development of a liberal democracy, it continues to contravene not only the 1954 Geneva convention but also the 1973 Paris peace agreement, specifically article 11 of the Paris agreement, which exists to ensure the democratic liberties of the people—personal freedom, freedom of speech, freedom of the press, free association and organisation—and numerous other personal, political and economic liberties. These have been denied to the mass of the Vietnamese community. The Vietnamese government had previously pledged its support to both of these documents and today actively works to imprison the people of Vietnam by not allowing them to practise these basic freedoms.

In Australia we continue to hear tales of the horror inflicted upon those detained in prisons and so-called re-education camps. In the wider community and especially in electorates where there is a high proportion of Vietnamese people, like my own electorate of Cowan, we are continually reminded of the ill-treatment, undernourishment and lack of medical treatment experienced by many political prisoners in Vietnam. Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to record in Hansard a list of political prisoners held by the Vietnamese government.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Truss)—Is leave granted? There being no objection, leave is granted, subject to the document being suitable for Hansard incorporation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. The detention of religious leaders by the Vietnamese administration is no myth and that administration's actions in detaining them should not be tolerated or sanctioned by a community—especially by a community such as Australia which holds the right of free speech and of political and religious tolerance at the base of its social and cultural heritage.

PARA.TAB: An authority born in resolution 297 of 1977, decreed by the Vietnamese Council of Ministers, was in the words of Amnesty International designed to bring religious and cultural activities under the control of the state and the Communist Party by means of a comprehensive set of rules which included restrictions on religious services, religious education and the holding of religious gatherings and retreats. The control over religious activity in Vietnam is so suffocating that one cannot practise openly as a religious priest or minister without first obtaining government approval—an attitude which would never be accepted in this country.

The human rights question represents the most difficult but most fundamentally important aspect of Australia's relationship with Vietnam. This is made more difficult by the fact that Vietnam's impressive economic growth rate makes it a trading haven for Australia's business interests; Australia has already become Vietnam's biggest foreign investor. The time has come for Australia to balance its economic interests against its pursuit of human rights claims against Vietnam.

As a community that has prided itself on its pursuit of human rights abuses around the world, we cannot now turn a blind eye because pure economic gain dictates such an approach. I would like to quote from Time magazine of 24 May 1993, and more particularly the comments of Thang Manh Nguyen, a former Vietnamese citizen:

SPEECH.PARA: The world needs to remember that Hanoi has repeatedly deceived the international community . . . in 1977 Hanoi began a campaign to persecute Vietnamese of Chinese origin and those previously associated with the South Vietnamese Government . . . the Vietnamese Government has committed some of the worst abuses of human rights, for which it has not yet been brought to account . . . it worries me that in Vietnam a person arrested does not have the right to independent legal representation.
I commend the motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before calling the next member, I inform the House that I have perused the information that the honourable member wishes to incorporate in Hansard and it is not really in a form that would normally be regarded as acceptable for Hansard. For incorporation you normally look to tables or charts or things of that nature. Could I suggest to the honourable member that he seek leave of the House to table the document as a way of putting it on the record.
—I take your advice, Mr Deputy Speaker, and seek leave to table the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Vietnam is a word. It is also a place; it is also a culture; it is also people. In all of those things it is very firmly embedded in the psyche of all Australians. There are those Australians who, often through no fault of theirs, found themselves engaged in that most vile of all human activities, war, and who today still suffer as a result of that experience in Vietnam. Those of us who were not involved in that type of vile activity but became part of what was known then as the peace movement have different reasons to remember Vietnam, very strong reasons to remember Vietnam; and those who put Australia into that conflict prolonged, in my view, the agony of Vietnam.

PARA.TAB: The agony which Vietnam has experienced has been not just in the conflict in which we were involved, but in events well before the Second World War when the French, among others, tried to impose their colonial will. At the end of the Second World War, the British rearmed Japanese prisoners of war and set those prisoners of war back against the Vietnamese people.

Other powers in the world which thought they could resolve the internal problems of Vietnam by war or conflict only prolonged the great pain that the Vietnamese have now suffered for a long time. The great tragedy of Vietnam today is that the agony continues. I believe there beats in the soul of all of humanity a great need and a great desire for very simple things—things that we in Australia take very much for granted.

These simple things are as follows: the right of free association; the right to belong to political parties; the right to elect representatives in a free and a democratic political system; the right to an independent judiciary; the right to be represented in a court of law, to be aware of the charges and to have the right of representation; the right of freedom of religion; the right of free travel, not just internationally but also domestically. Many of those are rights which the Vietnamese do not have.

Honourable members, I do not think there can be any dispute that the Australian Parliament supports, not just in Vietnam but around the world, the right of all people to have those very simple and very fundamental rights. It is appropriate when the Prime Minister of Vietnam is in Australia that we in this Parliament remind ourselves, as well as the Vietnamese Prime Minister, of the great difficulty which we had in getting those rights.

The history of the world and of the development of other countries shows that the rights which we enjoy here in Australia are not always easily obtained. Those rights are very often only obtainable when the economic conditions of a country enable the development of the educative processes which develop those rights. So in many ways the fact that Australia is now entering into economic relations with Vietnam is indicative of the fact that Vietnam is leaving its closed boundaries—just as the wall came down in Berlin—and entering the world of other nations, of other viewpoints, of other concerns.

It is my firm belief that through trade, and through the Vietnamese learning the systems that we have and the ease with which we cope with our freedoms, we will create a desire amongst the Vietnamese leaders to give their people the sorts of freedoms which we enjoy. So, whilst I condemn the total failure of the Vietnamese leaders to abide by the 1973 Paris peace accords, particularly chapter 2, and the fact that they have failed to comply with international obligations and agreements, I hope that through trade and with involvement in world affairs the Vietnamese people will have a much better and freer future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr E.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —On numerous occasions in Australia's recent history there have been some quite emotional debates on our immigration intake. I do not intend to enter that debate today, but the fact that we are forced to put limits on the numbers of migrants we accept shows how attractive Australia is to members of foreign countries.

PARA.TAB: I realise that a great number of migrants come from free and independent nations. We also accept a great number of migrants from nations which exercise human rights abuses and deprive their citizens of living in a free and democratic nation. In my maiden speech to the House I mentioned that my electorate had a very diverse ethnic mix, with many migrants coming, as I said, `to our great nation to escape homelands plagued by both religious and political persecution'.

The motion moved by the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) coincides with the visit of the Prime Minister of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, Mr Vo Van Kiet. It is important that we debate this motion during his visit, for the motion recognises and deplores the record of the Vietnamese Government on human rights.

It is imperative that Mr Vo be made aware that this Parliament disapproves of the way his government has treated the citizens of Vietnam over the last few decades. A new Vietnamese constitution, which was promulgated in 1992, was aimed at improving human rights. An amendment actually stated that `all human rights' are to be respected. However, it seems these changes were cosmetic and, in practice, human rights abuses have continued to occur in Vietnam.

I would like to comment on a report submitted to the United States Senate Committee on Foreign Relations and the US House of Representatives Committee on Foreign Relations. The report is entitled Country reports on human rights practices for 1992. It details some specific cases in Vietnam and shows clearly that human rights abuses still exist there. Reading the report, I was astounded at what actually went on—and obviously still does go on—and it certainly makes me feel proud to be an Australian. Speaking as we are here today and having the opportunity to speak on virtually anything we wish is something most Vietnamese would not be entitled to do, yet it is something that we here in Australia take for granted.
I would like to quote a number of sections from that report which detail human rights abuses which occurred last year. The abuses include:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . severe restrictions on freedom of speech, press, assembly, and association, on workers' rights, and on the right of citizens to change their government. The government crackdown on dissent begun in the spring of 1990 continued in 1992.
The report goes on to mention particular instances of abuses. On the issue of deaths of political prisoners, it states:

. . . according to credible reports, prisoners have in the past died of exhaustion, physical abuse, malnutrition, the lack of medical care, and other effects of conditions in prison and re-education camps.
On torture, and other cruel, inhumane or degrading treatment or punishment, the report claims that there continued to be credible and consistent reports of:
. . . police brutality during interrogation . . . (and severe) conditions for those confined in prisons.

While in Australia fair, open and public trials would be taken for granted, in Vietnam, even in spite of legislative changes aimed at improving them, secret trials are still reportedly being held for some political prisoners. The report also recognises a report by Amnesty International, which organisation has campaigned on behalf of political prisoners from countries such as Vietnam.

PARA.TAB: While I have detailed examples of human rights abuses, I would now like to talk briefly on the content of the motion moved by the honourable member for Moore. The motion calls on the Vietnamese Government to immediately and unconditionally release all political prisoners and prisoners of conscience. This is very straightforward, and I do not think anyone with any compassion would argue against this. It also urges basic rights to be introduced, including freedom of assembly, religious worship, speech and the press, and free and open elections. Such freedoms are ones which I am passionate about. While changes have recently been made in Vietnam, they have been artificial changes, and past practices have really continued.

I will conclude by saying that the motion of the honourable member for Moore is commonsense and straightforward and deserves absolute support. With the Prime Minister of Vietnam present in Australia today, we must demonstrate that Australia's parliamentarians are concerned at his government's appalling human rights abuses, and signal that we want change if Vietnam is to receive aid and if we are to trade freely with Vietnam to help improve the living standards of all the Vietnamese people. This motion is too important to be ignored, and I implore all members to provide their support for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to support all that has been said, but I do think that we ought to make it very clear as we welcome Mr Vo Kiet to Australia that we recognise the fact that here we are one culture talking to another culture. As we have found—as we try to reconcile our relationship with other countries in the Asia-Pacific region—it is extremely important that we recognise that here we are one culture with a not particularly good history in human rights, even going back a few decades, much less centuries, saying something which we mean sincerely to another culture. I support all those statements that have been made by the honourable members who have spoken before me, and I believe that we ought to be making those statements to the Government of Vietnam.

PARA.TAB: Just as our criticisms of other countries such as Indonesia and Malaysia have been made in this Parliament by honourable members on occasions, we need to continually remind ourselves that here we are one culture talking to people in another culture. It is not so many years ago that I was at school. To me, it does not seem so long ago, because I remember quite distinctly going to school in Mildura when Aboriginal children were not permitted to go to the local schools. That was as recently as the late 1940s and early 1950s—although I know that that is not so recent to some of the young members here.

I can recall when Aboriginal people were not allowed to go to one of the local movie theatres, or allowed to attend the other unless they went into the first six rows. One only had to visit some of the `camps' in areas such as Mildura, Robinvale and some of the areas along the Murray to realise that people were treated very harshly in those times. They had had their whole culture taken from them. Of course, even today we have people who are denied access to services when they should receive services.

When one looks at the ancient cultures of China and Vietnam, one can see the religions that the people have had in those countries. The religion of Buddhism and the variants of Buddhism have contributed greatly to the cultures of those countries. Even when they have been taken over by secular governments, many of the great traditions have been preserved and are being held. In fact, there are people here in the Buddhist communities who suffered under some of the changes that came with those secular governments.

Nevertheless, the philosophy that those people in other countries have developed can actually contribute something to us. So we say to them, `We welcome you, Prime Minister. We welcome you to Australia. We draw your attention to incidents which we believe are infringements of human rights, but we also recognise that we ourselves speak to you as people from another culture which itself has had failings. So welcome, and we hope that you will listen to us'.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Truss)—Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)notes the increasing vulnerability of Australian clothing manufacturers to counterfeiting and the negative effect that this is having on investment, employment and future prospects of this part of the textiles, clothing and footwear sector;
(2)notes the amendments to the Trade Marks Act 1955 made last year providing for increased penalties for counterfeiters; and

(3)calls upon the Government, Australian Federal Police and State police forces to consider suitable methods to reduce the damage to the clothing industry's intellectual property that counterfeiting is causing.

This motion will be ably seconded by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) and supported by the honourable member for Indi (Mr Lieberman), both of whom have a good understanding of this issue. I also look forward to supportive remarks, I hope, from the honourable member for Corio (Mr O'Connor) on this matter, because it also affects his electorate, which is adjacent to mine.

PARA.TAB: Counterfeiting of clothing is a theft of Australian jobs. Australia is attempting to reach world-class best practice in many areas and a large number of clothing companies have achieved this, but the counterfeiters debase the manufacturers' hard efforts over many years.

At the weekend a friend of mine went to a Sunday market in Belmont in my electorate and she noticed that a stallholder had Hot Tuna and Quiksilver brand T-shirts and polo fleeced T-shirts that were on sale for $25 and $35. My friend said to the stallholder that these garments were fakes. The clothing stayed on display. No doubt many people walking past thought, `What a great price', for what they thought were quality garments. It would have been a different story after a few washes when these counterfeit garments would have fallen apart.

John Ramsden of the Anti-counterfeiting Action Group represents 18 of Australia's leading clothing manufacturers: names such as Country Road and Palmer Corporation, or Jag as it is better known as, as well as surfwear manufacturers in Torquay—Rip Curl and Quiksilver. Mr Ramsden says that the Australian clothing industry is losing an estimated $300 million a year through counterfeiting.

Weekend markets act as a convenient vehicle to dispose of thousands of such garments. Mr Ramsden believes that, unless there is action to reduce counterfeiting, Australia will be less of that `clever country' because quality in clothing will be penalised by these fake garments.

Clive Fitts, of Quiksilver in Torquay, says that retailers, such as former Geelong footballer Billy Goggin's sports store in the seat of Corio, are often across the street from such markets. Consumers come into the store and wonder why the T-shirt that they bought at the market across the street for $10 costs $35 or $45 in the sports store. The consumers do not understand the $20 million that it has cost Quiksilver to develop its designs and image in the marketplace over the years.

These reputable manufacturers have to emphasise quality. They are in a fashion conscious industry; they have to market internationally. Their products are accepted in Europe, in the UK, in California and around the Pacific.

Mark Wiesmayr of Rip Curl says counterfeiting of clothing cheapens Rip Curl's brands. The surfboards, the wetsuits and the beach gear of these Torquay companies have won a worldwide reputation and recognition. Shop retailers become angry because the market stallholders who sell the counterfeit goods have such low overheads. Consumers are not aware that Rip Curl's T-shirts are designed eight months before the summer season and have been extensively tested to see whether the design will give Rip Curl's customers what they want in wear, style, overall quality and performance.

This whole argument must focus on the importance of Australia's growing reputation as a nation with design skills. We are increasingly seen as manufacturers of quality clothing products that are winning acceptance in domestic and export markets. This clothing commands a premium price, whether it is fashion or business clothing or surf wear. The garments, designed by professionals over many months and years, are made from high quality yarns and fabrics.

Threats to the viability of clothing manufacturers from counterfeiters have to be taken very seriously. These typically backyard operators seek a free ride on the backs of companies such as Quiksilver and Rip Curl in Torquay, which in 20 years have built their businesses from nothing to enterprises employing 100 to 300 staff. The counterfeiters seek to misrepresent their clothing as being as good as that produced by the holder of the trademarks, but the copies have inferior fabrication and printing, and an overall totally inferior quality rating. The reputable manufacturers, who are the victims, have not sought to hide behind a tariff wall. They are out there in the international and local markets trying to sell quality clothing.

Counterfeiters typically sell these garments through 300 Australia-wide weekend markets. When clothing purchased at the weekend market falls apart later, the reputable manufacturer gets the blame. How is the customer to know that the proper, `original' garments are never sold through market stallholders but only through retail shops and, in a few cases, factory outlets run by the manufacturer?

I have little argument with the existence of weekend markets. They provide important community benefits through lower prices to consumers for some goods. However, I object most strenuously to the misrepresentation of these counterfeit garments as the genuine article.

This seemingly small problem of a few T-shirts being copied and sold cheaply has now blossomed into a problem that costs Australian clothing manufacturers anything up to the figure given by John Ramsden of $300 million a year. Australian companies, in many cases, are now receiving royalties and licence fees from the internationally accepted clothing that has been designed here. If Australia does not regard intellectual capital as one of its most precious commodities, I fail to see how we can really expect other nations to take seriously our efforts to increase our exports.

Last year the Parliament finally considered a report into this whole matter. As a result, amendments to the Trade Marks Act 1955 were passed. The penalties for selling a counterfeit garment are now up to $500 for a single offence, with a fine of up to $50,000, or two years imprisonment, for an infringement of a trademark. Will the counterfeiters really be deterred by this level of penalty or should we again look at increasing penalties?

The Australian Federal Police have been cooperative in prosecuting. Together with various State police forces, which have jurisdiction over the markets, they have launched some 95 prosecutions. The highest penalty imposed in the courts was in New South Wales earlier this year—a $4,000 fine and a two-year good behaviour bond. However, Australia needs to do more.

In March this year John Ramsden, Norm Innis, managing director of Quiksilver, and Mark Wiesmayr from Rip Curl came to see me. They explained how counterfeiting was a major headache and how it took many hours of management time to even partially stem the flood of copied garments into the markets. I then sent a letter to the Australian Federal Police and I am pleased to say that a group, the anticounterfeiting action group, has met with the Australian Federal Police since then. The Australian Federal Police are considering establishing a task force to initiate a greater scrutiny of the counterfeiters.

The anticounterfeiting action group was set up in November 1990 with 10 members, and the number has now grown to 18. These companies, including their retail operations, directly employ 8,000 staff. Many members are leading the thrust of the clothing industry to have Australia recognised as a quality supplier and retailer of clothing on the world scene.

The Australian Federal Police may find the best results will come if their resources are concentrated on efforts to reduce the number of manufacturers of counterfeit clothing. I do not just advocate this because of the Australian Federal Police's jurisdictional limits. I believe it would be more effective to concentrate on the manufacturers. Unlike clothing retailers at the markets whose only expense is a small stallholders fee, manufacturers face start-up costs. These backyard operators usually purchase a four-carousel printer for $1,000. A pizza oven, heater and a gas bottle could come to $3,000 or $4,000, and silk screens cost up to $30 each. For a cost of under $7,000 their returns can be phenomenal. Typical incomes for clothing counterfeiters run from $50,000 to $300,000 a year.

I know of one case where it was alleged that an individual had a yearly cash income of $110,000 but a declared income of only $5,000. The collection by the Government of payroll tax, company tax, income tax and sales tax then drops. Employment in the clothing sector has already declined from 98,000 in 1971 to 64,000 in 1991. Many clothing companies can cope with predictable changes such as the removal of quotas and reductions in tariffs, but it is much harder for them to cope with the activities of counterfeiters. The latter problem is within our power as a community to solve if we set our minds to it.

We have to get the message through to our judiciary that we will not tolerate the loss of jobs and investment that result from widespread counterfeiting of clothing. A prerequisite is publicity, together with enforcement by the law. Media publicity or other parliamentary awareness of counterfeiting will result in a change in community attitudes. Consumers will be less likely to go to a weekend market believing that they are really buying a Jag or Country Road or Rip Curl garment if they know that the real manufacturer never sells through markets, only through shops and, in very few places, factory outlets.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Truss)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—I welcome the comments that have been made on this issue by the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur). In the city of Geelong and in the Geelong region we share the representation of many textile, clothing and footwear firms that are suffering because of the practice of counterfeiting clothing. But I must say to the honourable member for Corangamite that he does stretch his credibility by coming into this place talking about these issues, because the people of Geelong and the Geelong region know full well that in the lead-up to the last federal election the honourable member walked and drove the length and breadth of the Corangamite electorate preaching a very dry economic rationalist line. Of course—
—Supported by the Government.

—The honourable member may interject but the simple reality is that he proposed to those manufacturers, the textile and clothing manufacturers in the Geelong region, that a zero to five per cent tariff was going to be a mechanism that would enhance the interests of this industry and employment in this industry in the region. I welcome his interest in this particular regional industry but I put it to him that, if he had come into this place on this side of the Parliament as a member of a government with a zero tariff policy, then the people who have come to him over the issue of labelling and country of origin counterfeiting would not have been coming to him over that particular issue; they would be coming to me, and to him, fighting for their very survival under a zero to five per cent tariff regime.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Corangamite has pursued this dry economic line for many years in this particular region. We had many political battles in the early 1980s and the mid-1980s. He might recall the battle that we had over the Colac pool when the city of Colac sought $100,000 from the Federal Government to construct a community facility. All we wanted from the honourable member for Corangamite was a letter of support. It was not forthcoming but the visionaries in that particular area pressed ahead. We built the facility. It is a good example of public enterprise that has gone well. It is now running at a profit and it is servicing the needs of the Colac community.

I did hear a rumour the other day that the honourable member for Corangamite was actually trying to claim some credit for that facility. Recently, the honourable member opposed any federal government assistance going to BWK to locate in the region. So I welcome this interest that he is currently showing. I am sure that it is genuine—I have no doubt of that—but I think I should point out to the House the honourable member's record in this.

I turn to current government programs and I refer to the local government capital works program. There is an interesting program in the honourable member's electorate to build a surf museum that will complement Quicksilver and Rip Curl. I am not sure whether the honourable member supported that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did support that.

—He did support that, and that is welcome support for that particular project. I do believe at some stage he did say that it was a pretty short-term employment creation project with no long-term enduring benefit.

PARA.TAB: But the honourable member has come into the House and he knows the respect that I have for him. He has raised an issue that is of concern not only to textiles, clothing and footwear manufactures in Geelong but also to other industries throughout Australia. This counterfeiting problem has its genesis in two particular areas: the counterfeiting of labels and brand names and the counterfeiting of the country of origin labels that are put on products.

I agree that counterfeiting is causing extensive damage to the clothing industry's intellectual property. The Geelong region has firms, as the honourable member for Corangamite has indicated, which have significant investment in intellectual property. It is that intellectual property that is being pirated and damaged by the activities that the honourable member for Corangamite has so eloquently put to the House.

The Geelong clothing industry, generally, has directed its activities in recent times to capturing niche markets, to producing high quality garments and high value added materials that have a high retail price. In this environment, they are really sitting ducks for the activities of the counterfeiters and the pirates that are attempting to come in on the back of the good name that these products have in the Australian marketplace.

The marking for country of origin on imported goods is enforced by the Australian Customs Service. It recently, as the honourable member said, set up a series of task forces in each State to really home in on those who are pirating. It was code named Operation Cipher. While many of the activities uncovered were of a minor nature, the task forces have found that there are significant deceptive practices being instituted by people overseas and these practices are damaging the Australian producers.

The Australian Customs Service has made strong efforts to bring this particular issue to the forefront of importers' minds. There was a story recently on the ABC's program The Investigators, followed by an appearance by the then Minister on the Ray Martin Midday Show, which excited a lot of consumer interest. But, whilst the ACS has significantly lifted the level of compliance in the last nine months, especially in the apparels and accessories area, there is still widespread abuse of this particular practice.

The Government has shown its commitment to correct country of origin labelling of goods with the establishment of two working parties, set up to study the means available to make country of origin labelling more comprehensive, accurate and informative. A draft report on the working parties' deliberations has been prepared. I would like to cite to the House some of the recommendations that came out of that. I commend the Minister for publishing this particular report and I commend it to honourable members and other interested parties.

The working group considered basically four options. Option 1 was to maintain the status quo with additional resources for enforcement, that is, that there would be no real changes to the legislative arrangements but the enforcement angle would be stiffened up by the adding of considerable resources. In option 2 the working party canvassed the repeal of all statutory requirements to label with country of origin and to let the existing false misleading provisions under Commonwealth, State and Territory legislation prevail. Option 2 called for a repeal of all statutory requirements to label with country of origin and for the introduction of consumer product information standards under the Trade Practices Act, which defines acceptable descriptors and stipulates the specific classes of goods that must be labelled. Option 4 referred to the repeal of all statutory requirements to label with country of origin and the introduction of a new division into the TPA which defines acceptable descriptors to be used if any claim of country of origin is made voluntary or, when stipulated, requires that the goods must be labelled with country of origin information.

If I may refer to the clothing industry generally—and it relates to the firms that are now operating in the Geelong area—the Australian Government's policy assistance to the industry has been directed to encouraging market rather than production orientated activities. The Government has sought to encourage producers that have close relationships with retailers. It has encouraged the development of branded quality merchandise and it has encouraged those manufacturers that engage in quick response manufacturing techniques. We have those, of course, in the electorates that the honourable member for Corangamite and I represent. The success of the Government's policy lies in the fact that value adding in the clothing industry generally in Australia is about $2.2 billion and I believe that since 1986-87 exports from this particular industry have increased to about $418 million. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have pleasure in seconding the motion of the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur). It has particular relevance to my own electorate. It was interesting to hear the honourable member for Corio (Mr O'Connor) attacking the honourable member for Corangamite on the issue of tariffs. I understand that in a previous incarnation the honourable member for Corio worked for then Senator Button in his role as Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and, as we know, Senator Button reduced tariffs and removed quotas at a greater rate than any other politician in Australia, with the possible exception of Gough Whitlam. So I am going to report the honourable member for Corio to his former master and make sure that he is rapped across the knuckles for his untoward remarks in this House.

PARA.TAB: The other point in relation to his remarks, many of which were devoted to imports and the labelling of imports, is a problem we have at the moment that was raised by my honourable friend and is one that is very domestic. These are things that are being made here, labelled here and counterfeited here that are ruining local businesses. So it is the local thing that we are really raising in this debate and, whilst we are very pleased that all these other things are going on, as mentioned by the honourable member for Corio, I want to concentrate on the particular concerns of local manufacturers.

I can illustrate this best, I think, by quoting directly from a letter from one of my constituents, Mr Terry Fitzgerald of Hot Buttered Pty Ltd. I will read the letter because it illustrates the problem in a very direct way:

SPEECH.PARA: As you are aware, the northern beaches—
this is in Sydney—

are the home of Australia's surfing industry. The area has produced more World Champions, leading surf board designers and manufacturers, magazines and films/video than another 20 km of coastline in the world.

That has been challenged by the honourable member for Corio, and I also notice that the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) is likely to challenge it, but we are very proud of our industry in my electorate.
The area is the home to not only my company since 1971,—
this is Mr Fitzgerald's company—

but also, Peak Wetsuits of Newport, O'Neill Wetsuits at Warriewood, Insight Surfboards, Energy Surfboards and at least twenty surf retailers. Offices are maintained on the Peninsula by Victorian companies Rip Curl Wetsuits and Quiksilver Garments and Wetsuits, as well as Queensland's Billabong.
Various Agents represent companies such as Mambo, Oakley, Reef of Brazil, Freestyle, and a plethora of other surfing labels.
The point is, your electorate—
that is, mine—
is essentially the hub of Australia's surfing industry with its subsequent effects on surfing's multi-million dollar export. My company alone exports to eleven countries. . . .
The gist of the problem is this:
.Surf Industry labels are being blatantly ripped-off on a continuing basis.
.My label has been found in a number of markets including Parklea, Menangle, Cowes, Geelong, and Tamworth.
.This unauthorised use has multiple effects on our label:
*Retailers cutting back because of t-shirts being sold at three for $10.00 at markets, as against our retail of $35.00 for instance.
*Cheap Chinese t-shirts with bad printing reflect on our brand and quality.

.Over last summer, I had a private investigator continually policing markets and serving `Cease and Desist' letters at great expense. Needless to say, some results were obtained, but, effectively illegal stock just moved sideways.
