.All major players in the industry spent tens of thousands of dollars on what is a rapidly growing anti-counterfeiting industry combating the counterfeiting industry. And with little or no effect.
.I know of only one prosecution taking place against illegal TM usage. By Victorian Police at Collingwood.—
although, I understand, there have been some more—
So where do we go from here to protect our domestic marketplaces?
How do we convince the Federal Police to act under the Trade Marks Act and take advantage of stiffer penalties to be imposed?
Can we get some action against this blatant abuse of labels that have been built over decades, and represent Australia and your electorate in virtually every major export market in the world?
Mr Fitzgerald goes on:
Mr Carlton, you cannot believe how frustrating it is to write cheques for private—
detectives—actually, he says `private dicks', but I thought that would be unparliamentary!—
to try and stem abuse of hard earned product integrity. Particularly when there seems to be very little interest whatsoever in pursuing the counterfeiters by the authorities.

Now I am pleased to hear that the Federal Police are stepping up its campaign here, assisted by the State Police, and I am very happy indeed to support this being raised in the Parliament by my colleague. On a personal interest matter, my daughter works for Country Road: I should declare that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I applaud the motion put before this House by the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) and endorse the comments that have been made, particularly by my colleague the honourable member for Corio (Mr O'Connor). The issue obviously relates to the domestic scene, as the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) has just indicated, but it is also of course not only an international problem, but an international problem with respect to counterfeiting across a whole range of industries, and we are going to hear a lot more about this issue in this place in the foreseeable future.

PARA.TAB: It is an issue that relates to both country of origin labelling and brand labelling. What I would like to do, as the basis for supporting this motion, is to refer briefly to the more general picture in the clothing industry. I believe that it is important that we in this place should be supporting our domestic clothing industry. There is a view in many areas in this country, particularly in high places in the bureaucracy, that this country has a very limited future with the manufacture of clothing, but it is certainly not a view that I endorse. It is important that we make every effort, particularly in legitimate areas such as protecting local manufacturers from aspects like counterfeiting, to ensure that our manufacturers are able to compete genuinely in an environment which assists them to both sell and market their products here and overseas.

I have a very substantial presence of the clothing manufacturing industry in my electorate, in areas such as Brunswick, Richmond and Collingwood. It is true that there are aspects of this industry that do essentially produce relatively cheap and relatively poor quality products. That has certainly been the predominant image that the Australian clothing manufacturing industry has laboured under for some time. In reality, it is a misconceived image and, certainly, considerable change has been occurring in the industry in recent years. There are areas where there are very poor working conditions for workers, antiquated technology and inward-looking attitudes on the part of management but, in my view, the proportion of the industry where these characteristics can be said to be the case is decreasing fairly rapidly.

There are clothing manufacturers in my electorate who accept that the tariff wall and the structures that have been in place for some time in this country to protect the industry do need to be wound back. Their view essentially is that the pace of change is the key issue, not so much whether the change is necessary. I have spoken to these people and they accept the need for the reduction in tariffs and the inevitability of that occurring. Their major objection, which I sympathise with, is that the speed at which change is occurring is placing them and their ability to innovate and employ new staff under too much pressure too quickly.

There is new technology investment occurring; there is an upskilling in staff occurring in many areas. We should be ensuring that this type of change can occur productively in the manufacturing sector while we are gradually—and I emphasise the word `gradually'—winding back the tariff protection.

The key problem that we face, particularly in my electorate—and one that will increasingly occupy the attention of the Government—is that we now have a middle-aged work force very heavily dominated by migrant women, who have been losing jobs in this sector and related sectors and for whom the opportunities for re-employment elsewhere are extremely limited. We will need a great deal of collective will, and a willingness to think laterally and to intervene in the marketplace, in order to be able to provide future employment opportunities for these people. A very substantial number of them have been assisted by the Government through labour market programs and the like, but equally there are many who have slipped through the net and who have not taken up the opportunities offered under some of the very innovative labour market programs of the Government. Equally, there are others who have been in a position where they have been unable to avail themselves of these opportunities. If society is saying to people, `Sorry, you have to lose your job because of restructuring in order to benefit our society at large', then it is society's responsibility to ensure that those people do not suffer unduly.

I commend the motion as a very worthwhile effort to ensure that the local clothing industry is assisted in one of a variety of ways that this House and this Government need to undertake in order to protect the existing industry from underhand, illicit activities that can undermine its genuine efforts for innovation and change.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me much pleasure to speak in support of the very worthwhile motion of my colleague and friend the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur), whose interest in whether a swimming pool should be built in the Corio area was mainly based on whether the community had enough knowledge of what the cost would be and the outcomes. His homework there probably helped the project to get off the ground and be more viable.

PARA.TAB: My interest in this area was heightened somewhat by a visit I made to Asia some years ago when I proudly purchased a Sheaffer pen. I thought that I had got a real bargain, but I found that it melted in the hot sun about a day later. I was very angry about that, so I sympathise with the manufacturers and people of skill and talent when they actually see their ideas being stolen. We have many of them in Australia and we should be encouraging them as much as we can, particularly in the value added industry area. What this motion deals with is the burgeoning industry of stealing the intellectual knowledge of Australian manufacturers and innovators who are prepared to work hard and to risk their capital to develop ideas and products so that we can create permanent jobs for Australians.

There is an increasing tendency in Australia for people to go to markets. They are good fun; I go to them in my electorate in Wangaratta, Wodonga and Mount Beauty, and sometimes I go to the famous Melbourne markets and the Essendon market—I enjoy them and so does my family. But the consumers going to markets in increasing numbers—hundreds of thousands every year—are being duped, not by all stall operators but by many of them, because the products being sold are blatantly being marketed as belonging to particular brands when in fact they are fakes. I guess the Australian culture tends to let things drift on, so that if nothing more stringent is done about this we will find a breaking down of standards. It will be seen to be okay that these markets allow this sort of thing to happen.

As well as helping the Australian Federal Police in its difficult job of enforcing the trademark laws, I believe we should be developing and concentrating on the education area. We should also seek, in consultation with local government and with the people who manage the markets, some self-discipline and some peer review amongst stallholders. That would complement the existing trade laws.

For example, I would like the operators of markets, who are the people who allocate space to the stallholders, to be involved in discussions and dialogue with honourable members such as the honourable member for Corangamite, who has taken the initiative to draw our attention to this issue, to see whether they would be willing to introduce guidelines into the markets; that is, whether they would not allocate space for people to operate from the markets unless there were some guidelines and some discipline in relation to how the goods were displayed.

There ought to be truth of origin. Before the law on country of origin is brought in and improved, as undoubtedly it will be, there ought to be a simple statement from the operator to the stallholder. The operators should be able to say that if the stallholders are going to put clothing on display, they are required to put a board up that says that they are satisfied, as much as possible, that the products they are offering were in fact manufactured in such and such a country.

There is nothing wrong with asking people to do that. We should involve them in that way. We should tell them that what they are doing is helping us build a nation in which commercial investment, skills and talent are being fostered and encouraged for everybody's benefit. We should say that we can tackle the problems much better as a team.

I would go one step further and ask the operators of the markets not to allow people to set up their wares and operate in the community markets unless they have made reasonable inquiries from the stallholders about the truth of the labels that are on the particular products they are marketing. If we added that sort of dimension to the debate, as well as the dimension of enforcing the law and the penalties, we might start to make a lot more progress than we have. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) for raising this very important issue in the House today. I think all honourable members would agree with the sentiments that he has put forward because, if nothing else, we are all Australians who have the interests of the Australian community and economy at heart, no matter how we choose to demonstrate it.

PARA.TAB: What is very clear to anyone who goes shopping or who talks to people in the community is that Australians want to buy Australian goods. They are quite prepared to put a price premium on that. In some areas of merchandising it is estimated that a price premium of between 10 and 15 per cent is acceptable to Australian consumers if they know that what they are buying is Australian. Australian's recognise the obvious benefit of that. They want to help their fellow workers to keep their jobs. They want to increase our standard of living.

That implies a degree of responsibility in many people. Certainly, the Government has a responsibility to provide a legislative regime that will ensure that people are getting good, clear and accurate information. It requires that the merchandiser, the retailer, the importer or the manufacturer in Australia is honest and right to the point about the labelling requirements.

Unfortunately, while we do have quite strong labelling laws in terms of their presentation, there are ways in which people get around them. Some try to get around them, not so much in an underhand way but by being very legalistic about their approach to labelling; whereas others, particularly with counterfeiting, are—
