TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, I have wanted to make this speech for six years. When I first entered the Parliament I was on the Parliamentary AIDS Liaison Committee. One of the first things I asked about was the threat of HIV to Aboriginal populations. I was told that plenty was being done, and that we had to be sensitive about it because, if we were not, it would give people an opportunity to reinforce existing prejudices. I accepted that.

PARA.TAB: When I became shadow Minister for Aboriginal affairs in 1990, I raised the same issues privately. I was told the issue was being adequately addressed. In three years as shadow Minister and spending a lot of that time travelling around Australia visiting Aboriginal communities and on one occasion actually working as a doctor in one of those communities, I have got to say that this issue is not being addressed; and it is a culpable negligence for which this country may pay for many generations.

In the First World, the HIV epidemic has been predominantly confined to the homosexual and IV-drug using communities. The expected third wave under the heterosexual community has happened at a much slower rate than was then predicted.

This is not the case in Third World countries. In eastern Africa, HIV has been a heterosexual epidemic from the very beginning. There is no evidence that it has ever been associated with homosexual or IV-drug using communities. Similarly in the Second World, such as South-East Asia, the explosion in HIV exposure is occurring through heterosexual contact.

Most recent data out of Zimbabwe suggests that the virus is so widespread in some parts of that country that 42 per cent of young women presenting for their first medical visit during pregnancy screen positive to the HIV virus. Well over half of these will be dead within ten years. Of these, well over half will die of AIDS or AIDS related illnesses, the majority within five years. Thirty per cent of the infants will be born with HIV.

There is virtually no person working in the field in Australia who denies the possibility that, once the HIV virus becomes established in the Aboriginal population, its pattern will be that of the Third World rather than that of the First World. Of all the risk factors existing to have caused the epidemic in Africa, the same risk factors exist in Australia's Aboriginal population.

HIV has the potential to cause a holocaust in Aboriginal society. The late Fred Hollows estimated that we face the prospect of having 40,000 Aborigines die of AIDS in the next decade. To put this in context, this is 50 per cent greater than the number of Australians killed in World War II.

There is no hard evidence that HIV has extensively entered the Aboriginal community so far. The Northern Territory appears virtually free, the only cluster of cases existing in Queensland around Palm Island and Townsville. The late entry of HIV into Aboriginal society is not easily explained, but the following seems a reasonable hypothesis: contact between Aboriginal and European society is mainly heterosexual. While homosexual activity is well documented in traditional society, there seems to be little traffic between big cities and remote communities. There has not been a heterosexual HIV epidemic in Australia to date. And the majority of drug use in Aboriginal communities is alcohol; needle use is rare.

It is clear that, once HIV enters Aboriginal communities, it will spread quickly and extensively. The epidemic will follow the African model, which expects predominantly heterosexual transmission with high rates of transmission between mother and child. The effects upon the Aboriginal community are frightening to contemplate.

As this will predominantly affect traditional society, the epidemic has the possibility of wiping out a good part of traditional Australia. This could be the event that results in the death of Aboriginal culture as we know it today. There will be a very substantial orphan population, as the highest death rate will be expected in people between 20 and 40 years of age. It can be expected to lead to a reduction in population in parts of remote Australia and a likely further breakdown of what society is left in those places.

Efforts to prevent this epidemic have been largely unsuccessful in Africa and South-East Asia. However, if any country in the world should be able to successfully prevent HIV transmission, it should be Australia. We have a highly educated medical and paramedical work force, a well developed health system and a great deal of expertise in the area. We only have one chance to control the HIV epidemic in Aboriginal Australia and that is before the disease has entered the community. Given the horrendous costs of treating people with AIDS, any prevention is likely to be cost effective.

We need to address some specific difficulties with a comprehensive national HIV program. There is a lack of data about the prevalence and distribution of sexually transmitted diseases in the Aboriginal population and there is a very large reservoir of untreated sexually transmitted disease in Aboriginal communities, which leads to a very high re-infection rate. These figures are kept secret but in some urban communities in Australia we have rates of sexually transmitted diseases higher than in the slums of Atlanta or New York. The resurgence in ceremonies associated with men's business across the whole of central and northern Australia has real risks.

On a management level, there is simply no group in Australia looking strategically at this issue. There is no security of funding arrangements. These tend to be for one year at a time and there are numerous examples of a good strategy starting up, having been negotiated and agreed upon, but there being no funding to carry it through. The extreme secrecy of men's ceremonies makes it a very hard area in which to undertake adequate education. The present system of AIDS funding through NACAIDS has served Aboriginal people particularly poorly. There is no coordinated approach, funding is not secure and generally is of 12 months duration. Aboriginal people believe they have been largely forgotten by existing funding sources, even though on a relative risk basis the greatest current risk is unquestionably in the Aboriginal community.

On a clinical level, the following problems exist. There is still considerable uncertainty as to the most efficacious of different treatment regimes, and research is clearly needed in areas specific to Australia. In some parts of Australia over 10 per cent of the population carry dono virus. We do not know how best to treat that and the answer is not going to be found overseas; it is going to be found in research here in Australia.

But there are some positive aspects. We are not starting from scratch and a significant body of opinion amongst Aboriginal medical services and in Aboriginal society generally recognises that the problem is growing.

To have a nationally coordinated approach I believe there are 10 things that could be done much better than are being done now. For a start, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) and the Minister for Health, Senator Richardson, need an independent advisory committee. Given the abysmal role of the department in this, the committee has to report directly to the Minister and not through the department. There is enormous scope to have additional trainees working as Aboriginal health workers and to run additional seminars for people from communities. There is still in communities a lack of AIDS and STD videos in Aboriginal languages; clinical services in parts of Australia are exceedingly poor; there is no stand alone walk-in STD clinic in the whole of the Northern Territory and upgrading of local facilities needs to occur. We need to have clinical STD research; we need to have a screening program—a voluntary program—with a pilot program first to work out the most efficient method to get it going and then a main program that works very hard. There needs to be a men's program. It is easy to do and it would not take a long time. We need a significant increase in the number of Aboriginal HIV workers. In the end, a program like this over five years needs to be reviewed to see whether we are making any difference. It is easy to do: we have got markers and we have got very objective ways to work out whether we are making a difference or not.

A program like this cannot simply be given over to ATSIC, to the Department of Health, to the Aboriginal health services or to State or Territory governments—it has got to be given to everyone collectively. Health is a very political issue in Aboriginal society, and this should not be an issue of politics between Aboriginal controlled organisations and State and Territory organisations; it should be the issue that has these organisations starting to work together. My criticisms today are not particularly a failure of NACAIDS, of AMCA, of the Federal Government or State or Territory governments—it is a failure of everybody. It is a failure of leadership because this country has seen no leadership on this issue at all. As I said at the beginning, I have waited six years to make this speech and I do it very seriously. Had I been the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs after the last election, I would be seeking to implement this program now.

I make this speech and put it on the public record because I have got a horrible feeling that in 100 years time my descendants will look back at me and say, `You were in a position to do something and you did not. Why not?'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recently had occasion to view on the ABC, under the program title True Stories, a documentary entitled `Admission Impossible'. As an ardent supporter of the ABC and one who applauds its important role in our society, I find it a matter of deep concern when the ABC puts to air a documentary that consists of old Cinesound news clips which—like most of the news films made at that time—when dealing with Aboriginal or immigration issues, were heavily laden with racially stereotyped comments and presentation.

PARA.TAB: In dealing with Australia's postwar immigration program, this ABC program chose to give a selective and misleading version of our immigration history and the role of the Hon. Arthur Calwell, who is acknowledged as the founder of Australia's immigration program. The True Stories program would have led any uninformed citizen to conclude that Arthur Calwell, as a forthright supporter of the White Australia Policy, allowed that policy to dictate all aspects of immigration policy. It repeated as evidence the standard `Two Wongs don't make a White' allegation. It suggested that an extension of this led to a clearly anti-Semitic aspect of the program that improperly discriminated against Jewish immigration.

The White Australia Policy was the plank of all major political parties in the 1950s. The change that has taken place in all political parties was a generational change that commenced in the late 1950s and continued through the 1960s. As a policy, it was based on a community of fear of cheap Asian labour, upon our geographic isolation and upon our Anglo-Celtic origins. It is a gross distortion of our history to suggest, as was implied in this television program, that adherence to the concept of white Australia by our political leaders—and, I might add, by all political parties—in the 1940s, 1950s and 1960s was the product of individual racist attitudes on the part of those leaders.

Arthur Calwell, like other leaders of that period, was a supporter of the White Australia Policy, but he was not a racist. On the question of Jewish immigration, Calwell allowed the Jewish community to process applications to expedite immigration of survivors of the Holocaust and the camps of Europe when they were excluded from immigrating to Britain and the United States. When they had nowhere else in the world to go, Calwell allowed them to come here. The community also arranged for Jewish immigration from Shanghai, and the Javanese Prince arrived on 31 March 1946. From November 1945 to November 1946, landing permits were issued to 7,829 Jews out of 14,545 applicants and, from 1945 to December 1949, 21,584 permits were issued to the Jewish community out of a total of 71,679 applicants.

Calwell was the subject of ostracism and anti-Semitic cartoons because of these decisions. As was pointed out recently by the distinguished historian, Professor Bill Rubenstein, author of The Jews in Australia, the `Are you Jewish?' clause, which featured heavily in this film, was the policy used to identify Jews and speed up their arrival. It was not used to discriminate against them.

The affection with which Arthur Calwell is still regarded by survivors of the Holocaust in my electorate is testimony enough. I certainly support Professor Rubenstein's view that that segment of the True Stories program dealing with Jewish immigration to Australia is nonsense from start to finish.

The `Two Wongs don't make a White' statement has been not only widely and grievously used in this program but almost continuously used in textbooks to suggest racist attitudes on the part of Arthur Calwell. The Hansard of 2 December 1947 indicates that a question was asked concerning deportation generally and, in particular, deportation of a Chinaman who had been in the country for many years. That gentleman's name was Wong. It is clear that the department had issued an order for deportation on the wrong person. Calwell was explaining this. During his reply he was subjected to persistent interjections by the honourable member for Balaclava, who was then a Mr White. In concluding his remarks, Mr Calwell said, and I quote from the Hansard:

SPEECH.PARA: There are many Wongs in the Chinese community, but I have to say—and I am sure that the honourable member for Balaclava will not mind me doing so—
he was responding to the kind of interjection that we are pretty familiar with in this House—
that `two Wongs do not make a White'.

It was a specific reference at that time to the then honourable member for Balaclava, Mr White. What then occurred was that the newspapers in Australia which were strongly anti-Calwell, excluded the capital `W'. That statement then became `two Wongs do not make a white' a continual repetition which made it a segment of both the attitude of Arthur Calwell and a gross assertion purporting to be the base for our immigration policy. I am pleased to have had this opportunity to correct that piece of Australian history.

PARA.TAB: The change in the capital `W' made by the newspapers, changed that statement from a specific response to an interjection and converted it into a statement relevant to the formulation of immigration policy. As his daughter, Mary Elizabeth Calwell, who is equally outraged by this program, has correctly pointed out:

SPEECH.PARA: My father changed the Immigration category of the `Middle East' from Asia to Europe, tried to relieve restrictions on the Chinese community in 1947 and encouraged people to keep their heritage. He was an Australian, proud of his Irish, American and Welsh ancestry who spoke Gaelic and some Mandarin. He said that `politics is the art of the possible' and it is sad that the reviewer apparently accepted an appalling misrepresentation of the person who ensured the future of Judaism and Jewry in this country.

I was a pallbearer at Arthur Calwell's funeral and I watched as the heart of Melbourne stopped to pay tribute to this great Australian. It was also interesting to note that the nature of politics was such that the then former Prime Minister, Mr Menzies, who was at that time quite ill and who could not physically present himself in the church, sat outside in his car during the ceremony.

PARA.TAB: For those who talk about this man Calwell as a racist, it is interesting to note that as a tribute, not merely to their local member but to a distinguished Minister of immigration, the Chinese community which is centred in Melbourne in the heart of Little Bourke Street, closed their shops and their restaurants. That was a tribute of enormous proportions.

Therefore, I am bound to conclude that with a little more research on the part of the producers of Admission Impossible and, perhaps, with a little more regard by those who were responsible in the ABC for getting this program to air, the community would have been informed of the origins of our immigration policy and the vision of Arthur Calwell, rather than a scissors and paste exercise in the presentation of a film which, one can only conclude, sought to justify the conclusions and inaccurate perceptions of its producers.

I have a letter from a distinguished and very senior immigration official, who was responsible for the administration of policy. His letter, which he also sent to the ABC, is in strong support of the role and vision of Arthur Calwell and condemnatory of this program. I seek leave to table a letter from Mr H. J. Grant of Rosenthal Street, Campbell.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today, I want to draw to the attention of the Parliament the very serious nature of the agricultural downturn that is facing farmers in this nation. This downturn, I believe, is very much more serious than the cyclical downturns we have seen in the past and it has national implications. It is not only a very serious economic and social problem; it is also a very serious problem for the environment. I would suggest that the response of the Government to date can only be described as pathetic.

PARA.TAB: In 1993-94 the net value of farm production is forecast to be $2.1 billion. This is about half what it was in the late 1980s. I am talking about the average for the 1980s, not just one year. But the situation is very much more serious than just the economic one. It has a much wider effect where it is devastating the families of many individuals. It is devastating farms and it is devastating local communities. The tragedy is that so much of the wider community is largely unaware of just how serious it is and, in particular, what the effect of the lack of investment that has come about through this economic downturn is having right throughout country Australia. It seems that the whole productive base of primary industry, which has been the backbone of this nation for the last 150 years or more, is being eroded and eroded quite rapidly at a time when, frankly, I think this nation needs more than ever before to have a strong, vibrant and healthy, agricultural sector.

It is interesting to note the Government's priorities. For example, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) made a lot of noise with his recent announcement concerning the rural adjustment scheme involving somewhat less than $50 million. Putting that in perspective, the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) is authorising for his new gazebo, Gareth's gazebo, the new building for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, an amount at least four times that figure. Given past records of government spending, one would suspect that that might even get higher. I think that indicates the priorities that the Government has—and I would suggest very wrong priorities—when it comes to dealing with what is a very serious problem.

One of the things to remember about our farming community is just how much it has increased its productivity. While commodity prices have steadily declined since the 1960s, farmers are becoming more productive and yields are up by about 40 per cent since 1970. In fact, since 1970 the agricultural sector has increased productivity at literally double the rate of other economic sectors. Yet in the last two decades, with an annual productivity growth averaging 2.2 per cent, we still are seeing a decline in agriculture. Total rural debt, for example, has blown out from $10.6 billion in 1987 to $15.6 billion last year and no doubt that figure will be exceeded this year.

The average woolgrower lost almost $40,000 last year and a loss of $34,000 is expected this year. Given the $34,000 that the Bureau of Agriculture and Resource Economics is forecasting for next year, that is a loss of over $100,000. That person and his or her family have to live as well as try to run a business, and the impact of that loss is very severe. A three-year loss for a broad acre farmer—that is one who is involved in cropping as well—is expected to be just under $50,000. Again, a very serious problem is emerging.

But the problems go further than that. Because of the lack of investment we are seeing problems in three areas. We are seeing a decline in the productive assets, we are seeing a decline in the level of services to the rural community, and we are increasingly seeing a lack of resources available to tackle some of the environmental problems that are degrading many of our farmlands.

This is a very long-term problem and one the Government has not tried to address to date. To start with the Government has not recognised the growing lack of competitiveness of Australian farmers partly imposed by the tax regime that currently is there. The Government's own figures confirm that Australian farmers are three to five per cent worse off against our trading partners due to the taxes on inputs into production. We have to recognise that people in the country are also disadvantaged by the fuel taxes that impact very much more on people living in rural areas than they do on people living in the city.

The question about how we are to continue to match the world's best practice has to be addressed in the light of the lack of investment in new plant and equipment. There was a farm facts assets survey done in 1991 and it found that only eight per cent of the farming equipment was less than five years old and that there was a tendency for machinery age to be related to the declining yield of crops.

When one goes to other farming areas, one will find that woolsheds, for example, have an average age of 45 years—and there are many innovations in woolsheds that ought to be adopted and obviously have not been. Sheep yards have an average age of 27 years and cattle yards an average age of 21 years, and all those studied in this survey were in less than fair condition. The number of farm machinery dealers is also indicative of what is happening: 2,400 in 1986; 950 in 1991—less than half—with a further fall of 300 expected in the current year. In other words, the number of farm machinery dealers in the last seven years has dropped to one quarter: a staggering statistic! Think of what that is doing, by way of not only its direct impact on farming but also, through that, its impact on local communities.

We also have to look at the effect on the environment. There is no doubt that farmers have been at the forefront in trying to turn around land degradation. In fact, they really are the only people who can do it. Of course, it all costs money. If they are losing money—for example, a woolgrower may lose $100,000 over three years—how on earth are they going to be able to afford to do what they know in their own hearts is right? How can they do that if they cannot spare the money just to live, let alone get on with doing some of those other things?

If we look at the effect of this decline on the rural communities, we see a decline in the number of people living there and a decline in the infrastructure in the rural towns, with people moving to the cities. Of course there are many assets that are underutilised, at the same time as increasing pressures are occurring on some of the big cities. If one looks at a simple thing like the family home on a farm these days, in many cases those homes are deteriorating and would be considerably inferior to the sort of home that people would expect to live in in one of the major cities.

The lack of capital investment goes on. This is seen not just in tractors and so on, but also in the fact that farmers cannot afford to employ enough people to keep their farms up to a reasonable standard. In the same survey, 64 per cent of the farmers said they needed more labour, but only five per cent said they could afford it. When we look at the effects of some of the other Government policies on people trying to survive on the land, we find that it all militates against them. Look at the assets test that is applied to Austudy. Sure, farmers may have a nominal value in their farm but, if they have no income, I think that really is an unjust way of assessing eligibility for Austudy. This is reflected very strongly in the number of farming children who go on to tertiary education. If we look at some of the studies that have been done in Victoria, we find that the numbers are about half those of their city counterparts—a very frightening statistic.

So I would suggest that this is a very serious problem, not just for country Australia but for the whole nation. All Australians should be concerned about this long-term decline in our rural sector. It may be largely invisible to many, nonetheless it is very real, very serious, and I believe it should be addressed as a national priority not just for country people but for the whole nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My grievance relates to a matter that was probably discussed earlier today—country of origin labelling and products sold in Australia. It arises out of an example of misleading labelling brought to my attention by a constituent in my electorate of Oxley. Like most Australians, this constituent likes whenever possible to purchase products which are actually produced in Australia. Most Australians recognise the need to buy Australian in order to help reduce our balance of payments deficit and to reduce our dependency on imports.

PARA.TAB: I am sure that all honourable members welcome moves by the Government over recent years to encourage consumers to buy Australian, and it is certainly something that I very strongly welcome. One example of successful Government action in this area has been the buy your kids a job program which the Government has run in conjunction with the Advance Australia Foundation. The Government has also given the foundation financial assistance for its Australian Made campaign. In this financial year, over $4 million has been allocated to help the Australian Made campaign promotion.

If all Australians made the decision to buy Australian made products wherever feasible and stopped buying foreign made substitutes, it would be a huge boost to Australia's economic development. If we as consumers are to buy Australian made, it should be easy to judge from a product's packaging whether a product is or is not Australian made.

However, because of the misleading labelling which appears on some products, the task of buying Australian made is not always as easy as it should be. Take the example of the product brought to my attention by one of my constituents, the Sheen video cassette. I have actually got one here with me. I cannot do much with it in terms of incorporating it but I will just explain what it says on the packaging. On the front of the packaging for the video cassette, in large bold printing, it has the words, `The All Australian Video Group', right across the front of it. In the bottom right-hand corner it has the words `Australian Guarantee' and that is surrounded by two boomerangs. One would assume that is an Australian made product with all the identification on the front of it. Any consumer who looked only at the front of this packaging would assume that this product was made in Australia by an Australian owned company, as the packaging uses the words `all Australian' and uses the boomerang, which is well known and easily identified as a symbol of Australia.

But when we look carefully at the back of the box we will soon discover that this is not the case. Actually, on the back of this product, it actually has `Made in Korea' in one corner of it. Then, when we go a little bit further, we also discover that, rather than being manufactured by an `All Australian Video Group', the product is manufactured under licence for Victor Company of Japan. So we have all the other things on the front of it which indicate that it is clearly an Australian product but when we look at the back it is made in Korea, manufactured under licence for the Victor company of Japan. It is clearly misleading advertising.

Whilst manufacturers of this product abide by the letter of the law by having the words `Made in Korea' on the packaging, they are clearly attempting to mislead consumers by implying on the front of the box that the package is manufactured in Australia by an Australian owned company.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is outrageous.

—It certainly is outrageous, and it has to be stopped. Clearly action has to be taken to stop companies misleading consumers about the country of origin of a product by the manner in which this product has been labelled. The Government has recently begun the process of developing a strategy for more accurate country of origin labelling, and the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Ms McHugh) has been working particularly hard in this area. I congratulate her on those efforts. Last October the Government established a working party consisting of a range of representatives from various government departments and agencies to draw up options for country of origin labelling schemes. The report of the working group was released early this week by the Minister for Consumer Affairs. The working group found that the various pieces of legislation currently in force at a federal and State level in relation to country of origin labelling were potentially contradictory, and that many suppliers are not able to work out what is required of them when it comes to labelling.

PARA.TAB: This confusion amongst suppliers then leads to confusion amongst consumers, who cannot determine which country products are actually made in. It is instructive to read the list of descriptions currently in use on packaging in Australia to understand how consumers could easily become confused. The list of descriptors includes—there is quite a range of them—made in Australia; Australian made; manufactured in Australia; product of Australia; produce of Australia; produced in Australia; processed in Australia; packaged in Australia; assembled in Australia; servicing Australia; and Australian made from local and imported ingredients.

It is no wonder, with such a diverse number of ways of describing a product, that consumers can easily become confused as to what is Australian made and what is not. The working group's report goes on to outline a proposal for country of origin labelling. This proposal involves amendments to the Trade Practices Act 1974 to include the descriptors to be used when describing a product and the tests that are to be applied when determining which of the descriptors is to be used for the product.

In the new scheme, any supplier that made a claim about a product's country of origin would have to use the descriptor specified by the new section of the Trade Practices Act. The new scheme will also go some way to addressing the problem that occurs when a product assembled in Australia has foreign made components, another important area. `Made in Australia' would only be able to be used when more than 85 per cent of the cost of producing the product was incurred in Australia. When less than 85 per cent of the input into the production process are Australian, the `Made in Australia' tag could not be used without qualification. Such products would have a qualified statement such as `Made in Australia from Australian and imported components'.

The committee put forward two options for the words that could be used to symbolise that a product was made in Australia. Under option one, suppliers would be restricted to using either `Made in Australia', `Product of Australia' or `Produce of Australia'. In the second option terms such as `Produced in Australia' or `Australian Made' could also be used. Also, under option two, the label for a foreign made product would simply state that it was made in wherever was the country of origin. If a manufacturer wished to add additional words such as `Designed in Australia', this could only be done after first stating the product's country of origin.

The report of the working groups on country of origin labelling of consumer products is a useful starting point for reform in this area. Clearly, action needs to be taken to ensure that Australians are able to exercise their rights as consumers to purchase Australian made products wherever possible. Only when there is an accurate labelling of a product's country of origin will consumers have the information they need to purchase more Australian goods.

While the moves by the Government to tighten up labelling requirements are a step in the right direction, clearly more needs to be done to prevent false and misleading labelling on products such as the one I have highlighted here this afternoon. The Sheen video cassette would still comply with the letter of the law under the proposed country of origin labelling scheme. Not only should products have their correct country of origin on their packaging, manufacturers such as the Victor company of Japan should not be able to get away with claiming that they are an `All Australian Company', or be able to use well-known Australian symbols such as the boomerang on their products.

While I welcome the Government's initiatives in the area of country of origin labelling, the measures need to go an extra step to prevent deceptions of the type perpetrated by the manufacturers of the Sheen video cassette. When it comes to purchasing Australian made products, I believe it is one of the most important things that we can look at to actually give jobs to our kids. Given the level of unemployment that we have today, Australian consumers have to become more and more conscious of the need to inspect items and find out if they are Australian goods.

I support very strongly the view that in some stores it would be a good idea to have areas designed specifically for Australian made products and to have foreign made products in other areas. In that way people could go to where they want to go and forget about the foreign goods altogether. It would probably be a better move than labelling and we will see just how many people go to the section in the store that has the foreign made goods.

I think it is a matter that we, as members of Parliament, really need to take a bipartisan approach to and encourage our constituents right throughout our electorates to buy Australian goods wherever possible and be more critical of those products. Sometimes it is not such a bad idea to pay a little bit more for an Australian made product because it may be that it is your son or daughter who is given a job as a result. It is only through developing Australian industries and by purchasing our own locally made products that we can effectively help those people who are unemployed and help develop our industries in Australia, particularly in our manufacturing sector.

I draw the attention of the House today to this particular product which was drawn to my attention by one of my constituents—a good friend of mine—and I think it is important to highlight to the Parliament the problems that consumers face when they wish to buy products.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Dr D.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate about whether or not Australia should formally declare itself a republic is a debate above all about our national identity—about who we Australians are, what we have been, what our destiny is and how we approach that destiny. I welcome that debate. It is an opportunity to engage a new generation of Australians in the consideration of their nation, its constitution and its values. Out of such a debate I believe we will forge a new consciousness of the remarkable democracy which has evolved here—one of the great democracies of the world—and its capacity to respond to the challenges we face in a world of accelerating change.

PARA.TAB: Australia will not become more independent either in spirit or in its relations with other nations if we are incapable of acknowledging the uniqueness of our own national experience and the strengths of our institutions. No established nation has advanced its position in the world by apologising for its past or by dismantling what is unique in its institutions.

The fundamental weakness of the case of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for a republic is that it is based on an attack on Australia and its past. He seeks to promote his republic by a divisive weakening of our sense of ourselves. The Prime Minister's republic is not the culmination of a history in which we can take pride. It is to be the symbolic slamming of the door on a past which the Prime Minister despises, and the establishment of Australia as an Asian nation which has turned its back on its European heritage.

The Prime Minister's republicanism has dark roots in his obsessive hatred of the British origins of Australia's political institutions, law and language. His desire is to expunge every reminder of them, by tearing the Union Jack out of the flag, by writing them out of the constitution and, wherever possible, by rewriting our history. It is also part of his broader agenda to dismantle the checks on his own power which the conventions of our present constitution impose.

In making his case, he has not hesitated to falsify our history. He has claimed that Australian military forces in the past did not fight under the Australian flag. That is untrue. Australia's soldiers were inspired and uplifted by the flag. This is made clear in Sir John Monash's account of that triumphal and historic moment, when the Australians turned the tide against Germany on 8 August 1918. That day was regarded by the Germans themselves as the turning point of the war, when the Australians and Canadians broke through the German lines. At 1.15 p.m., General Monash recorded:

SPEECH.PARA: Australian flag hoisted over Harbonnieres at midday today. Should be glad if Chief would cable this to our Governor-General on behalf of Australian corps.

Australia's identity has been enriched and broadened by the growing number of people who have come from other European countries, as it has by the growing acknowledgment of the importance of the heritage of the Aboriginal people. These, too, are important elements in our identity. But a national leader who seeks to create the future by denying, attacking and distorting, and who is embarrassed by the central contribution of Britain to our institutions, our law, our language and our national identity, is offering an impoverished and inadequate foundation for our future. It is a foundation based on a deep misunderstanding of what Australia has been and is.

PARA.TAB: If we owe the strength and stability of our democracy to any source, it is to Britain—the world's most successful proponent of constitutional government. Even apparently minor conventions, such as the presentation of the Governor-General's address in the upper house, remind us of past victories of Parliament over the executive but which the Prime Minister, in his grab for power, is all too ready and keen to expunge. It is not forelock tugging to acknowledge this; it is honesty.

One of the ugly features of the current debate, indeed, is the promotion of an intolerant and narrow view of what it is to be an Australian, which rests on a denial and distortion of our history, and which demands the rejection and disavowal of long established institutions and traditions combined with the astonishing assertion that, although they have been around for a very long time, they are not really Australian.

The most extreme version of this that I have seen is contained within a report on the Ethnic composition of the Australian Defence Force by four academics from the Australian Defence Force Academy and the Australian National University. Chapter 10 of this report, entitled Images of the Australian Defence Force, argues that the Defence Force should abandon ceremonies, symbols and celebrations which are clearly British in origin in favour of ceremonies, symbols and celebrations which are, in its words, `truly Australian'.

It is always reasonable to suggest that institutions adjust to change, but this report has features which are deeply disturbing. It does not simply suggest revision of, or additions to, the traditions and practices of the defence forces. It effectively recommends wholesale abandonment of features of the defence forces which have obvious British origins. In doing so, the report adopts a highly restrictive interpretation of Australia's multicultural society. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Scottish regalia denies the Australianness of the ADF.

The millions of Australians of Scottish origin would deeply resent the claim that they are un-Australian. A genuine and broad concept of multiculturalism should not be so hesitant to acknowledge the contribution of the ethnic groups from Britain.

PARA.TAB: Moreover, the report is underpinned by an untenable concept of Australian identity and a fictitious view of Australian history. What it calls `truly Australian' is, in reality, what is narrowly Australian. While on the one hand supporting the notion of Australia as a multicultural society, it is reluctant to acknowledge as `truly Australian' anything which has its origins elsewhere in the world, particularly if elsewhere is Britain. Its concept of what is `truly Australian' is actually incompatible with the concept of Australia as a multicultural society.

When Australians fought at Gallipoli, they were proudly Australian, but equally saw Australia's interests as being closely linked with the security of the British Empire, of which they were a proud part. But for the authors of this report, and I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: Anzac Day commemorates a failed campaign as part of a British force.
The report goes on:

There is no Australian defence force wide or even single service celebration of a date commemorating some action in defence of Australia's national sovereignty. The vast majority of Australians then and the vast majority of Australians today would see Anzac Day as such a celebration.
The attack on Anzac Day in this report is the starkest evidence of the failure of this document to have anything worth while to say about Australia identity.

PARA.TAB: Like the Australian Constitution, the Australian identity has evolved and continues to evolve. Whether the Prime Minister likes it or not, and he plainly does not, the British, Scots and English, together with the Irish, the origins of our national institutions and culture are a historical reality. We do not need to disown these foundations upon which we have built one of the world's great democratic institutions. Indeed, we should not try to sever our history at this point, to draw a veil over the past and reinvent the nation, to gratify the political whims of a prejudiced and narrow man. It is not a grand but a narrow and truncated vision which would deliberately break the threads which link the generations in this country across the years and replace emotion filled symbols as if they were brand names or logos on a packet of biscuits.

We do not need to turn our back on our European heritage to become an influential nation in our region. It is that heritage which will enable us to make our unique contribution. We do not need to deny our British heritage and its symbols in order to move beyond them into the future, because it is to that heritage that we owe the political institutions which enable us to look to the future with confidence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just returned from a trip to the Kimberleys, in the top part of my electorate, where I visited Aboriginal cattle stations. I visited Noonkanbah, Louisa Downs and Mount Barnett. As a generalisation, I would say that the standard of the stock on these properties and the quality of the improvements on these properties are better than they ever were under white management.

PARA.TAB: One of the things that were graphically illustrated to me was how out of touch we are getting with Aboriginals and Aboriginal aspirations. Everywhere I went in these communities, people told me that they were heartily sick of ATSIC and wanted nothing to do with it; that they opposed Mabo—indeed, two stations have Mabo style land claims on them; and that the high powered meeting that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) had had in his office with Aboriginal people did not represent them; in fact they did not know who they were. They were very critical of the museum, which they said was distorting Aboriginal culture for its political purposes. Generally, they said, `We are Australian, we are part of Australia and we want nothing more than what everyone gets. We do not want special consideration, we want to be in the mainstream'.

This is a view overwhelmingly of Aboriginal people; it is not the view that has been disseminated in the cities. I have said, and I am prepared to say again categorically, that any one of those gentlemen meeting with the Prime Minister in Canberra, in what was termed the highest powered meeting of Aboriginal people ever, I would be prepared to stand against at an election in Western Australia where only Aboriginal people voted and I would win convincingly. As Aboriginal people said to me, they voted for me; for them, they did not.

I want to deal particularly with Mount Barnett, because I think this station is a real gem. I want to pay a tribute to Billy King, the chairman of the Kupungarri community and the manager of the station. Billy is a man of the old school. He can still hot shoe a horse, and there a very few people today who could do that, and at 72 he can still ride a damn sight better than I can. I did have some salutary lessons in other places. For instance, when I was at Louisa Downs, I was talking there to Wayne Gordon, who had just finished building a set of cattle yards. The cattle yards were clearly the most workable yards I have ever seen and when I looked at them I thought to myself, `Why didn't I think of that?'. I used to build cattle yards for a living as a contractor and I can tell the House I have never built a set of cattle yards as good as those. I am determined to see that that design is recognised as the Gordon design of yards.
I return to Mount Barnett to bring the Parliament's attention to a situation that occurred there. I have an explanatory letter to read:

SPEECH.PARA: This paper has been dictated by Mr Billy King, Chairman of the Kupungarri Community at Mt. Barnett Station.
Billy King is a very highly respected elder of the Ngarinyin people and has passed through all stages of tribal law.

He is speaking out not just for himself but on behalf of other tribal elders who are greatly concerned about the actions of David Mowaljarli and others who claim a status to which they are not entitled.
These elders understand that the Government and its departments would not be aware of Ngarinyin Tribal law and can easily be misled.
Although the normal stance taken by the elders is to ignore such happenings, in this case where their own law ways are directly affected they wish to make others aware of the situation.
Any decisions concerning Ngarinyin Tribal law and the associated paintings must be made by all tribal elders together. No one person has the right to decide on such matters.

PARA.TAB: This arises because Mr David Mowaljarli, much feted by the press, named Australian Citizen of the Year and feted generally, received a grant from the Commonwealth Government through the State museum in Western Australia to restore Aboriginal paintings. The paintings he had in mind were very significant paintings on Mount Barnett station. So he collected some Aboriginal kids from Derby, went up there, completely whited out the paintings and had these kids redraw them. The community knew nothing about this and was greatly affronted.

This act of vandalism, for which he apparently got the Order of Australia, was just horrendous. A white person who did that would be in gaol. The community was concerned about it and actually wrote this paper, which I will not have time to read in its entirety. The community wanted the paper read out at the Congress of the Australian Rock Art Research Association which was taking place in Queensland at the time. Although they made two attempts to have it read out, that congress ignored the pleadings of these people.

These people have set out quite clearly the traditional method of restoring those paintings. When they explain their tribal ways one is astounded at the commonsense that exists. They say that the custodian of the paintings would regularly inspect the paintings. If he himself was not an artist, he would take one with him and that artist would touch up the paintings in a traditional manner under the direct supervision of the custodian. Mr Billy King also tells how, as a youngster, he went to art class training and the elders would have all the Aboriginal kids draw pictures continually. Those that showed promise were encouraged and the others were discouraged. It is quite clear that this community has been greatly disadvantaged. A tourist attraction has been greatly reduced in value and all at the expense of taxpayers. I believe this matter does need investigating.

It was fobbed off at the time by the University of Western Australia, but I think one must look at the history of the University of Western Australia. The University of Western Australia in its prehistory and archaeological departments is corrupt—intellectually corrupt and maybe corrupt in other ways. For instance, I have in my possession two documents from the university's prehistory department in which it seeks to tender its services commercially to the mining industry. One of these documents says of a particular area that `it was so sacred you could not touch one single stone'. The other document says of another area that it was of so little significance that they could not get any Aboriginals interested and that they were going to clear it within 10 kilometres of the mine site. That was the Giralia goldmine site. Unfortunately, the Yakabindie mine and the Giralia mine overlap. So the University cannot have it both ways. On the one hand, they are saying, for purely political reasons, that Yakabindie was so sacred that it could not be touched but, on the other hand, that there was no interest at all in the other one. The map reading was certainly not as strong as the political agenda. That is the sort of thing we have to put up with.

I have been approached by Aboriginals at Meekatharra who are claiming that they are being disadvantaged by what they see as the Aboriginal industry. The museum has given instructions that any mining company seeking to work in the area must consult with a particular Aboriginal. The tribal elders say, `This Aboriginal has never been initiated, knows no Aboriginal law and does not come from the area; why should he be consulted?'. They say, quite rightly, that that consultation process diminishes the status and the authority of the traditional lawgivers. I know that everywhere I go in my electorate, and I suspect it is the same Australia-wide, Aboriginals are saying, `We want to mine, we want to talk directly to the mining companies, we do not like the land councils, we want no part of them'. Yet what we seem to be doing is entrenching the authority of the land councils. Why would we not? When one looks at the Aboriginal industry in Australia one looks at a $2 billion industry—a bit more than $1 billion from the Commonwealth Government and a little less from the States. If one is to ask whether the policy of Aboriginal Affairs has been for the benefit of Aboriginal people, one would have to be very dubious about it. Indeed, it is my view that the policy of Aboriginal Affairs was never designed for that purpose. It was designed to placate affluent, urban, white middle-class guilt, and to that end it has been highly successful. It has been so successful that people are now saying, `All this money we spend on Aboriginals and nothing gets better; they are hopeless, they are no-hopers'. The truth is that the great bulk of Aboriginal people out there hate that as much as anyone: they hate the patronage, they hate the corruption that goes with the present ATSIC system, and they want to get on with their lives as Australians.

One woman who is a hero of mine, Mrs Parker, said to me once, `Why is that my children have to prove they are Australian over and over again? A Greek can come to this country and in the next generation their kids are accepted widely, but my kids have to prove it over and over again'. It is about time we got some rationality back into Aboriginal affairs and started listening to Aboriginal people and not to the professionals who inhabit the office of the Prime Minister.

If one looks at the agenda they promised the Prime Minister, one can only wonder how they got in the door. Not only were there other extravagant claims but also demands for immediate negotiation for setting up an independent Aboriginal nation within Australia. This is not the wish or the desire of the great bulk of Aboriginal people, and I speak in this place today to put their views on record.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I pay tribute to the previous speaker, the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell). I think it is the finest and most rational address on Aboriginal affairs I have heard since I listened to Fred Hollows some six years ago when I did not even know who he was. I watched him on television one night and thought, `This bloke really knows what he is talking about', and so did the previous speaker. I am here to give an identical speech, strangely enough.

PARA.TAB: We passed land rights legislation in Queensland in 1984 and God was good to me in giving me the privilege of being the Minister when those laws were passed. I want to read some names into the record: from Hopevale we got advice from the Rosendales, the Gibsons, the Pearsons, the Deerals and the Deemals; from Pormpuraaw the Shortjoes and the Holroyds; from the Torres Strait the legendary George Mye and Getano Lui; from Yarrabah the Alfie Neals, the Roy Grays and the Mick Connollys; and from other places the Eric Laws, the Les Stewarts and Tommy Geias. We also got advice from Frank Brennan, the very prominent priest who has been active in these areas, and from the Anglican, Catholic and Lutheran churches.

When we passed the legislation in Queensland—the community services Act 1984 and the Land Act (Aboriginal and Islander Grants) Amendment Act 1984—we were not criticised in any way as the Queensland Government, but we were not praised either. What we had done was viewed with very great suspicion because we had a history of not getting on well with people of Aboriginal descent. However, as time went on and people began to understand the implications of what had happened, we were lauded. In fact, some 20,000 people turned out for the handing-over ceremony when the Aboriginal people, after three, four and five generations, once again owned their land. We are talking about a very significant amount of land in Queensland—seven million acres—and it is not desert country. Almost all of it is country with an above 40-inch rainfall, and it is some of the most valuable land in Queensland—Yarrabah adjoins Cairns, of course—so it was an extremely valuable resource that was being handed over.

I make the point that we were not in the business of land rights in the sense that we were taking land off somebody else and giving it to these people. This was land that they had traditionally and legally owned, as was recognised by successive governments in the State of Queensland. No-one could argue in any meaningful sense that this land was not theirs. We passed those laws and the net result was that in the community stores the profits went from a loss of $408,000 a year to a profit of $924,000 a year, and the cattle turn-off leapt from 965 a year to 5,835 a year.

The crayfishing industry—and I must stress that these are soft but I think accurate figures—went from $0.3 million to $7 million. The turnover at Masig Island in fishing went from $14,000 to $291,000. The number of privately owned businesses operated by people of Aboriginal descent went from three to 52. The number of community services employees—those were predominantly people of white descent—was cut by some 21 per cent, and the number of jobs created in the building program alone was 328. So it was a magnificent success story. The trauma rates halved. The rioting stopped completely. In fact, in the last five years that I was Minister not one single riot took place in any community. Let me make a very valid comparison and put teeth in the remarks made by the previous speaker.

Two examples are Aurukun, which was under total white control and effectively under the control of the Federal Government, and Pormpuraaw, which was effectively under the control of the local council and black people. Aurukun started with 12,500 head of cattle. In five years there was not one solitary head of cattle left on Aurukun. Pormpuraaw started with 326 cattle on the books. In five years they ended up with 6,000 head of cattle on the books. That proves two things: one, that if people are given a fair go and if they are given the same rights and privileges as other Australians, they can perform just as successfully. That is living proof of that.

For those who question what I am saying, let me point out that we had the honour—to some degree, I suppose—when the Pope visited Australia of an address from him at Alice Springs, in which he advocated the introduction of the laws that existed in Queensland with respect to lands. Of course, the person drafting those laws was Father Brennan, whom I referred to earlier, who would have made the recommendations in the notes for the Pope's speech. Our Premier, Joe Bjelke-Petersen, who was not always an admirer of the Pope, I might add, rather coyly observed that everyone should take the Holy Father's advice and implement the same laws as Queensland.

That is not what I want to talk about today. What I want to talk about today is what happened. What happened to this success story? What happened to the vicious venom and hatred that now abides in the community? Why has the word `Mabo', which was honoured at the time, which was a rallying call for people to fight for their rights, now rebounded so badly upon Australia? To explain that I must quote from the Queensland Hansard:

SPEECH.PARA: In the current financial year the Federal Government will spend some $800m on Aboriginal affairs throughout Australia. Thirty per cent of people of Aboriginal descent live in the State and, even allowing a 10 per cent override for administration, this should allow some $220m to be spent on people of Aboriginal descent in the State.

PARA.TAB: Last year 30 per cent of the Aboriginal people of this State lived in what were once reserve areas of Queensland. They received not the $70m to which they were entitled but only $22m—

SPEECH.PARA: They are audited Federal Government figures-
A lot of that was CDEP money. But the big question is where has the missing $150m gone?

PARA.TAB: It has been suggested by former Senator Neville Bonner that 80 per cent of that money ends up in the pockets of whites—the pockets of consultants and advisers. But who are the consultants and advisers? Honourable members have heard a lot of talk about corruption. Today I am talking about institutionalised corruption, a system of . . . funds moved from the public purse into private pockets without any benefit accruing to the people of Queensland or Australia.

Not content with this record of inhumanity and paternalism in Government, Labor is now riding shotgun on a cheap political course. However, the question is how cheap? I refer to the case of Mabo and Others v. the State of Queensland and the Commonwealth of Australia, which is currently before the High Court of Australia and the Supreme Court of Queensland. I am advised by the Crown Solicitor that the plaintiffs' instructing solicitor in this case is Mr Greg McIntyre, who is no less than the principal legal officer of the Aboriginal Legal Service of Western Australia. Mr McIntyre is now recognised in Western Australia and in the High Court's jurisdiction as barrister and solicitor. He continues to act as solicitor for the plaintiffs. At the recent hearing before His Honour Mr Justice Moynihan, Mr McIntyre also appeared as counsel.

I am further advised that Mr MacIntyre's position, with a salary of $47,000, is funded by the Federal Government. Although once involved in legal aid in north Queensland, it is curious that a legal officer funded, by the Commonwealth to provide for the welfare of Aborigines in Western Australia, should be engaged in a case questioning the sovereignty of the Commonwealth of Australia and the State of Queensland. But that is not all.

Advice to me, again from the Crown Solicitor, is that Mr McIntyre's town agent in Melbourne is the firm of Holding, Redleich and Co. "Holding" refers to Labor's former Commonwealth Minister for Aboriginal Affairs at the time that case was commenced—Allan Clyde Holding, the member for Melbourne Ports and Minister in the Federal Government. I am advised that, whilst Mr Holding has retired from the firm for the duration of the Mabo case, he has for all this time acted as a consultant to his old firm.

It is more relevant to this House that Mr McIntyre's town agent in Brisbane is a firm that is familiar to all honourable members—the firm of Goss, Downey and Carne, the former firm of the Leader of the Opposition in this place. Whether Mr Holding, Mr Goss and the ALP are profiting directly—

SPEECH.PARA: and I am not suggesting here that they are, and I want to emphasise that—
or just looking after their business—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, on a point of order—
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. Does the Parliamentary Secretary have a point of order?
—Yes, Mr Speaker. The honourable member is reflecting on a member of this House in his comments.
—Who?
—The Hon. Clyde Holding. Aren't you listening?
—He went past that about 10 minutes ago.

—No, he has not gone past it. The honourable member is making a reflection. If he has anything to say, he should make a substantive motion in relation to that reflection. I ask him, firstly, to withdraw that reflection and, secondly, if he has anything to say he should proceed on the basis of a substantive motion.
—Mr Speaker, I refer you to the very last sentence I spoke before the interjector stood up. I am not alleging that these people put money in their pocket directly. I am not alleging that at all.
—I think the honourable member has been around in Parliament long enough to know how it should be dealt with, and I am listening intently as well.
—All right; that is fine. To continue:

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to understand how much money has been expended on the Mabo case, which has now spanned seven years.

Honourable members should remember that the last speaker spoke about all these people with white guilt in the cities who are getting the money. The advice to me from the head of the department stated that $528,431 had been expended so far, and this did not take into account the cost of the time and services of officers in the Solicitor-General's office, DCS, and other assisting departments.

PARA.TAB: Time is running out on me, but I must say this in conclusion: the Mabo case continued when Queensland had granted that land to these people. Eddie Mabo simply had to ask his local council on Mer Island, and Mer Island had agreed to it. I do not in any way want to disparage Eddie Mabo, but the islanders were dead right because, with the incoming socialist government, all the land was taken off them, with the worst riots in Queensland history. They tore the front doors off Parliament House—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tanner Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I trust sincerely that the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) does not suffer from high blood pressure. I would suggest to him that, if he does, the combination of speed reading and conspiracy theories is a very bad recipe for exacerbating that problem.

PARA.TAB: I would like to introduce my comments by referring to the slight that he has passed on the firm of Holding Redlich & Co., which I actually had the privilege to work for for three years in the early 1980s. The honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) can certainly defend himself appropriately in this place, but I would suggest to the honourable member for Kennedy that the sort of lunatic conspiracy theories that he is peddling really are totally misplaced and a slight that is totally unjustified on a very fine law firm.
I would like now to deal with the crisis that is currently facing the community health sector in inner suburban Melbourne. I have a number of community health centres in my electorate—

TALK.START.PARA: —Watch the blood pressure. I have a number of community health centres in my electorate; and there are three, in Collingwood, Fitzroy and Carlton, which recently, as a result of the actions of the Kennett Government, have suffered a combined cut in their funding of over $1 million out of a total funding level of $1.9 million. In other words, these centres, which perform a

SPEECH.PARA: very valuable role for the people of those communities, have suffered funding cuts of over 50 per cent. If one takes into account the fact that there is a significant fixed cost in running any organisation of this nature, the real funding cut is probably of the order of 70 per cent or more.

PARA.TAB: This funding cut has been based on a totally spurious analysis of the distribution of services in the health sector across the metropolitan area, based on a dubious notion that the inner suburbs are overserviced. What the analysis it is based on has failed to recognise is that there are a substantial number of State-wide or regional services located in those areas and they are assumed to be, in effect, the same as a purely localised service. It also ignores the fact that, in areas like Fitzroy, Collingwood and areas of that nature in my electorate, there is inevitably a substantially high level of demand for the sorts of services that community health centres provide. There are in-built extra costs, for example, because of the need for interpreters to be provided because there are substantially higher levels of non-English speaking background people using those services.

As it was put to me in a meeting the other night by one of the key figures in the Fitzroy health service, what this exercise illustrates more than anything else is that if you torture the figures for long enough you can get any result you like; they will confess to anything. That is precisely what is happening in Victoria under the Kennett Government.

These health centres play a very important role in their local communities. They are crucial to the pursuit of preventive medicine strategies in a variety of areas. They play a very important role in education on issues such as nutrition and fitness, on the reduction of smoking, on prevention of AIDS and a variety of other issues, and they manage to reach communities that are very often impervious to other education strategies in these sorts of areas. So, although the effect of these educative programs will not show up in any accountant's analysis of the budgetary provisions for the health sector, in the long term we are going to see in our community substantial improvements in many areas in cases of heart disease, lung cancer and the like, because of the work of these community health centres.

They operate often in areas that are very poorly serviced by the private sector. In Collingwood, for example, there is a very limited presence of the private medical sector and the Collingwood health service plays a dominant role in the provision of GP services in that area. They are staffed universally, in my experience, by people who are dedicated to the work that they are performing, who are not there to make a buck, and the doctors in particular are deserving of the highest praise for the long hours and the hard work that they do for remuneration that ultimately ends up being less than what they can get elsewhere, in many cases.

Finally, they provide a very important focus of integration of people of recent migrant origin into our community. In the case of the Fitzroy community health centre and the Hmong people who have recently migrated in substantial numbers to Australia, involvement with that health centre has been an important focus through which that particular people have managed to reach out to other areas of the community and other sectors.

The community health centres account for only a tiny proportion of the total health budget in the State of Victoria and yet you have got a situation where some of the heaviest cuts, far out of proportion to what is occurring in many other areas of the health budget, are being imposed on these centres. Recently we saw over 500 people demonstrating on the basis of the cuts to the Fitzroy community health centre in the streets of Melbourne. That illustrates that these centres do have strong community support and there is certainly strong activity going on within my electorate to seek to turn around the actions of the Kennett Government.

There are many conservative elements in the health bureaucracy, in the medical profession and elsewhere that do not like community health centres. They were, of course, an initiative of the Whitlam Government—one of the greatest governments this country has ever seen. They pursue an ethos of preventive medicine, in contrast to the pursuit of high technology toys that seems to be all the vogue in many areas, and they pursue an ethos of community involvement that is critical in many of those disadvantaged communities in the inner suburbs.

The Federal Government used to fund them. It handed the funding obligations over to the States some time ago. I would suggest to the House that the time is coming soon when we will have to re-examine our role with respect to the community health centres. We have now such an irresponsible, such a straight-out class motivated government in the State of Victoria that is doing everything it can to destroy a very worthwhile sector among the providers of health services. It is a very cost effective sector and it provides services that many people would not be able to get access to otherwise.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Melbourne Ports wishes to make a personal explanation. Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, grievously misrepresented.
—You may proceed.

—The honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter), in speaking to the House, made a reference to me in my former capacity as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and my relationship to the legal firm of Holding Redlich. I have known the honourable member for some time and I understand that, as we all know, his thought processes do not always keep up with his volubility. But the truth of the matter is that, in accordance with the practices which were adopted by this Government, on becoming a Minister of the crown I resigned and terminated any relationship I had with Holding Redlich. I can understand that the honourable member for Kennedy would not understand that, having been a member of the National Party Queensland Government. If I want to visit my former legal partners, I can usually find them—
—Order! The honourable member might get to the point of why he thinks he is being misrepresented.
—The point is that I understand why the honourable member for Kennedy would think that way, because if he wants to visit some of his ministerial colleagues he has to go to Boggo Road Gaol.
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat.

—A major problem confronts members of Queensland's deaf community, particularly those living in provincial and rural areas of the State. In my electorate of Groom there are more than 200 deaf adults or people suffering from a hearing impairment who are in desperate need of the services of extra trained adult interpreters.

PARA.TAB: At present the Queensland Deaf Society is able to provide only one qualified interpreter who comes from Brisbane to Toowoomba once a month to provide a service to the adult deaf population. The visiting interpreter's fee is normally around $25 per hour for a four-hour session, plus $15 per hour travelling time. The interpreter must be sanctioned by the Queensland Deaf Society and must hold the highest level of qualification. Herein lies one of the problems. The only places where courses are available for the interpreters to gain the necessary qualifications are in Melbourne, Sydney and Perth. Figures for interpreters for other States show Victoria has between 18 and 20 of these interpreters and New South Wales has 12. Only four adult qualified translators and two interpreters are available for service to Queensland's deaf community of 4,000. I hope that some of our TAFE colleges in Queensland will be able soon to introduce important courses that will enable more qualified translators and interpreters to be made available by the Queensland Deaf Society in provincial and remote areas of the State.

These issues are important for a small but important number of people in the community who are inflicted with a handicap that for some time has seen them totally disadvantaged and perhaps even discriminated against.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would suggest that the current debate in Australia surrounding the moves to reform our Constitution in order to recognise our growth as an independent nation has to a large extent been distracted by the confrontation over the status of the flag.

PARA.TAB: I believe that a solution is possible that would recognise the conflicting views being promoted. My solution is that upon declaration of a republic—hopefully on 1 January 2001—Australia would adopt an additional flag emblem to recognise the declaration. The practical outcome would be that from the declaration date Australia would have an additional symbol to represent it. However, for all the events that relate to the period of the Commonwealth of Australia—1901 to 2001—the flag of that period should be flown. Therefore, we would have a flag for the Commonwealth of Australia that reflected 1901 to 2001—the flag which is part of our history and part of the social fabric of this country. There would be no disrespect to those people who have endeavoured and achieved under that flag. However, if we do become a republic there should be a symbol. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Taking up some of the comments of the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Knott), it is nice and simple to talk in terms of decisions on the basis of flags and republics that suit standard lots of 100 years. But I say that we have a flag that in fact was developed as part of a competition in this country many years ago. To try to change the systems of history because they fit into blocks of 100 years is totally inappropriate.

PARA.TAB: As a country, we need first to recognise our roots and where we have come from. Through multiculturalism we encourage people from other countries to recognise where they have come from and to make sure that their children know their backgrounds because of the importance for their future. As citizens of this country—one of which I am very, very proud indeed—we need to recognise our heritage and where we have come from; we need to recognise that in fact we have a flag that was decided through a competition with 33,000 entrants. I would encourage people to think very seriously about the history of this country before they look at making changes in the short term without a considerable amount of discussion first taking place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, as you are undoubtedly aware, Saturday 5 June is World Environment Day and one of the most significant days on our national calendar. I congratulate the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) for the role that she has taken in promoting this very important initiative, especially with our junior Australians, our school children. I also welcome the initiative of advising the owners of cars whether their particular vehicle is suitable to burn lead-free petrol. I know that this initiative has been well received in my own electorate.

PARA.TAB: The protection of the environment is very important to the residents of my electorate of Paterson. We have the Myall Lakes National Park, the Tomaree National Park and the Barrington Tops wilderness area, to name just a few areas of natural magnificence. But we are also part of the Hunter region where there are major coal mines and where electricity is generated for much of New South Wales. That is what causes me major concern. Coal is being hauled using imported diesel fuel, which not only increases our foreign debt but contributes significantly to the increase of greenhouse gases, particularly in the built-up areas of the Newcastle city region.

I believe that World Environment Day should be an occasion on which we take stock of the inefficient energy consumption in our country. The Hunter region can set an example. We must become leaders in better coal burning technology. We must insist on the electrification—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Today, I seconded a motion by the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) about the visit of the Vietnamese Prime Minister. Later on, about midday, I went out and addressed the crowd of some 1,500 plus. I have about 3,000 people from the Vietnamese community in my electorate. I would like to express the interests and concerns of Dr Van That Njuyen, who is the community leader in my electorate, regarding the aid that Australia is providing to Vietnam.

PARA.TAB: One of the concerns of the electorate is that the aid is not going directly to the people of Vietnam but is going more into military projects. They are missing out in necessary health and education issues. The people in the Cowan community are very concerned about this. They would like some response back from the Government, if it can provide such a response, as to whether funding is being provided. It is a concern to the electorate and the Vietnamese community in the electorate because they do care about their previous homeland and they do care about the human rights that are lacking in that country. I encourage the Government to provide information to the questions that we have put forward and ask that it provide some answers on where the funding is going in Vietnam.

If ever there were a need to bring people together to help them it is now.

PARA.TAB: So yesterday I was dismayed to see the Prime Minister criticising Mr Garland, the leader of the RSL, because he had the temerity to hand the Prime Minister an Australian flag at a reception.
