I believe that the attack by the Prime Minister on Mr Garland for that action is absolutely inexcusable. It really shows that the Prime Minister seems to be wanting to create division in this nation for reasons that I think are becoming more and more apparent. I believe that this Parliament—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to draw attention to the actions of Jeffrey Kennett and the manner in which he is making the residents of Victoria destitute and attacking everybody in Victoria. I have a chart to show that recently he has increased a deficit levy, that is, a $100 poll tax, on every citizen in Victoria. DEBATE.TITLE: PROPOSED CREATION OF A DEPARTMENT OF PARLIAMENTARY INFORMATION AND REPORTING SERVICES

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the advisory committee on the proposed creation of a department of parliamentary information and reporting services. In September 1992 Speaker McLeay and the President of the Senate established the committee, in consultation with the party leaders in both Houses, to provide advice to us on a proposal to create a department of parliamentary information and reporting services to replace the Department of the Parliamentary Library and the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff. Copies of this proposal were circulated to all senators and members and the staffs of both departments prior to the establishment of the advisory committee.

PARA.TAB: The nine committee members came from both the Senate and the House of Representatives, and included representatives of all parties in the Parliament. The committee's terms of reference required an examination of the proposal and an assessment, in light of written and oral comment received, of its likely impact on the provision of services to the Parliament. Senators and members, along with the staffs of both departments, were advised of the committee's terms of reference in mid-October and were invited to make submissions. A number of relevant organisations were contacted and similarly invited to make submissions.

The committee's report consists of a majority report and a dissenting report. The President and I will consider the report over the next few months with a view to advising the Parliament of our response early in the Budget sittings. In tabling the report at this stage I would urge all members to take the opportunity to consider the report and the matter it raises. I would like to thank all committee members for their willingness to assist the Parliament in this way and express mine and the President's appreciation to them for their efforts. Thanks are also extended to those who contributed to the committee's deliberations. I would also like to thank the two officers of the Department of the Parliamentary Library and the Department of Parliamentary Reporting Staff—Mr Hicks and Ms Attrill respectively—who provided the secretariat and support services for the committee.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent the allocation forthwith of a period not less than 45 minutes for questions of both the Prime Minister and other Ministers of this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion.

—What the Government has done today is to reinforce, not only in the eyes of the Opposition but also, I suggest, in the eyes of the Australian public, a number of views that have begun to develop about this Government since its re-election on 13 March. One of those, of course, is an impression of increasing, and indeed unsurpassed, arrogance.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members would remember that only a few weeks ago we were treated to all of those stories about how the Opposition was absolutely shaking in fearful anticipation of the reconvening of Parliament; how when the Parliament came back there was going to be opposition blood flowing out of the House of Representatives; and how the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was again going to do people slowly. In fact, he even had a bit of advice from the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) as to the way in which he ought to respond to those questions.

We were going to be treated to a truly Roman-style slaughter by the Government. We were going to be torn from limb to limb. It would be like the Christians and the lions. That is what we were told. We all came back in fear and trepidation of this unbelievable carnage that was going to befall the unfortunate Liberal and National parties who sit on the opposition benches. That was the warning; we were told that blood was going to flow. But what, in reality, has happened?

Let me tell honourable members that today will represent the 10th day on which the House of Representatives of Australia has sat in a total period of eight months. It is a measure of the Keating Government's respect for the institutions of Australia—and parliament and Question Time are great Australian institutions. This Prime Minister's contempt for the great institutions of the Australian nation is represented by that unassailable statistic that in a total period of eight months—at a time of this country's greatest economic crisis since World War II, with our highest level of unemployment since the years of the Great Depression and when the Australian people are wanting sensible, moderate, intelligent, modest leadership—the House has sat only two weeks.

What do we have from the Prime Minister of Australia? Yesterday we had an arrogant verbal assault on a man simply because he is proud of the Australian flag. What do we have today? We have the Prime Minister's supreme contempt for that great Australian parliamentary institution of Question Time.

What is the Prime Minister scared of? Was he not the bloke who a few weeks ago asked, `What has a fellow got to do to get a question around here'? He was the fellow who stood up and asked, `Why don't you ask me a question?'. What is he doing now? He is shutting the place down. He cannot run the tawdry little line, `Oh, this is a special emergency sitting of the House of Representatives. It is unexpected and unplanned, and therefore on those occasions we do not have a Question Time'.

He cannot run that line on this occasion because these special, unusual, emergency sessions of the House of Representatives have now become a regular feature of parliamentary life under the present Government. Of course the Leader of the House is nodding his head: it has become a regular part of the sitting pattern. We are always brought back for a couple of days in December to clean up legislation and we are brought back for a couple of days in May or June to clean it up before the winter recess.
I remember one of the first emergency sessions I went to was one that Whitlam convened in July of 1975 to deal with the Khemlani affair. That was a special emergency session.

TALK.START.PARA: —It must have been interesting.

—It was a very interesting session; it was a fascinating session. I remember it very well. That was an occasion where we did not have a Question Time because there was a precise, atypical reason for Parliament being convened. But today's sitting of Parliament is part and parcel of the regular pattern of parliamentary sittings under the Keating Government. We on this side of the House—and I believe many hundreds of thousands of Australians—want to know why government members are so gutless that they will not face Question Time.

PARA.TAB: What have those opposite got to hide from? Are they concerned that they will be asked more questions about the Auditor-General's report? Are they frightened that those Ministers in their Government who want to dump the income tax cuts, as reported in the Australian this morning, might say so under questioning? Are they concerned about a Question Time that will expose the further incompetence of their Ministry on such matters as pay television and other communications issues? Why is it that they are so scared of having a Question Time? Why are they junking something that they know, as well as I do, is an inviolate part of the normal pattern of normal sittings in a parliamentary system of government?

The Leader of the House, who is at the table, knows better than most in this Parliament that there are certain conventions and traditions. We can cop in proper circumstances a situation where a government will say, `Look, we can't give you a Question Time', but there can be no earthly justification according to the conventions of this Parliament for the Government to knock off Question Time today.

The only explanation can be found in the attitude of the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister, be it remembered, is the man who, 2 1/2 years ago, stood opposite where I am at the dispatch box and said, `Mr Speaker, Question Time is a courtesy extended by the Executive to the Parliament'. I repeat: `a courtesy extended by the Executive to the Parliament'. That was a measure of just how contemptuous the Prime Minister of this country is towards the great institutions of this country.

The Prime Minister is the great destroyer of institutions in this country; he is the great divider of Australia. He is never happy until he divides one Australian against another. If ever a leader of this country had no natural instinct for unity and healing, it is the present Prime Minister of this country. If ever a Prime Minister of this country believed in setting interest group against interest group, class against class, people of different ethnic origin against people of another different ethnic origin, it is the Prime Minister of this country. He is the greatest trader in division and contempt for the great institutions of this country.

Mr Speaker, surely if you believe in an essential democracy, what earthly right, what earthly objection can anybody possibly have to the proposition that the majority party in the Parliament will respect the right of the minority party in the Parliament for 45 minutes every time the Parliament sits to question the Leader of the Government and to question the Ministers in that government? But not even that fundamental right is respected by this man because he believes that when you have got the numbers you use those brutally, without any care for the rights of those who have not got the numbers. That might be popular in Sussex Street; it might go down well at a meeting of the Right Wing caucus of the ALP, but I do not think it goes down very well in the highways and byways of this country.

I do not think it is redolent of a man who believes in bringing Australia together; I do not think it is redolent of a man who believes in uniting and healing and not dividing and wounding. That is what the Prime Minister of this country represents—he represents the wounding of people and the dividing of people, and unutterable contempt for the great institutions of this country. And he has demonstrated it again today by his jackbooted approach to Question Time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion, Mr Speaker. On this occasion the Government has been caught red-handed. I have two pieces of paper in my hand: the first is the House of Representatives draft daily program for Thursday 27 May, which says: `At 2 p.m.—Questions Without Notice'. Not satisfied with that, the second paper I happen to have is a House of Representatives blue, which says, in absolute terms: `Speaker to call on—Questions without notice'.

PARA.TAB: For the benefit of members of the public, this Government is breaching its own Notice Paper by its cancellation of Question Time today. It is breaching its own Notice Paper circulated to indicate the proceedings of this Parliament. The Government should be ashamed. The Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) should be personally ashamed because two weeks ago on the floor of this House we considered a special adjournment motion. I asked the Leader of the House, as part of that debate, whether there would be two Question Times during the call back of the House of Representatives. He indicated at that time that there would be, if possible, two Question Times.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I didn't. I said it was possible.

—The Leader of the House should go back and look at the Hansard; he will see that it is recorded in Hansard. He has breached his own undertaking to this House, quite apart from breaching the documents which have been circulated to the Parliament.

PARA.TAB: I want to remind the House of a couple of parallels to this situation. Not so long ago in this Parliament a Prime Minister was carved up by his own Caucus. That was Bob Hawke. That was a pretty critical, moving and historical day. It happened during a call back session of the House of Representatives in December 1991, on the very day that those opposite carved up Bob Hawke as Leader of the Australian Labor Party, as Prime Minister of Australia, at their Caucus meeting that afternoon; nevertheless, the Government proceeded with Question Time on that occasion.

That Prime Minister, that man who was less than arrogant compared with the current Prime Minister (Mr Keating), that person who had spent less time in parliament but who awards and acknowledges the convention of parliament far more than most, allowed Question Time to proceed that day as the honourable gentleman that he was whilst those opposite were carving him up behind his very back. During Question Time some of them walked across to him, shook his hand and said, `Bob, I am sorry, I am now switching to the Keating camp', as the countdown went on that very afternoon. The Government allowed Question Time on that red-letter day, but it will not allow Question Time on this the 75th day after the polling events of 13 March.

I accept that the Government won the election on 13 March. But I also accept that the Government has lost the plot on just about every day since 13 March. This arrogant Government is at a stalemate, in hibernation, unable to produce an agenda to deal with the economy, unable to produce an agenda to deal with the unemployed, unable to produce an agenda to deal with the record drought ripping apart so much of country Australia, unable to produce an agenda to deal with the wool industry crisis on a long-term strategic basis and unable to really provide united and cohesive leadership to this great country Australia.

I say, `Shame on the Government for its tactics here today'. Those opposite should hang their heads in absolute shame for having taken this course of action. I know how much it will annoy them, but try one more dimension as to why they did not have Question Time today. Overnight Brigadier Alf Garland put on record the absolutely correct happenings when the Prime Minister came off that stage at that Battle of the Coral Sea function.Dick Cheney was nowhere near the Prime Minister or Brigadier Alf Garland. Dick Cheney was being escorted around by Sir Eric Neal. Yesterday, the Prime Minister effectively misled the House. He in fact bumped into Alf Garland. Alf Garland took a proper action. I must say it is a regrettable occasion when the Prime Minister of this country cannot even support the flag of this country.
So I simply say to the House that it is time that the Government thought again about its arrogance, that it allowed Question Time to resume and that it allowed the MPI to proceed. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me just assist the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer), the previous speaker, on a couple of technical details before dealing with the arguments, in so far as they can be characterised as arguments, put by him and the Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Howard). That the daily program says what it does is what happens whether or not there is to be a Question Time. If he actually talks to the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), whom I know he has a difficulty sitting down and having a civil chat with, he would point out that, whether or not Question Time were going to take place this day, this is what would have appeared there.

PARA.TAB: I am surprised at him because he is his pea. He is the person that he was rather hoping would come through and replace his leader in the fullness of time. He no doubt hoped very much that he himself—indeed, if the National Party had been sensible it would have been the case—would have been in leadership until the time came to pass the baton to himself. He has a very high opinion of him, and that is not an unreasonable assessment on his part. But he should not feel he needs to get in behind his leader on this occasion because his leader, despite his lengthy service in the New South Wales Parliament and his reasonably lengthy service here, has absolutely no understanding of how an agenda paper is prepared.

This is a technical argument. I will go through the technical details of it and answer the points he made. Far from the Government at the last minute racing in and panicking about Question Time—which is the point he is trying to make, I assume, by starting off with that technical point in his statement—that is merely the way all these matters are handled. The normal process of the day is left standing and when it comes to Question Time the Leader of the House stands up and asks that questions be placed on the Notice Paper. That is normally how you suspend Question Time.

TALK.START.PARA: —So it is normal?

—Yes, normal. I will talk a little bit more about the normality of suspending Question Time when I get on to that. The honourable member also alleged that I had promised him a Question Time. In answer to the Opposition's spokesman, let me read exactly what I said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is likely that there will be two Question Times, but I am not absolutely certain about the Thursday. It would depend a bit on the pressure of business from the Senate.

That was the point that I made at that time. I did not give him an undertaking that he was going to have two Question Times. No reasonable reading of that statement would indicate that that would be the case. That is the second technical point the honourable member decided to raise in this regard.

PARA.TAB: Let me now deal with a third point that he decided to put forward. He spoke in glowing and friendly terms of the former Prime Minister of this country—terms that he was unable to manage, I note, when he was in office; nevertheless, he did speak in glowing terms of him earlier. Let me mention what happens at this point of time when we have these two days of sittings at the conclusion of the period when we come back to clean up items of business that have been handled by the Senate for us. On 17 December 1992, that was the case. Of course, he was not in office then. That was last year. It also occurred on 21 June 1991, 21 December 1990 and on 16 June 1989. In fact, ever since the implementation of the Macklin motion in the Senate—even though that has now been removed from the Senate it has been effectively maintained in the conduct of the business of the Senate—we have been put in a position where we have these two clean up days at the end of the process. That Macklin motion has been in place since 1988 or thereabouts.

That is why, somewhat innovatively I suppose, these two days of sittings have grown up. By and large on these two days there is one Question Time. So do not come into this place and say that this is some sort of unprecedented move by the Government disturbed about what the Opposition is doing in this place. Do not think that in the period of office of the Opposition that there were automatic Question Times when the pressure of business in the House dictated that there should not be. Let me go through the record from 1976 to 1982: 79 days sittings in 1976 and 73 days Question Time; 68 days sittings in 1977 and 62 days Question Time; 75 days sittings in 1978 and 68 days Question Time; 68 days sittings in 1979 and 63 days Question Time; 51 days sittings in 1980—that was a vintage year—and 50 days Question Time; 62 days sittings in 1981 and 58 days Question Time; and 53 days sittings in 1982 and 46 days Question Time.

Just because the Opposition has missed out on one day of Question Time in this block of sittings, it need not come into this place thinking that somehow or other the Government is acting in some terribly deceitful, frightened and unprecedented fashion. It is not as though the practice has not been previously adopted in this House by this Government or by those opposite when they happened to be in office and it suited the convenience of the House not to have a Question Time on particular days.We are not dealing with any unprecedented behaviour on the part of the Government. We are dealing with a government operating as it normally does when it has to clean up the legislation at the end of a sitting period and it wants the opportunity to devote its time to the consideration of government business.

There is a difference between what is happening now and what happened in the period to which I referred earlier—when those opposite were in government and we sat without the benefit of Question Time about a tenth of the time—and the difference is this: this debate has been preceded by 4 1/2 hours of private members' business. Even though the Government has basically called back the Parliament to deal with government business—important government business—for the remainder of this day, we did not touch that 4 1/2 hours of time set aside for private members. Throughout that 4 1/2 hours of time it was possible for private members on both sides of the House and for frontbenchers on the other side of the House to raise issues connected with the economy, pay TV, or any feature of government business they would like to raise. In that 4 1/2 hours there was massive opportunity for that to be done.

The Government would now like a few hours for government business in order to clean up material forthcoming from the Senate, and we will assume for ourselves exactly the same privileges that those opposite assumed for themselves when they were in government and had to deal with the exigencies of government legislation from time to time.

There is a further reason for the arrangement, and that is the reason related to the position in the Senate. Ever since the adoption of the Macklin motion, this type of pressure has been exerted even more intensely on the government. Because we have respect for the parliamentary institution, that puts us in a double-squeeze play; once, because we acknowledge the force of the Macklin motion and have a parliamentary sitting that responds to that; and, twice, because we have allowed the time allotted to private members' business to be inviolate.

Nobody could have sat in this chamber for the 10 years that this Government has been in office—nobody could have sat in here—and said that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is fearful of Question Time. Nobody could have sat in this chamber yesterday and said that the Prime Minister was fearful of Question Time. As I recollect the events of yesterday, the Prime Minister stood up and had members of the Opposition so agitated that they went positively feral for the bulk of the afternoon. Far from the Prime Minister being fearful, they were feral. As a result, we did not get all the business done that we might have yesterday, nor as expeditiously as we might have got it done, and that was thanks to them. That was not the Prime Minister being fearful; it was the Prime Minister driving them feral.

We understand that. We understand why they should feel feral about it. They have not asked him a question since he has been on the front bench. They have directed questions to everyone else, but they have been leaving him alone. Why? Because, far from him being frightened by them, they are frightened by him. No questions about the Auditor-General were raised; nothing about the Auditor-General was directed to the Prime Minister—nothing at all. The matter was directed to everybody else but not to the Prime Minister. The Opposition had seven questions to put to the Prime Minister about the Auditor-General but it did not feel like putting them to the Prime Minister yesterday.

There is relief across the Opposition's front bench because they do not have to have another discussion with the Prime Minister about the shenanigans that they have engaged in with the legislation in the Senate. That is too bad for them. This is going to apply. It is quite legitimate for the Government to be doing what it is doing. (Time expired)

That the motion (Mr Howard's) be agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed work recommended by the Public Works Committee involves the construction of a housing development at Palmerston, Northern Territory, for the Defence Housing Authority, the DHA. The development is in line with the Government's commitment to increase Army's presence in the north. It involves the construction of a residential subdivision, incorporating normal infrastructure services as required by the local authorities.

PARA.TAB: When complete, the development will provide for 210 dwellings, incorporating both detached and medium density housing. The Defence Housing Authority proposes construction of around 70 houses for service personnel and their families. The remaining houses will be integrated with the service housing and will be offered for sale to private purchasers.

The project was originally referred to the Public Works Committee on 4 November 1992. However, due to the dissolution of Parliament on 8 February 1993, it was re-referred on 13 May 1993. The committee tabled its favourable report on 24 May 1993, recommending the development at a cost of $18.4 million, of which $4.2 million will be recovered from the sale of the building lots. I thank the committee for its report and commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio The Hon J.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs CROSIO
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Housing development at Flinders View near Ipswich, Qld.

SPEECH.PARA: In January 1988 the Government established the Defence Housing Authority as the first step towards providing a better standard and an increased choice of housing for defence personnel and their families. At this time, the Defence Housing Authority took over responsibility for some 23,000 houses. It now has a current investment program in excess of $270 million per annum.

PARA.TAB: The Defence Housing Authority has entered into a joint venture agreement with Mirvac Projects Pty Ltd to develop a residential subdivision area of 53.8 hectares at Flinders View. The development will provide for 560 residential blocks, incorporating both detached and medium-density housing. The Defence Housing Authority proposes construction of around 180 houses for service personnel and their families. The remaining 360 lots will be integrated with the service housing and will be offered for sale to private purchasers.

The development will replace the existing substandard housing located in the Amberley area. It is in line with the DHA's commitment to improve the standard of accommodation for defence personnel and their families and their commitment to return houses to the States. The project is estimated to cost $31 million, of which $18 million will be recovered from the sale of building lots. Subject to parliamentary approval, construction is planned to commence in May 1993 with completion anticipated for late 1997.
In its report, the committee recommended the construction of a housing development at Flinders View near Ipswich, Queensland, should proceed but raised the following specific issues:

The Committee strongly recommends that Defence Housing Authority provide solar hot water systems in all houses in the Flinders View development. The Committee further recommends that Defence Housing Authority conduct a review of its design criteria to ensure that Service housing is as energy efficient as possible.

The Committee recommends that smoke detectors and earth leakage circuit breakers be installed in all future houses constructed by Defence Housing Authority and, in particular, the Flinders View development.

The authority has indicated that it is required to act commercially, and has registered concerns with the committee about the inclusion of solar hot-water heaters, earth leakage circuit-breakers and smoke detectors in the Flinders View development and in the new houses generally. These units appear to be included in only a very small proportion of homes in the Ipswich area, and the authority is reluctant to make housing decisions that are in advance of the community norm. The authority will, of course, comply with the will of the Parliament, but wishes first to raise with the committee the concerns it holds towards these recommendations of the committee. I would like to thank the committee for its support, and I commend this motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: HMAS Waterhen facilities modernisation at Waverton, NSW.

SPEECH.PARA: HMAS Waterhen is the national mine warfare base for the Royal Australian Navy and is located at Balls Head Bay at Waverton in New South Wales, some four kilometres north of the Sydney central business district. Existing facilities and services date back to late 1940. A number of demountable buildings and transportable containers have been provided over the years to supplement facilities pending modernisation. The age and poor condition of existing facilities necessitate replacement or major specific repair to continue operational activities and to provide for future mine warfare capability.

PARA.TAB: Various proposals have been considered and developed for the Waterhen site over a period of about 10 years. In May 1991 the Defence Force structure programs and policy committee endorsed a high priority for the modernisation of the existing Waterhen mine warfare base. This proposal is to provide purpose-built facilities for the developing Royal Australian Navy mine countermeasure capability. The scope of the work provides for continuous Navy operations throughout the construction implementation period and includes an operations and administration building, supply and diving centres, a workshop building, a transport compound, flammable materials and explosives storage, and all associated site works and services. The estimated total cost of the works is $73 million at December 1992 prices, which equates to an out-turn cost of $79 million.

In its report, the committee recommended that the HMAS Waterhen facilities modernisation at Waverton, New South Wales, should proceed, but raised the following specific issues. The final design of the proposed car park will need to reflect its environmentally sensitive location. Defence should ensure that personnel to be employed at the redeveloped base use public transport to the maximum extent possible. Defence agrees with the conclusions and recommendations of the committee. Construction work on the site is expected to commence by January 1994 and, due to the need to keep the base operational, construction will be staged with completion due by August 1997. I would like to thank the committee for its support, and I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment is of a technical nature to ensure that changes to the broadbanded depreciation provisions do not have an adverse impact on those people who may have lodged their returns in reliance on those provisions before the changes made by the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill. At the same time the amendment ensures that taxpayers who did not take a possible interpretation of those provisions in lodging their returns will not now be able to go back and amend their returns to take that possible interpretation.

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill is the product, once again, of the coalition in general and Senator Watson in particular. We managed, once again, to help the Government clean up its hastily prepared tax legislation.
—Thanks, Al.

—That is not a new or unique happening in this place, as the Assistant Treasurer seems to understand. However, it does serve once again to point out the folly of the way we legislate in this chamber as distinct from what happens in the Senate. I have said it before, and it is equally true in this context: the Senate is the only true legislative chamber in the Parliament. Despite all the denigration that is heaped upon it by those opposite who would like to see it cease to exist, we can be thankful that it does legislate conscientiously. Mostly, that conscientiousness is due to the very fine work of the coalition in opposition.

PARA.TAB: So we have here an amendment which eliminates retrospectivity to which I referred when the Bill was first debated in this chamber. The committee will be aware, of course, that when the Bill first came in it was debated under the guillotine. There was no possible chance that we could go into committee to suggest precise amendments, although I did forewarn that what is happening now would in fact happen; that is, once again the tax legislation, after it had been considered in the Senate, would come back here for amendment. It should not be necessary for that to happen. It is a most inefficient way of going about getting tax legislation through the Parliament.

However, having reached this stage, we obviously support the amendment because, as I said, it was of our making. It serves to eliminate an element of retrospectivity which the coalition finds entirely objectionable—remembering that we have a constant policy, and have had since 1983, of not supporting any measure which imposes a burden retrospectively on Australian taxpayers.

We do not mind the Government deciding to retrospectively legislate if it confers a benefit, an advantage, on taxpayers. But we will neither countenance nor support retrospective measures which impose a burden on taxpayers. So we support the amendment. We congratulate the Government on slowly coming to the realisation that what we foreshadowed in this place during the second reading debate on this legislation was warranted. I suppose it is better late than never.

SPEECH.PARA: The Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Bill 1993 forms part of a package of seven cognate Bills which are being introduced today. Taken together, these Bills will substantially increase the level of prudential protection provided to the superannuation industry, and represent a substantial strengthening of the security of superannuation savings and of the protection of the rights of superannuation fund members. The Bills give effect to the new prudential arrangements for superannuation that were announced on behalf of the Government on 21 October 1992 in the statement of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) Strengthening super security.

PARA.TAB: The Government is introducing this legislation in order to give added protection to superannuation savings and to promote a more efficient superannuation industry, while avoiding the imposition of unreasonable supervisory and compliance costs. The long-term benefits of these carefully balanced measures will significantly outweigh the costs of their implementation.

The Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Bill 1993 provides for effective supervisory arrangements involving direct enforcement powers for the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, enabling effective enforcement of the prudential requirements and obligations placed on funds and trustees; for trustees and investment managers to be made subject to adequate legislative sanctions for the proper performance of their fiduciary responsibilities and increasing their accountability to their members; clear delineation of the basic duties and responsibilities of trustees, and indicating that trustees have primary responsibility for the operation of funds; that trustees and investment managers must be suitable to act as fund trustees and to manage fund moneys respectively; for financial assistance to be provided to funds that have suffered a loss owing to fraudulent conduct or theft; mechanisms for dealing with benefits in employer sponsored funds in respect of members that have left employment or who are lost, and of unclaimed benefits; for equal member and employer representation in large funds; certain disclosure obligations in respect of auditors and actuaries of funds; and rules relating to invitations and offers to subscribe for interests in, and disclosure by, public offer superannuation funds, approved deposit funds and pooled superannuation trusts.

The measures provided for in this Bill complement other measures being introduced today in the companion Occupational Superannuation Standards Amendment Bill 1993, Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Bill 1993, Superannuation (Financial Assistance Funding) Levy Bill 1993, Superannuation (Rolled-Over Benefits) Levy Bill 1993, Superannuation Supervisory Levy Amendment Bill 1993 and Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Consequential Amendments Bill 1993 to strengthen substantially the framework of prudential supervision of the industry.

In developing this Bill, the provisions of the current Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987 relating to prudential compliance standards have been taken up in order to consolidate superannuation industry prudential supervision arrangements. These provisions of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act are being repealed.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Financial Implications

PARA.TAB: The measures contained in this Bill to provide added protection to superannuation savings and to promote a more efficient superannuation industry, together with the arrangements contained in the companion Bills, will result in additional supervisory costs being incurred by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission.

The additional resources needed to give effect to this package of measures have been estimated at $4.831 million in 1993-94, $4.591 million in 1994-95 and $4.631 million in 1995-96. These additional costs will be recovered through the superannuation supervisory levy and the imposition of a new levy on certain superannuation funds and approved deposit funds as provided in the Superannuation (Rolled-Over Benefits) Levy Bill 1993.
I commend the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Bill 1993 to the House and present the related explanatory memorandum.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations of the 36th Parliament entitled Conditional migrant entry: the health rules, together with minutes of proceedings in evidence received by the committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask for leave of the House to make a short statement in connection with the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the immigration area there are certain fundamental entry requirements which apply across all immigration categories. These requirements include health character screening and, for some cases, assessment for settlement purposes. In all these classes, except diplomatic or short-term medical treatment categories, the criteria for entry or stay include a health requirement; and these are very important requirements for ensuring that the Australian public interest is protected.

PARA.TAB: This inquiry by the committee focused on applicants for migration or permanent residence who were refused entry or stay on grounds that they suffer from a prescribed disease, medical condition or a disability. The committee's main brief was to determine whether or not any such applicants could be allowed to enter or remain in Australia on a conditional basis. The committee considered at length the adequacy of the existing health rules as they pertain to migration and consulted with a wide range of community organisations and individuals as well as government agencies responsible for administering the migration program and its health components. In particular, the committee considered the various concerns which were expressed about the lack of flexibility in the existing health rules.

In this report, the committee has made a series of recommendations aimed at clarifying the existing provisions on the health requirement and, in particular, the committee sought to remove the perception that the health rules operate against disabled persons in a discriminatory way. The committee did seek that the Minister exercise a greater judgment in terms of his capacity to make discretionary decisions on waiver of these health conditions in particular cases. The committee was of the view that there ought to be greater flexibility in the way in which the existing system operates. The committee has emphasised the need to take into consideration the likely contribution which individuals and families make to the Australian community as well as their ability to meet the costs of treatment and care arising from the medical condition or disability.

The committee also came to the view that, associated with this latter matter, where discretion was inappropriate for exercise, the Minister might be in a position to impose a charge upon the likely applicant to meet the costs which would be independently ascertained and which would be paid up front to enable people to be able to access Australia if they had come under a category of, say, business entry or family reunion; and, where one person within a family unit suffered a particular disability that might impose a cost, that cost could be quantified, met, and then the person allowed entry to Australia.

These suggestions are very helpful. I am aware of many more cases that have been brought to public notice of individuals where the application of this discretion or the implementation of these particular suggestions would give the department greater flexibility and would enable, I think, the Government to respond in a way which was seen to be more humane and sensible. But I would have to say also that during the course of the inquiry issues related to the management of the health regulations, such as screening for diseases and fraud within the Medicare system, were also brought to the committee's attention.

The committee was very alarmed at the way in which some sections of our health system, and particularly the Medicare arrangements, could be utilised by people who were temporarily in Australia and have no entitlement under the rules to access the system. The committee made a number of suggestions as to the way in which that might be addressed. It is a matter of urgent and pressing need if there is any concern about the cost of health to the Australian community.

I would like to say on behalf of the committee that its thanks go to its subcommittee chairman, the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding), for the amount of work and effort that he put into this inquiry in particular. The committee was particularly grateful also for the committee specialist adviser, Dr Kathryn Cronin, whose valuable advice and assistance was appreciated greatly. Thanks are also due to the committee secretary, Andres Lomp, as well as Clifford Lawson and his predecessor, Cheryl Samuels, as well as Cassandra Paulus, and Dianne Fraser, who were involved with this work.

The implementation of the committee's recommendations in this report will contribute towards a fairer system which is flexible enough to allow conditional entry for some who have a disability or a medical condition, without endangering public health or placing an undue burden upon Australia, its facilities and resources. I commend the report to the Government.

DEBATE.TITLE: CHARTER OF THE UNITED NATIONS AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bilney The Hon G.N.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BILNEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Charter of the United Nations Act 1945. The amendments will allow the Governor-General in Council to make regulations allowing for more comprehensive implementation of Australia's obligations under the United Nations charter than existing legislation permits. They also provide for the imposition of fines for breach of the regulations and allow the Attorney-General to seek injunctions to restrain such a breach.

PARA.TAB: During the Cold War era, the rivalry between the Soviet Union and the Western powers meant that the Security Council was seriously hampered in addressing international crises. The end of the Cold War has seen the council begin to function in the way the founders of the United Nations envisaged it would. It has taken action in regard to a number of the world's most troublesome conflicts—in the Persian Gulf, in Cambodia, in Somalia and in the Balkan conflict, to name some of the most prominent.

In some cases the Security Council has determined that the imposition of economic sanctions is necessary in order to bring to an end a breach of international peace and security. In recent times, such sanctions have been imposed against Iraq, Libya and Yugoslavia—Serbia and Montenegro. A failure by member states of the United Nations to implement those sanctions would inevitably erode respect for and the authority of those decisions. It is therefore important that Australia play its part in strengthening international peace and security by placing itself in a position fully to implement obligations that may arise from measures mandated by Security Council decisions. Further, Australia, as a member of the United Nations, is required as a matter of international law by article 25 of the charter to implement those decisions.

Security Council resolutions imposing sanctions generally decide that `states shall prevent' specified transactions with the offending state. Australia's obligations under such resolutions have previously been implemented by way of the making of regulations under the Customs Act 1901, the Air Navigation Act 1920, the Banking Act 1959 and the Migration Act 1958 and by way of appropriate directions issued by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) to the Governor of the Reserve Bank. Until now, the Australian Government has been able to use those methods to implement, directly or indirectly, sanctions mandated by the United Nations against Iraq and Libya and those mandated against the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia—Serbia and Montenegro—last year. However, recent events have shown that this ad hoc utilisation of legislation designed to be used for other purposes is no longer adequate.

The Security Council adopted resolution 820 on 17 April 1993. The resolution provides for the imposition of strict new sanctions on the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia as from 26 April. The Government has been advised that Australia lacks a legislative basis by which it could ensure compliance with the obligations imposed by the resolution in a number of important respects, for example, the freezing of funds held in Australia by the Government of the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia or companies based in the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia. Nor, under existing legislation, can the Government prevent Australian individuals or firms from providing services—such as accounting services or the installation of computer software—to the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia. The High Court held as long ago as 1973 that the Commonwealth did not have the executive power to cut off the telephone and mail services of the Rhodesian Information Bureau in Sydney, pursuant to a Security Council resolution. A failure to comply with the resolution would place Australia in breach of its international obligations.

In examining its options in relation to the implementation of those sanctions, the Government had regard to the ways in which other countries have done so. The United States, Canada, the United Kingdom and New Zealand have had facilitating legislation in place since the 1940s designed to allow a quick response to an obligation to implement Security Council sanctions. The Canadian and New Zealand legislation are particularly close in their wording to that proposed in the Bill.

The central provision in the Bill before honourable members is the insertion of a new section 6 in the Charter of the United Nations Act 1945. The section will enable the Governor-General in Council to make such regulations as are necessary or convenient for applying measures adopted by the Security Council pursuant to chapter VII of the charter. The Government will thereby be able to implement promptly by way of regulation economic sanctions introduced by the Security Council. As honourable members would be aware, the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances agreed in its 93rd report of December 1992 entitled Scrutiny of regulations imposing United Nations sanctions that it was appropriate that Australia's obligations under Security Council resolutions be implemented by way of regulation. The reason for their conclusion was the need for speed and flexibility in the implementation of the sanctions and the fact that the regulations merely filled out the details of Australia's existing international legal obligation to comply with the sanctions.

The legislation will be based on the external affairs power of the Commonwealth. It is not intended that the legislation replace existing regulations: rather, it will enable the Governor-General in Council to make regulations dealing with situations which fall outside the present regulatory framework.

The legislation will not have the effect of taking away from the Government or the Parliament the power to decide whether the imposition of sanctions against a particular foreign state is in Australia's national interests. It would only be after the making of regulations under the legislation, which would be subject to the normal provisions regarding disallowance in the Parliament, that sanctions would be implemented. It would be open to persons aggrieved by a decision to make particular regulations to claim that their making was neither necessary nor convenient for applying measures adopted by the Security Council.

The other amendments to the Act are directed to ensuring that regulations made under the Act as amended will properly implement Australia's international legal obligations. The proposed section 3 will ensure that regulations implementing Australia's obligations under the charter can be enforced in Australia's external territories. The proposed section 4 makes it clear that the Crown in the right of the Commonwealth and of the States and Territories is bound by any regulations made pursuant to the Act.

Security Council resolutions may provide that member states of the United Nations shall prevent their nationals from engaging in specified conduct. Section 7 will allow the Government to implement such provisions effectively.

The wording of section 8 reflects the fact that the sanctions introduced by regulation are those currently mandated by decisions of the Security Council. Once the Security Council decides that sanctions against a particular state are no longer necessary, it would obviously be inappropriate for the regulations implementing those sanctions to remain in force. Whilst prompt action will be taken to repeal or amend the regulations formally in line with the decision of the Security Council, this section will make it clear that they cease to have effect as soon as the sanctions are lifted by the Security Council. It also makes it clear that the Government may decide, consistent with the position regarding the introduction of sanctions, that the continued implementation of particular sanctions is no longer in the national interest.

Consistent with the position that we are obliged by international law to give effect to decisions of the Security Council, the proposed new sections 9 and 10 are intended to guarantee that regulations implementing sanctions are not read subject to existing legislation nor later found to have been accidentally repealed by subsequent legislative action. Unless such provision is made, Australia could inadvertently find itself in breach of its international legal obligations and be subject to international criticism.

As I stated earlier, the Government has previously implemented, and will continue to implement, United Nations sanctions by way of regulations under the Customs Act, the Air Navigation Act, the Banking Act and the Migration Act. Doing so confers substantial advantages in regard to the administration of the regulations and the imposition of more appropriate penalties than are available under this Bill. This Bill is intended to supplement, not replace, that existing pattern of legislation and regulation. Section 11 makes it clear that regulations made under the legislation referred to above will continue in force.

The Bill includes provisions for penalties for breach of regulations made under it and for the Attorney-General to seek injunctions to prohibit prospective breaches of the regulations. The Bill will come into force on royal assent. I commend the Bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Leave granted for debate to continue forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is facilitating the passage of the Charter of the United Nations Amendment Bill by debating it now rather than seeking to adjourn it to another day. This course is being followed because of the measure of agreement in relation to the Bill and its purpose.

PARA.TAB: It is important to recognise that, unlike many other debates, it is no longer incumbent upon me to try to explain what the legislation is about in order for it to be seen as a coherent discussion; save for me to say that the Bill does authorise changes to the Charter of United Nations Act 1945 which will allow the government of the day to implement fully, by regulation, sanctions agreed to by the United Nations Security Council.

The coalition welcomes a reinvigorated role for the United Nations. With the ending of the Cold War and superpower rivalry as we knew it, we have seen a revival in relevant and useful international organisations. UN members will be expected to assume greater responsibility for maintaining and enhancing global stability. To achieve this goal the United Nations needs to have a structural and bureaucratic system coupled with our own. There is an increasing demand for the UN, in exercising its peacekeeping function, to be able to respond in a prompt and efficient way and there are growing demands upon Australia, many reports of which we have seen of late.

It has been a difficult time for the international community. In this period after the Cold War it has been much more difficult to establish the `new world order' than many of us might have envisaged. Many ethnic, communal, religious and national conflicts seem to have broken out and replaced the former major superpower tensions in a way which has had quite unfortunate repercussions upon individuals. Nevertheless, we have seen a great deal of ingenuity in trying to deal with these situations. There has been a great deal of effort to minimise some of the brutality that has emerged in quite highly complex and difficult situations which are the result of many past international circumstances.

Obviously, the coalition supports the international community, through its international body the United Nations, in doing all that it can to cope with these difficulties. Therefore, we support strongly the commitment of Australia as a part of the United Nations. We have often commended Australia's contribution to the peacekeeping forces throughout the world. It is timely to note that Australian military forces have made a very worthwhile contribution in Somalia, from which they are just now returning.

I have personally witnessed the work of our defence forces in Cambodia. My parliamentary colleagues the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Snowdon) are both presently in Cambodia monitoring the process by which elections are being undertaken. Hopefully, the outcome of those elections will restore some element of stability to that country. No matter what we think about the process and the effectiveness of the plans of many individuals who have tried to bring about a peaceful outcome, it is important to recognise Australia's contribution to that peacekeeping function through its defence forces.

I visited Cambodia last year and met with some of the defence personnel who were stationed not only in Phnom Penh but also in many quite difficult locations. I travelled north-west to Kompong Thom where people have been injured and shot and where there has been a contest between the Khmer Rouge and the forces of the state of Cambodia. In the middle of that difficult situation Australian forces are playing a part in ensuring successful communication between the combatants.

We in the Opposition accept that the international community has a number of different tools at its disposal to try to bring conflict to an end. Inducements can be offered and diplomacy can play a part; but in some circumstances the international community needs to apply pressure in the form of arms embargos, economic sanctions and the placement of forces, as we saw in relation to Somalia. Ultimately, that pressure might involve a substantial military force, as we saw in the case of Iraq. It is important that the Government of Australia have a reasonably free hand in meeting our international responsibilities in that regard.

In that sense, we support the provisions which move us beyond the old regulations in the Customs Act, the Air Navigation Act, the Banking Act and the Migration Act, which have served us well but no longer prove adequate to enable a new sanctions regime to be fully implemented. This Bill is also intended to ensure that sanctions-related regulations are enforced in our external territories, that the States and Territories are also bound and that the Government has the power to prevent Australian nationals from engaging in conduct prohibited under its sanctions obligations. They are an important part of a total regime if it is to be put in place. I notice that the legislation which operates in other countries is similar to this legal regime that the Government has in mind to implement through this legislation.

The Bill has come about largely in response to the recent developments to which Australia has found itself unable to respond in a timely fashion. On 17 April 1993 the UN Security Council adopted resolution 820, which provides for the implementation of reinforced sanctions against the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia—that is Serbia and Montenegro—as from 26 April. If we are to respond to those provisions it is important that this regime be in place. That is part of the reason why we are facilitating discussion in relation to this legislation. I make the point also that its broader application will enable the Government to respond rapidly and with flexibility in the implementation of other possible sanctions regimes. That, I think, makes it a desirable objective.

The Bill will not only close gaps in the sanctions regime that has previously applied using the Acts that have been mentioned by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) but also allow future government to move rapidly on sanctions once they are imposed. This is an increasingly important consideration as national economies are even more interlocked than in the past; also in an environment of instantaneous international economic transactions.

I welcomed the Minister's emphasis that this legislation had been the subject of comment by the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances which, in its 93rd report, Scrutiny of regulations imposing United Nations sanctions, agreed that it was appropriate that Australia's obligations be implemented by way of regulation. The explanatory memorandum to this Bill quite properly emphasises:

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation will not have the effect of taking away from the Government the power to decide whether the imposition of sanctions against a particular foreign state is in Australia's national interests. It would only be after the making of regulations under the legislation, which would be subject to the normal provisions regarding disallowance in the Parliament, that sanctions would be implemented. It would be open to persons aggrieved by a decision to make particular regulations to claim that their making was neither necessary nor convenient for applying measures adopted by the Security Council.

In the wisdom of the Parliament, if there were not a unanimity of view it would be possible for either House—the Senate or the House of Representatives—to deny those regulations. This may impose a greater obligation upon us as members of parliament to scrutinise what goes on here.

PARA.TAB: In that sense, I welcome the advice as to disallowable instruments that is now provided on a regular basis by the Clerks. It enables us to monitor accurately the timetable which permits the moving of a motion to disallow a regulation. In that sense, it enhances our skills in being able to fulfil our duties effectively where these matters are involved and there is frequent recourse to regulations because of the need for flexibility and speed.

It is important that the Parliament itself maintain an ongoing interest in these matters and that the people who have a particular concern—and numbers of people do—about the scope and activities of the United Nations are aware that there is this potential to be able to move in relation to these matters should such a situation arise. I am sure, in the knowledge of the importance of these matters and Australia's reputation, that the Government will move in this area only with due diligence and after appropriate inquiry. But the assurance that these matters cannot be dealt with without public scrutiny is an important one—one which I note the regime permits to be maintained.

As I have foreshadowed, the Opposition does not oppose the passage of this legislation. It is important, in view of the need to implement resolution 820, that we are able to act on these matters promptly. Because of what has been happening in the former republic of Yugoslavia, I have an ongoing concern that Australia is playing as full a role as possible. I do not think any Australian would not be moved by the events that have taken place in that tragic group of countries and not want to see Australia playing a very positive role—albeit whether one considers that the steps taken by the international community to date have been either adequate or appropriate. I commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to join with my colleagues on both sides of the House in supporting the Charter of the United Nations Amendment Bill 1993 and recommending it to the House. The purpose of this Bill is basically to tidy up and tighten the capacity of the Australian Government to implement sanctions decisions that are made by the United Nations Security Council.

PARA.TAB: This Bill amends the Charter of the United Nations Act 1945 and, through this amendment, gives the Government power to regulate for the implementation of sanctions. At the moment the Government has the power to implement sanctions, but it must utilise a range of other legislation—the Customs Act, the Air Navigation Act, the Banking Act and the Migration Act—and within those regulations there are still loopholes in areas of commerce, industry or business dealings between Australia and other nations that cannot be fully covered. Through the amendments in this legislation, we are able to tighten that up. Of course, it does not replace the regulatory process of those other Bills; it is designed to complement them.

I think it is very important that we record in this House some comment about the United Nations and Australia's involvement in it. Australia has had a very long and proud history of involvement not only in the work of the United Nations but also in its formation. It was the Labor foreign Minister—or External Affairs Minister as I think he was called at that time—Dr Evatt who played a very important role in the formation of the United Nations and in fact was the first President of the General Assembly. I think he earned that honour because of the important role that Australia had taken in establishing the United Nations and getting it up and running in the first place.

Ever since that very first meeting and very first General Assembly, Australia has taken a strong and active role in the United Nations in implementing our foreign policy principles, in our work and our dealings with countries around the world, and in the work that we have sought to have the United Nations achieve. But it is fair to say that the United Nations has reached its full potential only in the last four to five years.

When I was preparing to make my few comments on this Bill today, I asked the Parliamentary Library to give me some details about when the United Nations had previously utilised economic sanctions so that I could get a picture of how often we have done this and what need there would be in future. It was interesting to note that in its first 45 years the United Nations adopted measures to impose sanctions only twice, and those two instances were in relation to Rhodesia and South Africa. Of course, in South Africa a lot of those measures are still in place.

This partly reflected the reality of the world political situation at that time where we had fallen between two global entities which were competing with each other. Whenever the concept of sanctions came up, it usually involved one side's ally or the other side's ally. The United Nations Security Council was powerless to act because one of the countries in the Security Council whose ally was the subject of the possibility of sanctions would always veto that move. The Security Council virtually became a powerless instrument in enacting any real political pressure on countries that were perpetrating crimes against other neighbouring countries or against humanity in some form or another.

It is only where those global interests of either the East or the West were not being directly challenged that the United Nations was able to implement some form of sanctions. In many cases they were reasonably limited. Sanctions were imposed on Rhodesia by Security Council resolution 232 on 12 December 1966 and called on all member states to break economic relations with Rhodesia. Although those sanctions were imposed, it would be fair to say that a lot of countries within the world community and member states of the United Nations did not implement those sanctions.

It is also interesting to note that at the time Rhodesian sanctions were implemented the Australian Government did not approve of the policy of imposing sanctions. The Liberal Government at that time and its Attorney-General, Mr Nigel Bowen, stated in 1966 that `very many Ministers found sanctions distasteful'—his party did not support the concept of economic sanctions—but that Australia would adhere to the sanctions once they had been formally adopted by the UN. It is important to note that although there were political differences about the concept of economic sanctions, Australian governments of both persuasions have implemented decisions of the United Nations—even though they might not necessarily have agreed with them—because they felt they were decisions of the international community and they should abide by them.

The second instance of the adoption of sanctions by the UN Security Council relates to South Africa. Resolution 418 of 4 November 1977 imposed an arms embargo on South Africa which is still in operation today. The Security Council determined that the acquisition of arms by South Africa constituted a `threat to the maintenance of international peace and security'. In 1977 the Australian Government and the Opposition fully supported those measures. After that there was quite a gap. Since that time there have been four further instances where decisions have been made by the Security Council to introduce economic sanctions. Firstly, sanctions were imposed on Iraq because of its invasion of Kuwait in 1990; secondly, resolution 748 of 15 April 1992 of the UN Security Council imposed an air and arms embargo against Libya because of the refusal by Libya to cooperate in the attempted trial of two men in relation to the bombing of a Pan American Airlines aircraft over Lockerbie in Scotland; thirdly, in Yugoslavia economic sanctions and arms embargoes have been imposed on various components of the former Yugoslavia in an attempt to bring about peace—unfortunately, that has still not succeeded, and most recently a hardening of those economic sanctions has been implemented; and, fourthly, sanctions were imposed on Cambodia and the Khmer Rouge in an attempt to ensure that all parties to the dispute and the civil war in Cambodia abided by the United Nations peace agreement with Cambodia. At that time Australia again was a strong supporter.

When talking about the use of sanctions as a general principle, it has to be said that they are a very important instrument. If the United Nations Security Council has no power to impose trade sanctions or arms embargoes, then it is a toothless tiger. No matter how much chest beating and pontificating might occur in the General Assembly or the Security Council of the United Nations, if there is no weapon of a non-military nature to force countries to carry out the wishes of the international community, then we may as well not have a United Nations.

That is why I support very strongly the reforms embodied in this legislation which will improve Australia's capacity to respond to decisions of the UN Security Council to impose sanctions. Sanctions are a weapon that the United Nations can use to force countries which are not abiding by international opinion, not observing the rule of international law, and not observing the rights of peoples to live in peace and freedom without being terrorised by their neighbouring states. If we do not have powers to implement that rule of law, then rogue nations will be able to get away with what they like and the international community will have very little means of controlling them.

What is very important is the fact that there needs to be a lot more consistency in the application of these economic sanctions. There are two other places on this earth where member nations of the United Nations have engaged in invasion, takeover and military suppression of other peoples, of neighbouring states, yet they have not been the subject of economic sanctions or arms embargoes by the United Nations Security Council. I believe most firmly that, if the United Nations is to maintain any form of credibility in the implementation of its work and in the use of economic sanctions, it has to impose them equally on all member countries which engage in those types of breaches of international law.

This morning there was a private member's motion on East Timor. In that debate I made some comments about the actions of Indonesia and the fact that Indonesia perpetrated a military invasion on East Timor and took over that territory against the wishes of the people of East Timor. Since that time, it has imposed a reign of terror on the people of East Timor to maintain its military control over that territory. Yet there has not been one move in the United Nations to impose any form of economic sanctions against Indonesia. There have been some 12 resolutions of the UN General Assembly and of the UN Security Council telling Indonesia that it should get out of East Timor, that East Timor does not belong to it, and that it should stop its persecution and harassment of the people of East Timor. Yet there has been no effort by the UN Security Council to follow up those resolutions with any sort of firm action.

I repeat the call I made this morning on East Timor: it is now time for the UN Security Council to impose sanctions on Indonesia if it is not prepared to abide by the decisions of the UN Security Council and the UN General Assembly. The people of East Timor do not wish to be part of Indonesia; they never have and they never will. They want the right of self-determination. The UN espouses the principle of self-determination as one of its founding principles and yet, in the case of East Timor, it is prepared to ignore it. Unfortunately, our country ignores that fundamental principle, which is a plank of our foreign policy and the foundation of all our dealings with other countries all around the world. But when it comes to countries in our near north, we allow them to get away with what they like. I think we face an unreasonable and unrealistic situation. It brings the UN into disrepute in that it is not prepared to implement fully the powers it has.

Another issue which is often debated in this House is China's takeover of Tibet. In this instance a large superpower has taken over a small, defenceless country and it continues to persecute and rigidly control those people.

Again, China has not faced economic sanctions and arms embargos against its actions on the takeover of Tibet. The people of Tibet still suffer today under the hegemony of Chinese military rule in that country. So there are two instances which need addressing. If the United Nations with all its new power—with the new world order, which I do not believe exists; with this concept that is constantly being floated of a new world order—wants to maintain any sort of credibility around the world, it needs to start looking back on those other instances where it has failed to take action.

I urge the Australian Government to raise these matters in the UN Security Council and in the UN General Assembly. If we do have any sort of commitment to the United Nations charter and the principles under which the United Nations was founded, we have a responsibility to act on those two places as well as all the other places where we have rightly sought involvement by the United Nations in places such as Cambodia, Iraq, Somalia and those other places.

This is an important Bill which strengthens Australia's capacity to respond to economic sanctions when they are decided. However, I urge the Australian Government to take up the challenge to also exercise its authority in the other areas around the world where the UN has failed to meet its true obligations to protect the interests of people who have been the subject of military takeover and invasion by larger countries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting to hear the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) talk about the Government's response to the situation in East Timor. As a member of the Government, he can hopefully exert more influence on his colleagues to ensure that Australia's response is strengthened. I happen to agree with him about the situation in East Timor. However, the Government and, I ought to say in fairness, the Opposition, particularly some of the older members who were here in about 1975, find it all so difficult. They do not want to offend our great northern trading partner, Indonesia, which—dare I suggest—could down the track somewhere be a military threat. We do not want to get on the wrong side of Indonesia.

PARA.TAB: So, as the honourable member for Moreton observes, we have done nothing. But he is now in the Government; so when he talks euphemistically about `our country's response', surely he needs to put pressure on the Australian government of the day to take Indonesia to task and go through the United Nations channels to ensure that its resolutions, as he rightly says, that have been moved in respect of East Timor are properly implemented. But, of course, as he mentions, they have not been.

The honourable member broadly canvassed the issues of economic sanctions, and that to a large extent is what the Charter of the United Nations Amendment Bill is all about. The honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock) indicated the Opposition's total support for this legislation. But we must wonder how effective economic sanctions are, particularly in the short term. For instance, we saw economic sanctions imposed on South Africa for many years. The effectiveness of those sanctions on that particular country was always controversial and debatable. In the context of this Bill, the immediate trigger for this legislation is to allow a better response to United Nations resolutions. When talking about the United Nations response in the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, we must also wonder how effective economic sanctions have been there.

One must observe that those sanctions have been notoriously unsuccessful in preventing the mutual genocide in that country. We would all be aware of that, having seen so much over the past 12 months of what is actually happening in the former Yugoslavia. So I do not think that economic sanctions work effectively anywhere in the short term. Of course, those sanctions were not given a chance to work in Iraq because they were promptly followed up with a strong military response—at the time I am sure the absolutely correct response. That was certainly our position in this Parliament.

Nevertheless, the immediate intention of the Bill is to allow for the full implementation of Australia's obligations under the United Nations Security Council resolution 820, which provides for the implementation of reinforced sanctions against Serbia and Montenegro. I have taken quite an interest in the situation in the former Yugoslavia. I have now spoken in this Parliament on two or three occasions on that situation. In fact, I have a notice of motion today on the Notice Paper in respect of the situation in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

TALK.START.PARA: —We know of your concern and we appreciate it.
—Thank you. That notice of motion says, in part, that this Parliament:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . expresses its profound regret to the people of Bosnia and Herzegovina for the suffering and misery they have experienced;

It goes on from there. Ironically, in so far as this legislation will help the people of Bosnia and Herzegovina, it is almost obsolete at this point of time. It is almost all over for the people of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Western efforts, United Nations efforts, to halt Serbian aggression in Bosnia and Herzegovina have failed comprehensively. Worse now, it appears that territorial gains made through aggression by the Serbians in particular and, to some extent, the Croatians will actually now be legitimised.
