So much for the new world order. The honourable member for Moreton expressed his doubts about how effective it is.

PARA.TAB: We saw the world react to the invasion of Kuwait, but Kuwait had oil. There is no oil in Bosnia and Herzegovina. I have said it in this Parliament and I will say it again: six months ago the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) and I were in Sarajevo and spoke with the legitimate Government of Bosnia. That Government made the point to us, `If we had oil here or something that was important to the Western world, the response would have been immediate and strong'. In respect of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the world has stood by and, once again, to use the description of the honourable member for Moreton, the United Nations has shown itself to be a toothless tiger.

The European response was one of hand wringing. We know that history makes it very difficult—Europe is divided, the Russians, Serbs and Greeks are allies and the Croats and the Germans are allied. We are not quite sure where the British are from day to day except for Baroness Thatcher who was quite categorical in her criticism of the response of the European Community to the situation.

Essentially, the United Nations failed to act. President Clinton made the right noises before he was elected. After he was elected, one day he decided he would do something; the next day he decided he would not do anything. Finally, we end up with some sort of agreement between Russia, the United States and Europe, which effectively rewards aggression. For the reasons I outlined, that aggression was not rewarded in Kuwait. When it is all boiled down, they are very simple reasons. I am not trying to oversimplify the situation. I am aware of the history. The member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) will probably get up and give us a history lesson on that. I am sure he is aware of it. The Balkans is a difficult and complex issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —This will be a different one.

—We look forward to that. The First World War started in Sarajevo. Nothing is new. The tribal differences there have existed for years and, unfortunately, they will be there for a long time to come. Despite the new world order, the world has stood by in Bosnia and acquiesced to mutual genocide. In Sarajevo the world has stood by while people who have been neighbours for years have killed each other. Australia is a long way away. We have ethnic communities from those parts of the world, which no doubt complicates our response. Nevertheless, Australia is an active and respected member of the United Nations and so we also, perhaps to some lesser extent, are culpable for what has happened there.

PARA.TAB: Having watched what has gone on in Sarajevo, without talking about other parts of Bosnia, one wonders whether there was ever an intention to occupy Sarajevo. It has been surrounded for months by heavy artillery, mortars and tanks. I could only speculate now, having seen and watched what is happening there for so long, that there is no intention to occupy but merely to terrorise and kill. I remind this House, as I have done in the past, that 75 per cent of the casualties there are innocent women and children. Artillery shells do not discriminate. We have seen plenty of evidence of that.

The latest US-Russian-European plan is totally unacceptable to the Muslims in Bosnia. Let us not forget the Muslims are the majority ethnic group in Bosnia and Herzegovina—around 40 per cent of the population. The Government was legitimately elected, the borders of Bosnia and Herzegovina have been internationally recognised; yet we have stood by and watched two-thirds of it now be occupied by an intruder, largely aided and abetted from outside—a civil war but aided and abetted from outside. Now it appears that ethnic cleansing, as it is called, has been—

TALK.START.PARA: —That makes it sound almost as though it is legitimate.

—They were the words I was going to use. It has been legitimised or condoned. That is what has happened on a large scale in Bosnia. We have stood by and acquiesced; we have condoned and legitimised ethnic cleansing. If that is not a disgusting concept or scenario for us to grasp, I cannot imagine what is. Naturally, the Serbians there have embraced the new plan. President Milosevic in Serbia and Mr Karadzic, the leader of the Serbians in Bosnia, have embraced the plan. Why would they not? It confirms, in effect, all of their territorial gains. It concedes that the territory that they have taken by force will be theirs in some form. One wonders where next Serbia's territorial ambitions will extend—Kosevo, Macedonia—
—Ireland.

—We will talk about the situation in Ireland another day. There is another hand wringing exercise, another almost apparently insoluble problem. How far will ethnic cleansing go within the broader borders of the former Yugoslavia?

PARA.TAB: One bit of good news that has come out of the United Nations in the last few days is the decision of the United Nations to establish a war crimes tribunal to investigate the atrocities and rape that have occurred in the former Yugoslavia. I am encouraged that at least that has been a legitimate response of the United Nations. I was pleased to see that no-one will be exempt from prosecution. If the United Nations pursues those prosecutions, I am quite certain that many people will ultimately be brought to justice for what has happened in that country.

We need to grasp the United Nations, we need to assist its processes, and this legislation enables Australia to be better prepared to respond by extending the Government's power to enforce sanctions by regulation. We can only hope that it will be more and more effective. As I have said, we despair at its response in respect of the former Yugoslavia and, as the honourable member for Moreton said, in a number of other areas as well, but we must remain hopeful.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The obvious accord that exists on both sides of this House gives a lie to the view often expressed that all we do here is argue. I might well say that the contribution of the member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock), in its pompous, sanctimonious posturing, proves that plenty of debate on both sides of this House is done with the absolute authority and assurance that only a long distance can lend.

PARA.TAB: I rise to support the Charter of the United Nations Amendment Bill, but I do so with some concern. I want to raise a few of what I see to be the problems. I am concerned that the central contradiction at the heart of this Bill is the conflict between supposed international legal obligations and the claim that we are free to disregard such obligations when they are deemed not to be in our own interests. A legal obligation means something that is binding by law and if breached is subject to some sort of sanction. If Australia was really legally obliged to act on resolutions of the UN Security Council or strictly according to United Nations conventions, then failure to do so would enact a legally enforceable penalty.

The Government and others who continually cite our supposed international obligations want to have it both ways. On the one hand, they say that we are internationally obliged to act in a certain way as though there is no choice in the matter. On the other hand, they claim that we have the freedom to ignore these obligations when they are not deemed in our interest. The Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Faulkner), on behalf of the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Evans, said in his second reading speech that Australia, as a member of the United Nations, is required as a matter of international law by article 25 of the charter to implement the decisions of the UN Security Council.

The second reading also states that, given the supposedly imperfect local mechanisms which exist to bring about Australian compliance with a Security Council resolution, this amendment is necessary. Without it we would find ourselves unable to meet our international obligations. With it we would have the speed and flexibility needed to comply. Once again this legislation turns upon the use of the Government's external affairs power. However, the second reading speech also states:

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation will not have the effect of taking away from the Government or the Parliament the power to decide whether the imposition of sanctions against a particular foreign state is in Australia's national interests.

Surely, if Senator Evans places so much stress upon our international legal obligations, such an outlandish expression as national sovereignty would be a breach of those obligations, no matter what our reasons. By giving the supposedly international legal obligations such high status, how could we safely and independently express our national sovereignty in such instances? Surely the Government, by its constant harping about international obligations, by its constant use of the term as a sort of overriding moral authority, has placed this country in an invidious position and compromised our national sovereignty.

PARA.TAB: If we were so bold as to refuse to comply with the United Nations Security Council resolution, the Security Council itself could accuse us of a flagrant breach of obligations our own Government has appealed to in the highest and most moralistic terms. So, by such continual appeals to international obligations, our own freedom to act as a sovereign nation in such matters is compromised. Also by a lap-dog willingness to follow a body dominated by the United States, we risk embroiling ourselves in overseas ventures against our better interests. We also, by tagging along with the UN whenever it decides to intervene in the affairs of sovereign nations, allow ourselves no defence should the UN ever decide to intervene in our own. There are more than enough internationalists in Australia virtually inviting foreign intervention already for our supposed breaches of international obligations.

Let us examine some of the UN interventions. The Gulf War intervention was led by the US for economic reasons. The Somali intervention was for supposedly humanitarian reasons, although US oil companies hold exploration rights to two-thirds of the country. The media got a lot of United Nations arranged photo opportunities in Somalia—but what happens once the troops leave? In spite of this, the disaster will unfold again. We have in the past got off lightly with our interventions.

But what if the United Nations led Security Council should decide to send ground troops into a dispute involving heavy fighting? Do we follow them? Surely our international obligations, according to the constant moralistic use of the term by the Government, would demand it in spite of any reservations we might have to the contrary. The media would urge us to do so and would be the first to condemn us when the body bags started coming back.

If our leadership was truly nationalistic, as it is claimed, it would be continually emphasising our national sovereignty; that we act in such and such a way because we have a right to do so and we as a nation insist upon it; that we intervene in the domestic affairs of a foreign country only with the utmost circumspection and not at the whim of other governments.

Where we act in international accord with other nations we do so without in any way ceding our national sovereignty. We reserve the right to act according to our national interests, no matter what international documents we have signed or no matter what the Security Council has decreed. It may be that we most often find ourselves in agreement with the United Nations resolutions, but we must always make it firmly understood that we will not be intimidated by supposedly international legal obligations.

Not only is this bad for local morale; we supposedly have to follow where the bigger nations lead, as though we were hardly a nation at all—and that could lead to unforeseen circumstances. One day we may find ourselves at the end of such intervention, especially given the fact that so many supposed humanitarians and others seem to want that. No matter what the Government and others, for reasons of their own, might say, we are a sovereign nation. We have no obligation to either follow blindly the resolutions of the United Nations Security Council or to enact legislation based upon United Nations conventions, even where we have signed these conventions.

I note that the new Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) is likely to introduce racial vilification legislation in the spring session of the Parliament. This legislation is also justified in terms of our international obligation in supposedly meeting the requirements of the United Nations convention. These days Gough Whitlam is taking credit for laying the foundations of this legislation and, apparently, he cannot wait for it to be enacted. He claims that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has a mandate for the legislation. The first I heard about Gough saying all this was on a Melbourne radio program on April Fools' Day. How appropriate, for there is no fool like an old fool. He repeated all this recently. So Gough claims both a local mandate and an obligation under the United Nations convention as reasons why legislation should be passed. This is, of course, a double misrepresentation.

There is no obligation at all, internationally or otherwise, for Australia to pass such legislation. Even Lionel Murphy—a strong United Nations man—was not in favour of just transcribing a United Nations convention into local law. His own Bill of rights, which, as Attorney-General, he attempted unsuccessfully to have passed, was inspired by the United Nations covenant. Nevertheless, he found that the covenant, as it stood, would `greatly reduce the contents of the rights guaranteed by the articles'. These rights included free speech. In other words, where highly priced freedoms would be compromised by our adoption of a United Nations model, it was the United Nations model that would have to give way.

As I said, those comments were made by Lionel Murphy, who was strongly in favour of following the lead of United Nations agreements. He is not one of my favourites, but he clearly had a strong commitment to freedom of speech. It is unfortunate that those who regard him as an inspiration and who are so determined to have this Bill do not have a similar commitment.

Apart from all this, there is a great deal of misinformation and disinformation about what our international obligations really are. It is commonplace for internationalists, when it suits their purposes, to claim that we are in breach of international obligations. The Human Rights Commissioner, Brian Burdekin, claimed on ABC television's 7.30 Report, and at other times, that Australia had breached its United Nations obligations in the processing of the Cambodian boat people. This was a blatant untruth, and Brian Burdekin, of course, knows it.

Although the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission gains its moral legitimacy from a United Nations instrument, Mr Burdekin is obviously prepared to misrepresent the position of the United Nations when it suits him. It is not mentioned that lawyers representing the boat people were largely responsible for the delays in processing. In fact, the relevant United Nations authority is happy with Australia's processing of refugees. It is only people such as Burdekin, and people involved in the immigration industry and the churches, who make such claims. In other words, it is locals, often paid by the public of Australia, who misrepresent the position of the United Nations in order to put pressure on their own government by using the very rhetoric of the government. That is one clear example of how the Government's continual harping about `international obligations' can be used against it.

This is done, of course, to exert pressure domestically, but by their actions those people continually invite international disapproval of their own country. In the past, church leaders in particular have made similar claims to those of Burdekin. The Catholic Archbishop of Perth, Bishop Hickey, has done so. The Anglican Archbishop of Perth, Dr Peter Carnley, in his 1992 Easter Day message, called the treatment of the refugee Cambodians `one of the most shameful events' in the history of the country.

One reporter actually bothered to seek a response from an appropriate United Nations representative to these claims. As reported in the 20 June edition of the Age, the head of the Bangkok office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees stated that Australia's record of processing asylum applications was well balanced, fair and deservedly reputable. I defy Brian Burdekin to get a UN refugee official to state that Australia is in breach of United Nations conditions in its treatment of refugees. If the ABC were doing its job, instead of acting as a propaganda unit, it would have inquired of the United Nations itself rather than taking the word of Brian Burdekin for it.

The Anglican Archbishop of Adelaide, the Rev. Ian George, also claimed on 24 May at a BIR immigration conference that the message being sent to our neighbours about our treatment of asylum seekers is one portraying us as a selfish society. It infuriates me when people as privileged as he, bishop or not, accuse Australia of being selfish in immigration or refugee matters. Australia has one of the highest per capita intakes of refugees in the world and has been traditionally generous towards them. Now that it has decided to crack down on obvious refugee rorts, people such as the archbishop accuse Australia of being selfish. He claimed that our immigration policy was sending confusing messages to our neighbours. What rot! We are indeed sending confusing messages to our neighbours. Principally, they are that we—or, at least, our leaders—do not know who we are.

The Prime Minister has constantly claimed that Australia is part of Asia but, after the Asians themselves ridiculed the idea, he backed off slightly and now claims that Australia is not an Asian country but a country in Asia. Increasingly, he will avoid saying that Australia is part of Asia and will say that it is a country in the Asia-Pacific region. No doubt, he will claim in the long run that that is what he has always said.

Our bishops and others want to play the good Samaritan as long as others bear the cost. How little concern they have for local middle- and low-income earners. The real good Samaritan took financial responsibility for his good deed, unlike the great majority of our so-called humanitarians.

Another person to use the international obligation argument is the well-known humanitarian, Hugh Morgan of Western Mining Corporation. He called for an immigration intake of 500,000 per annum, which—to quote from the July 1992 edition of Australian Business Monthly magazine—he said would:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . satisfy growing international criticism that we have too much land for too few people. The alternative is damaging interference in our national affairs as increasingly interventionist bodies like the United Nations pressure Australia to increase its migrant intake, with the aim of creating a target population exceeding 100 million.

People such as Hugh Morgan, and his friends in the churches and human rights lobby, seem determined to provoke such a scenario. The pressure is coming from them, invoking a presently mythical standard of international obligation and international pressure which may very well become real, particularly if they continue to invite it. Morgan, the bishops and Burdekin all have one thing in common: a very comfortable lifestyle, in contrast with that of the bulk of ordinary Australians who bear the consequences and the cost of increased immigration and who want immigration cut.

PARA.TAB: Both the humanitarians and people like Morgan effectively promote open borders. Among other things, Morgan is president of the Australia-German Chamber of Commerce. He was at the same October meeting in Dusseldorf as German industrialist Dr Eckhard Rohkamm, who told the meeting, as reported on 28 October in the Australian Financial Review—no doubt at Hugh Morgan's prompting—that Australia needed to import cheap Asian labour. He told the conference:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia must be prepared to open up its borders and not live in splendid isolation.

He then went on to boast of how German industrialists were subcontracting work to surrounding central European nations, where wages are about 15 per cent of those in Germany—all this in spite of the high unemployment in Germany. He said that much lower wages were needed to make Australia an attractive place for investment.

PARA.TAB: It is extraordinary, is it not, how the multinational industrialists are as high-minded as the multiculturalist churches and human rights commissioners? It is extraordinary that their opinions coincide and that they use the same rhetoric. It is interesting to note that the New Zealand Foreign Minister has said that there cannot be free trade without free movement of labour, and that both our Prime Minister and New Zealand's Prime Minister Bolger see the Australia-New Zealand arrangement as a model to be extended into the Asian region to our north. This would virtually lead to open borders and would send local wages and working conditions through the floor. Is this part of Australia's international obligations to big business?

It seems that the dictates of international economic interests are increasingly imposing themselves upon the sovereignty of nations. There was a very interesting article in the May edition of Charter, the journal of the Institute of Chartered Accountants in Australia. The article, entitled `The world's biggest bank', encouraged Australian accountants and law firms to pursue opportunities as foreign consultants to the World Bank. Increasingly, the World Bank, which mainly lends to Third World countries, has been responsible for fundamental overhauls of the institutions of countries in order to make them safe for international investment.

SPEECH.PARA: The article in Charter quoted Austrade's resident trade commissioner at the World Bank, Bruce Coyne, who acts as an agent for Australian firms seeking work with the bank. He states that, in order to get investments, countries such as Venezuela have handed over their judicial system for reform to the consultants of the World Bank. Coyne said:

On the other hand, the bank may be financing a transport project in the Philippines that involves development or restructuring of the local authority. This could lead to the bank bringing in accounting and management experts skilled in the transport sector, together with a legal expert to, for example, draw up new laws on tariffs.
After quoting Coyne, the author of the article continued:
Mountain-moving stuff, you might think, and you'd be right. It happens frequently when the World Bank is involved in a project: if local laws or procedures get in the way, change them.

That is precisely what is stated, `If local laws or procedures get in the way, change them'. It does not occur to the writer of the article, who makes this statement with approval, that the interests and wishes of the citizens of the countries concerned may not coincide with the wishes of consultants to multinational investors.

PARA.TAB: The statement is made, however, that such projects are in the `national interest' of the countries involved. This is a concern to people of Third World countries whose conception of the national interest may be different from the economic elites of their own countries who borrow from the banks and gain by far the most, along with the banks and their agents, from the investments.

This sort of international economic imperialism has implications for Australia as well. Quite apart from the danger of a decline to Third World status, it is clear that many in Australia's power elites embrace a destiny of laissez-faire economic internationalism, incorporating the breakdown of national sovereignty to better facilitate foreign investment. They are actively assisted by `humanitarian' internationalists. High immigration, the weakening of border controls and `free movement of labour' are part of the agenda. Many of these people stand to personally gain financially from such an agenda, at least in the short- to medium-term, but we will all lose out in the long run.

Though there has been a great deal of emphasis about the supposed quest for national independence through becoming a republic, our capacity for national independence has declined, not increased, in the last decade. True independence, as a number of more thoughtful commentators have pointed out, can be sustained only by a strong economy as well as national self-respect. Our present course will lead us to neither. While our debt continues to increase at such an alarming rate, we make ourselves more and more financially dependent upon foreign nations. At the same time our leaders cede our sovereignty to foreign bodies over which we have little control, as much as they may love to posture before them.

The common thread in all of this is that we must act according to international obligations. Where is the national independence in that? As part of our international obligations, I suggest sending a few comfortable humanitarians on secondment to neighbouring nations to our north. Irene Moss, for example, can be sent—along with the racial vilification legislation—as a race discrimination commissioner to Indonesia or, better still, Burma. Even if we have to pay for her and her ilk, it would not be long before the savings—financial and otherwise—make themselves apparent.

I am supporting this Bill, and I will be voting for it. I am doing so because I cannot at this moment carry any more battles. I think I have made it clear that I support the Bill with great reservations, and I hope we are much more cautious in the future and are more prepared to advance Australia's national sovereignty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the Charter of the United Nations Amendment Bill. I share some of the concerns of the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) about ceding Australia's sovereignty externally. Other issues arise from the introduction of this legislation, and some concern the problems of implementation vis-a-vis the relationship with the States. I will refer to some correspondence between the Western Australian Attorney-General and the Federal Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch). The effect of the legislation has obviously raised considerable concern with the Western Australian Government.

PARA.TAB: Another aspect of this Bill concerns the change from legislation to regulations in the implementation of United Nations sanctions. It is clear that on 26 April, following the failure of the UN Vance-Owen peace plan—which was rejected by the self-styled Bosnian-Serbian Parliament in Pala in Bosnia-Herzegovina—tough new United Nations sanctions came into force against the rump of Yugoslavia, Serbia and Montenegro.

The United Nations Security Council, which passed the resolution on 17 April, had delayed its implementation to give the Bosnian-Serbs time to ratify the plan and to avoid jeopardising the chances of the Russian President, Mr Yeltsin, winning his recent referendum. As a consequence of this, we find ourselves today in the position of debating the Charter of the United Nations Amendment Bill. I support the intent of the sanctions. I believe that it was necessary for the sanctions to be tightened. It was clear from the actions of the Bosnian-Serb Parliament after the eligible electors voted to reject the Vance-Owen peace plan that more stringent action was required.

I have been considerably interested in the crisis that has affected the Balkans as a consequence of the break-up of the former Yugoslavia, and I want to see the quickest possible end to the enormous damage, bloodshed and loss of life that has been wreaked upon Bosnia-Herzegovina since the outbreak of hostilities. I refer particularly to the aggression perpetrated against the Muslims. On our television sets we have seen the bloodiness and the bitterness of the fighting in the epicentre of Bosnia-Herzegovina which revolves around the capital city of Sarejevo.

In principle, I support the implementation of the sanctions against the rump of Yugoslavia, and the Serbian and Montenegran republics. Pressure must be placed on the transport of goods through Yugoslavia, its financial assets overseas must be frozen and shipping on the Danube and in the Adriatic must be blocked. Strict fines should be imposed on those organisations, individuals or nations that violate the particular sanctions.

Mr Momcilo Krajifnak, the Speaker of the Bosnian-Serb Parliament said, `We must not hesitate to mobilise for the defence of the motherland, tighten our ranks and fight to the end'. Another member of the same parliament said, `If the Vietnamese can survive a war conducted by the Americans, we can too'. General Vlajic, the officer-in-charge of the Bosnian-Serb forces, indicated that there would be a campaign of terror conducted around the world if the rest of the world dared to try to implement more stringent actions, and in particular to deploy ground forces or air attacks designed to try to prevent the bitter fighting that has been going on for some time.

I have a problem with this Bill, and that concerns the extent of the legislation and its consequences in relation to the powers of the States. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) indicated in the second reading speech in the Senate that the Bill was designed to provide for the States—in other words, that there would be overriding States legislation in achieving the implementation of sanctions. As a consequence of that, the Attorney-General of Western Australia, Cheryl Edwards, wrote to the Federal Attorney-General on 5 May indicating the concerns of the Western Australian Government. In her letter she said:

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill has enormous scope, particularly in its potential to extend into areas of State concern and State law.
For example, the Bill proposes to:
(1)bind the Crown in right of the States (proposed section 4);
(2)enable Commonwealth regulations to give effect to United Nations Security Council decisions including, for example, Security Council sanctions (proposed section 6);
(3)enable such Commonwealth regulations to override State laws passed prior to the coming into operation of proposed section 6 (proposed section 9);
(4)enable such Commonwealth regulations—because of section 109 of the Commonwealth Constitution—to render subsequent inconsistent State laws or regulations invalid;

(5)allow Commonwealth (but not State) legislation passed after the commencement of this proposed Act (if it expressly so provides) to be interpreted as amending or repealing such Commonwealth regulations—clause 10.

That is, only the Commonwealth—but not the States—will be able to amend, repeal or effect the operation of Commonwealth regulations implementing United Nations Security Council decisions. Therefore, there is an express and direct inconsistency between the positions under paragraphs (4) and (5); and

PARA.TAB: (6)vest federal jurisdiction under this Bill in State Supreme Courts—proposed section 13(8)—which may well have important consequences in adding to the already very heavy work load of those courts.

SPEECH.PARA: As she indicated, the Bill also raises serious legal and constitutional issues concerning the extent of Commonwealth legislative power, in particular concerning the external affairs power under section 51 subsection 29 of the Constitution. The use of that power, particularly as contemplated by this Bill, has important and often detrimental political and legal consequences for Commonwealth-State relations. She concluded in her first letter:

In view of the above matters, the timetable (of the Bill's introduction in the Senate next week) is far too short to enable appropriate and adequate consideration of the political consequences, merits and constitutional issues involved.

This is particularly so when the Commonwealth has provided no reasons for such urgency. The only suggestion is in paragraph 2 on page 2 of the facsimile from the Federal Attorney-General, which stated:

To date, Australia has given effect to. . . sanctions [imposed by the United Nations Security Council] under existing legislation eg the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations. However, the Security Council has in recent times begun to impose sanctions for which Australia has no legislative means to give effect.
The nub of this particular argument is, as the State Attorney-General, Mrs Edwards, has said:
However, there is no supporting documentation—
or there was no supporting documentation—
or reasons provided to suggest that factual premise correct.
She asked:
For example, has all State legislation been examined to ascertain whether it might be able to implement even some such sanctions?
Even if that paragraph two assertion is correct, it does not justify such an urgent unilateral Commonwealth legislative response.
Therefore that:

PARA.TAB: (1)this Bill should not be introduced into the Senate next week; and
(2) there must be adequate time for the States and other interested and appropriate persons and organisations to consider and consult regarding both:

TAB.TAB: (a) the merits of the Bill; and
(b) alternative methods of ascertaining the extent of, and overcoming any problem of enforcing appropriate Security Council sanctions "for which Australia has no legislative means to give effect.

SPEECH.PARA: She asked that, because of the proposed timetable, she receive an early reply. The Attorney-General did reply on 18 May, to which Mrs Edwards replied subsequently on 24 May.

PARA.TAB: Before I mention the reply that Mrs Edwards made to the letter from the Federal Attorney-General, I might point out where some of those difficult Commonwealth-State political issues arise. Of course, we are in the process at the moment of a tremendous debate in the community, particularly in the media, as to the future of our Constitution and obviously the relationship between the Commonwealth and the States.

Naturally Western Australia always has been concerned about the extent to which Commonwealth legislation or the Commonwealth authority overlapped or overrode the State authority. There is considerable interest in Western Australia as to the extent of any proposed changes, so that there is going to be an opportunity for the Western Australian State Government and for other interested parties in Western Australia to be able to assert their case in a fundamental and forthright way.

There is some suspicion, I might say, which is supported by some of the comments made by members on the other side of this chamber, that the real agenda for these proposed changes to our Constitution and the way in which we run our system of government is designed to eventually abolish the States. The honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner)—who was nominated by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) as one of three members to prepare the Address-in-Reply to the Governor-General's speech—indicated earlier today in the members' 90-second statements and in his maiden speech that the abolition of the States was part of this process. At the time, there was quite rapturous acclaim from other members opposite—and I see a smile on the face of the sole member in the back bench opposite me at the moment—for what I believe is a hidden agenda that will eventually see a movement towards the abolition of the States. I must say that, although it is probably a bit of a long bow to draw, there are some elements of this in the relationship of this Bill and its effects to State legislation.
I want to mention some of the matters raised in the letter from Mrs Edwards on 24 May to the Attorney-General. She said in relation to Security Council resolution 820 in the 1993 Bill:

SPEECH.PARA: Your facsimile states: "The obligations under Resolution 820 were not able to be implemented in full under existing Commonwealth or State legislation.
She asked the question:
Would you advise:
(a) what obligations under that Resolution were able to be implemented under existing Commonwealth and/or State legislation; and
(b) what obligations could not be implemented under such legislation.
In relation to the scope of the 1993 Bill, she asked:
Your facsimile indicates that the Bill was introduced to "fill the gap" in Commonwealth and State legislation in relation to Resolution 820.
However, your facsimile also recognises that the Bill is intended to enable Commonwealth Regulations to implement future UN Security Council sanctions.

Your facsimile states: "it was recognised [by the Commonwealth] that other Security Council sanctions might be imposed in the future which are not able to be given effect through existing legislation. The Bill therefore enables Regulations to be made to give effect to the obligations that arise in those circumstances
That is, a very considerable extension from the implementation of Resolution 820 to the implementation (by Commonwealth regulations) of all Security Council Resolutions.
She said:
Your facsimiles do not suggest any justification for such an extension either in terms of:
(a) identifiable gaps in the existing Commonwealth and/or state legislation; or
(b) the inability of Commonwealth/State consultation to address the issue of the implementation of future Security Council Resolutions.
She went on:

Your facsimile of 18 May does, however, claim that "the urgency with which Security Council obligations arise does not lend itself to detailed consultations with the States over their implementation." I presume that this assertion is meant to apply to all future sanctions.
She mentioned two matters which indicated the 1993 Bill ought not to extend as far as it is extending. She said:
(i)there will be sanctions where urgency is not a prime or even important consideration; and

(ii)particularly in view of the new Security Council practice outlined in para 2 of your facsimile of 18 May 1993, the implementation of sanctions may need to be carefully considered on an individual basis, including the need for Commonwealth/State consultation.

In conclusion, there are a number of issues raised by the later letter of the State Attorney-General, Mrs Edwards, in relation to the extent of the provisions of the Bill. I think that, under the circumstances, those issues need to be addressed and resolved as quickly as possible. As a Western Australian member, someone who is very keen to ensure that the authority and prerogative of the Western Australian State Parliament are not infringed unnecessarily or improperly by the Commonwealth, I am anxious to see that there is a proper consultation process between the Commonwealth and the State Government in relation to the Charter of the United Nations Amendment Bill and, in particular, to ensure that there are no unnecessary infringements of the rights and the prerogative of the State Parliament and, of course, the State of Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: I indicated earlier that I do support the general principle of the Bill because I believe that the sanctions were necessary and there are some conceded foreseen difficulties—they are indicated in the correspondence of the Attorney-General and in the second reading speech of the Minister for Foreign Affairs—in relation to the implementation of the sanctions which are quite wide ranging in their effect.

In supporting the Bill, I would like to register my concerns about the issues raised by the Attorney-General of Western Australia and I would like to see those concerns addressed as quickly as possible. I would certainly prefer that in future there be much closer consultation between the Commonwealth and the States in relation to United Nations sanctions and their implementation.

As was indicated in the second reading speech of the Foreign Minister, it is clear that in the changes that have occurred in the international community—and, in particular, in the United Nations—since the breakup of the former Soviet Union, the opportunities for Security Council agreement to sanctions have improved considerably. As a consequence, a lot more resolutions of that sort have been introduced and thus it is necessary for Australia to fulfil its international obligations.

I concede that Australia's membership of the United Nations and its participation in the implementation of sanctions is an important part of Australia's foreign obligations; there is no doubt about that at all. But I also believe that a much greater level of consultation is needed in the implementation of those types of sanctions, particularly as we have seen them becoming much more wide ranging and because of the effect their implementation has on Australian activities.

In conclusion, I support the Bill. I hope that resolution 820 and the sanctions imposed as a consequence have some salutary effect on aggression, and the opportunity to perpetrate aggression, against innocent civilians and others. I hope that what until now has been seen as a very powerless process will have a little more effect on aggressors and will bring to a halt the terrible destruction, killing and bloodshed that have been wreaked, particularly in recent times, on Bosnia and Herzegovina.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BILNEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I do not want to detain the House for very long, but I do want to thank those honourable members who contributed to the debate on the second reading of the Charter of the United Nations Amendment Bill. I think you would agree with me, Mr Deputy Speaker, that some of those contributions were nothing if not wide ranging and honourable members displayed great tolerance in listening to them. I suppose the substantial point about this debate is that the Opposition is supporting the Bill—indeed, the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) said that he was supporting it as well.

PARA.TAB: The previous speaker, the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing), made a point in relation to the possible effects on the States of legislation of this kind. I have regard for his sensitivities and the sensitivities of the State of Western Australia on whose behalf he speaks in this respect, but I do not think that can blind us to the fact that we do need to take a national approach on issues in which the States really have no role.

I, for one, have been disturbed occasionally by recent adventures—or purported adventures—of the States into the realm of foreign affairs. By and large, I think they have been brought into disrepute, particularly where they involve the stationing overseas of people who spend the taxpayers' money like water. I will not go into any more detail than that. But certain matters are far too important for us to be worried about over sensitivity on the part of governmental entities in States which really have no business worrying about them; and this is one such matter.While I am certain that the problems to which the honourable member alluded will be looked at in the context of this Bill, I do not think they should detain us.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Bilney) read a third time.
Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear The Hon G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill will amend several laws including the income tax legislation and the Corporations Law. It contains the measures foreshadowed in the joint statement by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and the former Attorney-General on 2 December 1992. Those measures included abolishing the existing priority of the Commissioner of Taxation for debts in relation to certain unremitted amounts which become payable after 30 June 1993. They also included measures to enable the commissioner to recover the unremitted amounts more quickly through an estimation process and to encourage directors to face emerging problems as soon as possible.I now turn to a more detailed discussion of these measures.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Removal of the Commissioner's priority

PARA.TAB: The commissioner's priority currently applies to amounts deducted by employers from the salary or wages of their employees, and deductions of a similar nature, where those deductions are not paid to the commissioner. The commissioner's priority ranks debts for those deductions above all other debts of a person or company in a bankruptcy or insolvency. The Bill will remove the commissioner's priority for debts in respect of those deductions, as well as certain other deductions such as those made from prescribed payments under the prescribed payments system. The amendments will apply to unremitted amounts which become payable after 30 June 1993. As a result of the amendments, debts due to the commissioner, arising because of a failure to remit amounts deducted, will be treated in a similar manner to debts payable to other unsecured creditors. Estimation of unremitted amounts

The amendments proposed in the Bill will enable the commissioner to recover unremitted amounts more quickly by estimating those amounts which become payable after 30 June 1993 and by commencing recovery action on the basis of the estimate. The commissioner will only make an estimate of the unremitted deductions when the due date has passed and those deductions have not been paid. The main objective of the new regime is to recover the actual deductions made. Ample opportunity will be provided to the person who did not remit the deductions, as required under the tax legislation, to inform the commissioner of the actual amount deducted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Directors to be responsible for unremitted amounts

PARA.TAB: The Bill will also make company directors liable for deductions made by their company and not remitted to the commissioner. Currently, directors can be convicted in relation to their company's non-payment of amounts deducted and can be ordered by a court to pay reparation equal to the deductions not remitted. This new measure will achieve this result more efficiently.

Consistent with the theme of the recent amendments to the Corporations Law, this measure will ensure solvency problems are confronted earlier and the escalation of debts will be prevented. The amendments proposed will result in a company either meeting its obligations to pay amounts deducted to the commissioner or going into voluntary administration or liquidation. Directors will only become liable for unremitted amounts when those options are not taken by their company.Another feature of the arrangements will be a requirement on the commissioner to notify directors who become liable for any unremitted amounts. He will be required to allow those directors a further period of 14 days, during which time the liability can be avoided if one of the options available is exercised.

The Bill contains defences for directors in recovery proceedings by the commissioner. For example, it will be a defence if a director can prove that because of illness, or some other reason, the director did not take part in the company's management when the company failed to take one of the options available to avoid liability.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Consequential amendments to the Corporations Law, the Bankruptcy Act 1966 and the Crown Debts (Priority) Act 1981

PARA.TAB: The Bill proposes to amend the Corporations Law. The amendments are relatively minor and technical and support the measures to be included in the taxation law. Broadly, they seek to put the commissioner in the same position as other creditors so that the commissioner has clear access to all the remedies enjoyed by other creditors. The amendments to the other Acts are purely technical and consequential.

The removal of the commissioner's priority is essential to the smooth operation of the proposed scheme of voluntary administration under the new insolvency provisions of the Corporations Law due to commence in June this year.

In accordance with the heads of agreement between the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory on corporate regulation, the Ministerial Council for Corporations has been consulted on the amendments to the Corporations Law which are contained in the Bill and has approved their introduction into Parliament.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Revenue effect

PARA.TAB: Any loss of revenue from abolishing the priority will be offset by the revenue recovered under the new recovery regime. It is important for honourable members to recognise the revenue recovered belongs to employees or payees and has been deducted but not remitted to the commissioner as required by law. I present the explanatory memorandum which contains more detailed explanations of the provisions of the Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
Leave granted for debate to continue forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Insolvency (Tax Priorities) Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 Bill seeks to give effect to the Government's announcement on 2 December last year to abolish the Australian Taxation Office's priority when an insolvency occurs. The announcement was made, as has already been pointed out, in a joint statement by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and the then Attorney-General, the honourable member for Holt (Mr Duffy).

PARA.TAB: Under the present arrangements the Australian Taxation Office has priority over employees and other unsecured creditors to claim unremitted group tax deductions and some other payments in the event of a company becoming insolvent. As the situation now stands these arrangements can cause considerable hardship for employees as a result of an insolvency because the ATO's priority means that there is often little or nothing left for employees and other creditors following the payment of these outstanding taxes.

The Bill sets out to remove the commissioner's priority for debts for those deductions including deductions made under the prescribed payments system. Under the proposed new arrangements debts due to the Commissioner of Taxation arising because of a failure to remit amounts deducted will be treated in a similar manner to debts payable to other unsecured creditors. This will put the Tax Office on an equal footing with other creditors, as might be expected. The amendments will apply only to unremitted amounts which become payable after 30 June 1993.

While the Bill will remove the commissioner's priority in these matters, it will also facilitate the recovery of unremitted amounts by a new process of estimating those amounts which become payable after 30 June next. Recovery action may then be commenced on the basis of such an estimate. The estimate is to be made when the due date for the payment of the deductions has passed without deductions having been paid. However, opportunity will be given to allow those who have not remitted these deductions to inform the commissioner of the actual amount deducted, thereby obviating the need for the estimate process to come into play.

In addition, the Bill makes company directors liable for deductions made by the company and not subsequently remitted to the ATO. This measure is designed to allow a more efficient means by which reparations can be made for the amounts deducted but not remitted. It will force companies to confront their solvency problems more quickly and thereby prevent a rapid increase in their debts which might adversely affect their ability to make payment. Such a rapid increase in debts can easily occur because of the penalties imposed for late payment and the ATO's slowness in demanding payment of moneys that under the existing arrangements it is guaranteed to receive ahead of other creditors. The Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) in his second reading speech indicated that the revenue effect will be neutral, whereas I am of the opinion that the penalty factors will mean that the commissioner may collect far less than he now collects.

Under these new arrangements, a company will be forced to either make the payments due or go into voluntary administration or liquidation. Generally, directors will only become liable for unremitted amounts when one of those options is not taken by the taxpayer company. The commissioner will be required to notify directors who become liable to pay any unremitted amounts. However, liability is avoided if one of the options is exercised within 14 days.

There are a number of defences available to directors in recovery proceedings undertaken by the Commissioner of Taxation under the terms set out in the Bill. These provisions allow a director to establish that he did not take part in the company's management at the time the company failed to take one of the options to avoid liability.

In addition to these arrangements for the Income Tax Assessment Act, the Bill also makes a number of consequential amendments to the Corporations Law, the Bankruptcy Act and the Crown Debts (Priority) Act. The amendments to the Corporations Law contained in this Bill put the Commissioner of Taxation in the same position as other creditors, with the commissioner having access to the same remedies available to other creditors.

The removal of the commissioner's priority, as proposed, brings these provisions into line with the new insolvency provisions in the Corporations Law that will begin operation in June of this year. The Bill thus brings the tax law into harmony with the new Corporations Law. The measures contained in the Bill have been in the pipeline for some five years now, it being that long ago that proposals along these lines were first recommended by the Law Reform Commission in its general insolvency inquiry in 1988.

Despite the long gestation period we are dealing with legislation in the now traditional mid-year rush, this Bill having only been tabled in the Senate on 19 May and dealt with in that place a few days later. As far as this House is concerned, the Bill has been introduced and is being debated within a day or so of it being debated and passed in its present form by the Senate. This is clearly an unsatisfactory state of affairs, particularly given some of the complex matters involved. The outcome of this rushed legislative process will be that the Bill will probably be passed without many of the coalition's concerns being satisfactorily addressed or explanations obtained.

It should be pointed out that the coalition is not alone in having concerns about the rushed legislative process. The Law Council of Australia has written to the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) in a letter dated 24 May 1993 recommending that consideration of this legislation be deferred until such time as the Law Council can examine and comment on the Bill. This is an eminently reasonable request, coming from one of the peak law bodies in the country, and one which the Government would be expected to accede to; but apparently Labor does not care about the council's request or what it might have to say. It thinks it knows better than the Law Council of Australia in these matters and so we are debating the Bill today without knowing what that council thinks about the legislation. Of course, what we do know is that the council obviously has grave reservations; otherwise it would not be requesting that consideration of the Bill be deferred.

Unfortunately, this legislation falls into the now infamous pattern of legislating established by Labor in government. Important measures take years to get off the ground and be embodied in legislation. Yet, when proposals finally reach this place in the form of a Bill they are rushed through the Parliament in the mid-year or end of year rush and often debated under the guillotine. The result is that we get inferior legislation despite the enormous amount of time expended in putting the proposals and the legislation together in a way designed to meet the Government's own objectives. There is no excuse for legislation and for making law in this way. Yet, the Government does it time and time again.

Despite these reservations, the objectives of this Bill are worthy and these measures are for the most part to be welcomed as useful improvements to the administration of tax law and corporate insolvency law. One of the many problems with the existing arrangements is that the size of the debts owed to the Tax Office is allowed to grow to ridiculous proportions because the Tax Office is so slow to recoup the money that is owed by the insolvent entity. The ATO now has no incentive to take quick and decisive action in these cases because its priority under the existing arrangements guarantees that it will get its money regardless of the consequences that might have for other creditors and, most importantly, employees.

While the unpaid funds which are the subject of this Bill are not assets of the company, there is always the temptation for companies to make use of deductions on behalf of employees as emergency working capital which can be ultimately disastrous for the employees. There is also a problem with the existing arrangements and the new insolvency procedure of voluntary administration under the new corporations legislation. This procedure allows for the possibility that a company can trade out of its difficulties under the supervision of an administrator. But creditors will not agree to the use of this procedure if the only or principal beneficiary for such an arrangement is the Australian Taxation Office because of its priority under existing arrangements. Clearly, the ATO needs to be put on an equal footing with other creditors to permit some entities to trade out of difficulty and do so effectively.

With this Bill debts due to the commissioner as a result of failure to remit amounts deducted are treated on the same basis as debts payable to other unsecured creditors upon the entity being placed into insolvency administration by the rateable application of the insolvent estate's assets. The provisions dealing with the new recovery procedure based on the estimation of unremitted amounts gives rise to a number of concerns about the discretion that these provisions afford the Commissioner of Taxation. The Bill provides that the commissioner may have regard to anything that he thinks is relevant in making an estimate, a discretion similar to that afforded the commissioner in so many tax laws and the administration of those laws.

The only restriction on the commissioner's discretion will be the requirement that the estimate be reasonable but, as we all know, that is a very loose restriction that affords little protection to the company or the entity concerned. Attempting to define what may be reasonable, and bringing the commissioner to account for his definition in any given case, is far more difficult than the word `reasonable' might be thought to imply. This is particularly so when it is realised that the Bill explicitly excludes the decisions of the commissioner from judicial review under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977, effectively putting the commissioner's judgment in this matter and related matters above the law and increasing the onus of proof on companies and entities challenging the commissioner's estimate.

There is no requirement in the proposed legislation that the estimate be based on an extrapolation of what reasonably would be due predicated upon past remittances of the particular taxpayer. The ability to pay the amount of the estimate which arises immediately upon the issuing of a notice is created by section 222AHA(1), with subsection 2 of the same section providing:
(2) A liability to pay an estimate is separate and distinct from the liability to which the estimate relates.

SPEECH.PARA: However, payment of one liability will correspondingly reduce the other. If the amount paid to discharge the estimate exceeds the unpaid amount of the actual liability, then the commissioner must either refund the excess or apply it against any other liabilities that that entity might have. This last option may allow the commissioner to avoid having to seek to execute a judgment for a debt.

PARA.TAB: If it is accepted that the issuance of an assessment creates a liability, then this provision is of even wider benefit to the commissioner. Section 222AHC provides for an affidavit from the defendant if it attests to certain things that would constitute defence to recovery of the estimate. An estimate will be provable in a bankruptcy or a winding up. The penalty regime will operate if an estimate remains undischarged after seven days from the issuing of the notice. The penalties will be on the same terms as would apply to failure to pay the underlying liability.

The commissioner is also given a wide discretion to make an agreement for the discharge of the liability by payments in instalments. The Bill provides that the relevant payments should be made or the company is immediately forced into liquidation or voluntary administration. As we should realise, these provisions are intended to prevent the use of PAYE money being used as emergency working capital. The directors become personally liable for the company's failure to pay if none of the three options of payment, voluntary administration or liquidation are taken up. These provisions are necessary to make the estimates procedure workable.

A difficulty arises from the fact that these provisions also provide that any person who was a director at any time during the period from when liability to remit arose until the date when payment is due will be liable to pay the commissioner an amount equal to the unpaid amount of the company or entity's liability. This is despite the fact that the director may have resigned from the board, having failed to convince it to take one of the options required under this Bill. This individual could still be liable for the whole amount of the unpaid tax despite having attempted to do the right thing and having acted in good faith if the liability cannot effectively be applied to the other directors.

Some of the defences available to directors provide little effective protection in contingencies such as these. The defences themselves are under-specified, creating a great deal of uncertainty in the application of these provisions. For example, one available defence is for a director to show that he took all reasonable steps—there is that word again, `reasonable'—to ensure that the deductions were remitted or that there were no such steps that the director could take in the circumstances. Whether this section also protects a director who has acted in good faith is far from clear. Another problem with the Bill is its failure to address the ATO's duty under section 221Q of the Income Tax Assessment Act to credit an employee with an amount of tax equal to the amount deducted from that employee's salary or wages when the employer has made such deductions but has failed to issue a group certificate for the employee's salary or wages. The interaction of the new estimates procedure with section 221Q has not been dealt with and it is not clear whether the issue of an estimate will grant the benefit of the estimated amount due in tax to employees in the way that it should. This is potentially a very serious problem in that it is not clear exactly how one would go about bringing section 221Q into line with the new provisions.

As I have already indicated, the coalition supports the broad thrust of the legislation. The intentions behind the Bill are unobjectionable. They put the Australian Taxation Office on a more equal footing with other individuals, which is important for the rule of law in the administration of taxation law and corporate insolvency laws. The provisions of this Bill also seek to encourage companies to address their insolvency problems in a timely way and to facilitate the ATO's recovery of deductions made on behalf of employees. The Bill also affords these employees a greater measure of protection than is available under current arrangements.

At the same time, however, the coalition, both here and in the Senate, has brought the Government's attention to a number of apparent deficiencies in the legislation which may compromise its effectiveness. It is unfortunate that the Government's overly rushed approach to this legislative program means that these concerns will be left unaddressed, at least for the time being.

As I have pointed out, the coalition parties are not the only ones with reservations about the specifics of the legislation. The Law Council of Australia has requested that consideration of this Bill be deferred until such time as it has had an opportunity to pass comment on the provisions. The Law Council obviously feels that it has not had enough time to scrutinise the legislation to its satisfaction, and any objective examination of the timing of this legislation through both Houses would bear testimony to that.

In debating this legislation this evening, rather than deferring its consideration as requested by the Law Council, the Government continues to show its disregard for sound law-making practices. If the peak law body in this country cannot persuade the Government to legislate in the correct manner, it would seem unlikely that the Opposition will ever be able to persuade it, given the Government's arrogance in this Parliament and its attitude towards debate and sensible discussion of measures such as this. It is a sad state of affairs that this Labor Government's most recent term of office is only a few months old and already it is back into its bad old arrogant habits.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Insolvency (Tax Priorities) Legislation Amendment Bill is long overdue. It is the result of the work of very many people. It is the result of the work of many members from this side of the House, but it also results from lobbying efforts from unions, small business and, as I said, politicians, particularly from this side of the House.

PARA.TAB: I would like to pay tribute to the work of the honourable member for Holt (Mr Duffy), who was a very enthusiastic advocate of this measure before us today. He, along with many people, worked very hard over the years to eliminate the privilege of the taxation commissioner in collecting his tax ahead of the wages of workers and the bills of suppliers, particularly small business. So I think this Government is to be congratulated on moving in this area and on moving with the speed with which it has moved.

The honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) talked about the lack of debate. There has already been a comprehensive debate in the Senate on this matter, much of which has been regurgitated by the honourable member for Curtin today. I do not intend to do that in my comments, except to talk about the broad principles behind the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about talking about the start of the debate back in 1978?

—Unlike the Opposition, this Government has a commitment to reform and to progressive reform. The Opposition has never seen fit to talk about the injustice of the current legislation or the previous legislation because it would not deliver justice to workers, through the delivery of their wages, and to small business. It has only ever been concerned with one particular side of the fence in taxation reform: it believes only in flat taxation, and it has always been quite happy to let the Commissioner of Taxation exercise his privilege against the wages of workers and the bills of small business people.

PARA.TAB: I cannot find, in doing my research into this matter, any comment from the Opposition on this matter over the previous decade or so. The pressure has come from this side of the House as well as from people in insolvency. It has not come from the Opposition, and that is the usual state of affairs when we look at taxation.

Let us get down to the main parts of the Bill. There are two in particular that I want to talk about today. The first one deals with the removal of the priority of the taxation commissioner in respect of bankrupt and insolvent businesses to collect unremitted PAYE and similar deductions made from the salaries or wages of the employees of businesses. It takes the priority of the commissioner away—that is a good thing—and it also sets up a mechanism to ensure that the taxation commissioner can collect PAYE taxation, in particular, promptly and fairly. As I said before, these changes rightly place the interests of workers and others at the head of the queue of unsecured creditors and ahead of the taxation commissioner. So essentially this Bill gives workers and others a better go.

I do not think we should forget that what we are dealing with here is employees' taxes held in trust by the employers prior to their remittance to the Australian Taxation Office. Currently, if a firm becomes insolvent what net benefit is there to the community to give priority to the Tax Office while employees miss out on wages and other entitlements? Of course, the answer is that there is no justice in that arrangement, which is why this Bill is before the House today.

The key point about this Bill is that employees of bankrupt or insolvent businesses will have much improved prospects of being paid their outstanding wages. For that reason alone, it is an historic reform—and should be acknowledged as such by the Opposition—and the Government should be congratulated by the Opposition for bringing this matter forward.

The Opposition cannot have it both ways. It cannot on the one hand argue that the principle is fine but that there should be more debate, because if the principle is fine one would have thought there was some urgency about putting this Bill into practice. Given the inequities that are taking place in the community, given the number of insolvencies which the Opposition constantly talks about, I would have thought that it would have seen some urgency in this matter.

As is always the case, the Opposition does not care about the employees in particular who are left out in the cold by the current arrangement. This is legislation which has been called for by most sectors of the community, including the legal profession, but not called for by the Opposition. In fact, it is pretty hard to find many people who have a bad word to say about this legislation, except the Opposition. Let us say goodbye and good riddance to the old legislation and welcome the new legislation as a very substantial reforming achievement. It is simply a false economy to put the Commissioner of Taxation ahead of employees and other small businesses in terms of insolvency.

The second aspect of this legislation that I would like to deal with is the provision of a new method whereby the commissioner may receive unremitted amounts by estimating the amount due from a firm. The situation at the moment is that the taxation commissioner has no real way of estimating what a firm may owe the commissioner should it fall behind in its payments. This legislation provides a mechanism so that the Commissioner of Taxation can make an estimate of what is owed, and it provides a mechanism for the Commissioner of Taxation to commence recovery of that amount. That is a very welcome initiative because it will ensure that many of the problems that currently emerge will not get to the stage that they currently do and result in the insolvency of the firm. The terms and conditions of this mechanism are set out in proposed section 222AGA, and I do not intend to run through them at any length this evening.

Lastly, I would like to talk about the other significant aspect of the Bill, which extends the liability for unremitted amounts to company directors. I concede this point: there is some cause for concern that if these sections were applied harshly there might be some disincentive for company directors to seek to continue to have their firm in operation whilst they were trying to sort out their problems. But I believe that there is sufficient scope within the Bill for company directors not to be concerned that they will be treated unduly harshly by the taxation commissioner. I believe that there are sufficient mechanisms within the Bill whereby company directors can ensure, through the Commissioner of Taxation—if they are acting properly and fairly and in the interests of their company and employees—that the taxation commissioner will take those considerations into account.

I believe that the Bill provides that in a number of ways. Firstly, a director cannot be held liable under the new provisions unless he or she has received a written notice of failure to remit which points out the options that need to be taken by that company director. That is a very significant provision. Secondly, if the company is going through a short-term liquidity crisis, it is open to the company to enter into an arrangement with the Commissioner of Taxation. I believe that is a significant section of the Bill.

If the company is having major liquidity problems, the company can either enter into a scheme of voluntary administration or wind up voluntarily. Either way it means that the company does not continue, as is the case now, to accumulate huge debts to the Taxation Office, thereby prolonging and creating an even bigger problem for itself and for its employees.

In winding up, I would also like to make the comment that, given that this is such significant legislation that does change significantly the way tax law has operated, I believe it is incumbent upon the Taxation Office to spend some time and resources in educating the business community as to the effect of this new legislation. I do not believe at the moment the current legislation is well understood in the business community, but when we have a new initiative as significant as this one, which imposes significant obligations upon company directors, I believe it is important that the Taxation Office engage in that public education.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams Mr D.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The ostensible object of this Insolvency (Tax Priorities) Legislation Amendment Bill is to remove priorities enjoyed by the Commissioner of Taxation in proving for certain debts and insolvencies of persons and companies in priority to other creditors. There are four types of debt involved. Firstly, there are tax instalment deductions made from salary or wages under the PAYE scheme; secondly, there are deductions made from prescribed payments under the prescribed payments scheme; then, of perhaps less day-to-day significance, certain natural resource and other unattributed income payments not remitted; and certain withholding tax payments not remitted.

PARA.TAB: There is a long history to this. It goes back prior to 1978 when the Crown exercised a right of priority in proving in insolvencies, but it was a prerogative rather than a statutory right in the main. In 1978 the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs recommended the total abolition of all crown priority in its 1978 report entitled Priority of crown debts. This report was partially accepted when the extensive priority given to debts due to the Commonwealth was significantly diminished under the Crown Debts (Priority) Act 1981 of the Commonwealth. These were primarily directed at removing priority of personal tax debts.

But, as the Australian Law Reform Commission in its 1988 report mentioned, the priorities which relate to employers and other persons being required to collect tax money and remit it to the commissioner were largely left untouched. It is this second stage that we are now at. The Australian Law Reform Commission studied the subject of insolvency quite extensively and, in its report delivered in 1978, recommended that the commissioner's priority under sections 221P, 221YHJ, 221YHZD and 221YU of the Income Tax Assessment Act should be abolished. It is that recommendation which is in effect implemented by this 1993 Bill.

There are very good reasons for the abolition of the priority which the Law Reform Commission articulated based on submissions to it. The commissioner's priority assures that he receives payment and consequently that he is under no pressure to recover unremitted taxes in the normal commercial manner. Secondly, by allowing taxation debts to accumulate without real risk to his position, the commissioner may seriously disadvantage other unsecured creditors. He may decide to let an employer continue trading even though group tax is owing, and other creditors who will not be privy to this information may be ultimately disadvantaged if the business later goes into liquidation.

Further, the taxation debts of insolvents are insignificant in terms of total government receipts, but the amount forgone by a private creditor may be the difference between the creditor surviving or failing. If one wants to put that in terms of looking after workers, employees, and looking after small businessmen, we agree wholeheartedly with that proposition. The Opposition supports the principle of this Bill.

However, I am not going to address the merits or demerits of the further provisions in the Bill, but the manner in which they arrive at this House. Let me first mention what they are. The second part of the Bill introduces a procedure to facilitate recovery by the commissioner. Because the commissioner is not aware of circumstances within a company, he is enabled under the legislation to make an estimate of the liability. This is a detailed innovation about which there has been no consultation. I accept that in the joint press release of 2 December 1992 the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and the then Attorney-General, the honourable member for Holt (Mr Duffy), both mentioned that there would be a range of measures brought forward in legislation. No detail of any sort was provided and none has been provided until this Bill was brought to the Senate last week.

One significant interested group, the Law Council of Australia, which has already been mentioned, reserves its opinion on those provisions because it has not had proper opportunity to study them, but it does suggest that it is undesirable that the process of recovery should be based on an estimate rather than on an inspection of the company books by the commissioner.

Further amendments proposed in the Bill derogate directly from the basic principle under which the Government brings this Bill forward. The fact of the matter is that under the Bill it is proposed that the commissioner have significant advantages that other unsecured creditors would not have. We can see that much even in the explanatory memorandum. Page 45, `Background to the legislation', dealing with the Corporations Law, provides that:

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed amendments to the Corporations Law are relatively minor and technical and support measures to be included in the Assessment Act. Broadly, they seek to put the Commissioner in the same position as other creditors, so the Commissioner has clear access to all the remedies enjoyed by other creditors.
If one believed that, there might be little to cavil at, but one need only turn four pages to page 49 where there is a subheading which says:
Where the liability of a director is avoided through a preference payment by the company, the position of Commissioner will be made equivalent to a guaranteed creditor
