That is not putting the commissioner in the same position as any other unsecured creditor; it is giving him an advantage over unsecured creditors. The same reasons that make the basic principle supportable, put the commissioner in the same position as other unsecured creditors and do not give rise to an encouragement to an insolvent to continue trading, apply to that provision.

PARA.TAB: These proposals are all new. They seek to impose personal liabilities on directors in situations where other creditors are not entitled to a similar liability. The effect is, as is mentioned in the explanatory memorandum, that the commissioner is in effect a guaranteed creditor, and if he is a guaranteed creditor he has security. Instead of being an unsecured creditor he becomes a secured creditor.

It is a matter of very serious concern that this legislation, which had its genesis in 1978, had its actual initiation in 1988, and was foreshadowed in December 1992, should have been introduced precipitately in the Senate last week without any consultation with relevant interested groups. When we talk about corporate law reform, we talk about interested groups who number hundreds of thousands, if not millions. The daily activities of millions of people are affected by corporate law. Any amendment, however insignificant it might appear to those sitting in Canberra, affects people in every city and every suburban street.

It is incumbent upon the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) to explain the urgency of this Bill. We accept that it affects small traders and employees. As suggested, the provisions under which the commissioner will in effect waive his priority can be brought into effect without introducing all the new paraphernalia that has been introduced along with it. The interested groups that are normally consulted on corporate law reform include: the Business Council of Australia, the Institute of Directors, the Law Council of Australia, the Institute of Chartered Accountants, the Society of Certified Practising Accountants, and the Insolvency Practitioners Association. In this case none of them were consulted. Why not? Why the rush?

Anybody who even looks at this Bill can discern that it is very detailed. The explanatory memorandum requires very careful reading. This Bill gives the appearance of being Treasury driven. Will we see a trend in which things like competition policy and corporate law reform become the bailiwick of Treasury? Or will we continue with the previous very satisfactory arrangement under which there was wide consultation in the corporate community regarding corporate law reform? Surely we will not have a recovery in the Budget deficit linked to the personal liability of directors.

But is the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) abandoning the consultation process that has worked so well in the past? Is the Attorney-General bowing to his more experienced Cabinet colleague the Treasurer in allowing this Bill, with its significant amendments, to be rushed through without consultation with the corporate community?

The Law Council of Australia requested that the Bill be deferred to enable the council to study it. I received a letter today from the Business Council of Australia expressing support for the relevant provisions of the Bill so far as they absolve the commissioner's priorities for unremitted group tax. The council said, however, that it had concerns about other provisions of the Bill. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: We have not had an opportunity to examine these provisions in detail but note the concerns of the Law Council of Australia in respect of trust monies, preferential payments, director's liability, administrator's liability and preferences in bankruptcy. These matters in our view require further consultation and we strongly urge the Government to hold over these provisions until the next session of Parliament.

In the short time available, the Law Council has sought to articulate its concerns. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter dated 26 May—yesterday—addressed to the Treasurer, referring to the Bill, indicating the preliminary concerns of the Law Council and indicating that the submission had also been sent to the Attorney-General; the shadow Attorney-General; the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer); and the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Kernot).

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Fitzgibbon)—I advise the honourable member that normally only tables and graphs are incorporated in Hansard. But we will have a look at it and, if it accords with the Speaker's rules, a decision will be made on that basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. The letter articulates concerns on the subject matter referred to in the letter from the Business Council of Australia. The Treasurer has had the letter since yesterday. The Attorney-General, presumably, has had the letter since yesterday. Perhaps in the time available each will be able to respond to the matters of concern to both the law council and the business council. If not, why not?

PARA.TAB: The corporate community is expected to do everything on the double. The Opposition is expected to do everything on the double. What about the Treasurer and the Attorney-General or their representatives who have appeared here—and while this debate has been going on there have been three such representatives. We have had three Ministers or Parliamentary Secretaries present for this very short debate. Where are the answers? We would especially like to know whether the Attorney-General is abandoning the consultation process in relation to corporate law reform.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to advise the honourable member that, after due consideration, it has been decided that this letter does not meet the guidelines for incorporation in Hansard. The honourable member might seek leave to have the letter tabled.
—I seek leave to table the letter.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Insolvency (Tax Priorities) Legislation Amendment Bill follows an announcement by the Government last December in which it undertook to remove the priority existing for the Crown for the Commissioner of Taxation in recovering moneys owed to the commissioner where firms became insolvent or were liquidated.

PARA.TAB: The prime beneficiaries of this initiative are likely to be the former employees of those firms that face either bankruptcy or insolvency. In the past it has been a sad fact that, with the priority claim the Commissioner of Taxation has on those moneys, those employees left without a job and little resources to support themselves found themselves unable to get their wages, long service leave and other entitlements to which they were due.

This Bill will ensure that in future employees will have greater access to their entitlements in the event of the firms they work for going bankrupt. It is not only employees who stand to gain by the Government's actions in this Bill. Other creditors, often small business people and subcontractors, are in the same position as employees when firms go under. The Government's initiatives in this Bill give those people a greater opportunity to recoup their outstanding claims.

In addition to removing the priority of the commissioner, one of the features of the Bill also places a responsibility on company directors over and above that which they previously faced—that is, to hold company directors, in certain circumstances, liable for outstanding group tax payments. We are talking about money which at no stage was the employers' money. We are talking about funds which were gross wages for the employees from which the employer was required to make a deduction for remittance to the tax commissioner.

Regrettably, employers faced with a liquidity problem have in some cases found the need or the desire to hold onto that money and not remit it to the Tax Office. Equally regrettably, it would appear that for some time the Tax Office has not been particularly efficient in its perusal, policing and collection of that money, although it does appear from some recent events in which I and the honourable member for Lilley (Mr Swan) were involved in Brisbane that the Taxation Office has markedly improved its methods of collection and that we now have in place a system which quite speedily ensures follow-up where that group tax payment has not been made.

Nonetheless, employers who decide to solve their short-term liquidity problems by dipping into the employees' pockets, which is effectively what they do when they hold onto that group tax, should face the force of the law. It is not their money, never was, never will be and should not be held by them in that way. That payment is made by them on behalf of the employees out of the employees' income. It should be seen fairly and squarely in that light. In that light, it is appropriate to say to company directors, `You have a responsibility to ensure that those funds which you are transmitting but which are not your funds are passed onto the Commissioner of Taxation'.

There are some circumstances in which they would not be liable. A company director would not be liable where his or her company has obviously made its group tax payments to the commissioner or has been placed into voluntary liquidation. In those situations, the directors would not be liable. Where that is not so, the director may be held liable for the unremitted tax. That seems to me not to be unreasonable.

The Bill also provides some measures to assist the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation in recovering those outstanding amounts. It allows the tax commissioner to make an estimate of the amounts not remitted and to commence a recovery action on the basis of that estimate. This replaces the requirement for the tax commissioner to accurately assess the outstanding amounts.

The new provisions give the tax commissioner a good deal more latitude. It is important in this debate to add that in exercising that new authority which the Bill confers the tax commissioner needs to ensure that the assessments are made carefully. The officers of the Australian Taxation Office, as with the great bulk of public servants, do an earnest job in the best interests of the nation and in accordance with the legislation within which they work.

However, I think every honourable member in this place would have had enough representations from individuals who have had difficulties and, of late, employers who have failed to make group tax remittance payments. We would have had enough representations from those people to know that the Tax Office makes its fair share of mistakes as well. One of the things that concerns me is, while supporting this legislation, to ensure that the procedures within the Australian Taxation Office result in employers who are in all fairness and reasonableness undertaking the repayment of outstanding remittances being dealt with fairly.

One of the things that has concerned me of late about remittances and the way in which the Tax Office has gone about collecting them is the transition. I spoke earlier about the fact that the Australian Taxation Office has not had a particularly effective record in collecting the group tax payments, which is why we now see group tax payments outstanding for two and three years. That should not be the case. It should not have occurred in the first place. It did occur for whatever reason.

We now have in place, though, a system in the Australian Taxation Office where those people who thought they were playing by the ground rules, even if they were not the legal rules, and had not remitted their payments for some time have had the full force of the law brought upon them. I think in those situations it is good public policy and good commonsense for the Australian Taxation Office to exercise some careful consideration when it looks at that transition so that it does not come down like a ton of bricks on top of those employers who are now quite genuinely endeavouring to make payments to make up for those payments which they have not previously made.

I make that point because of the experience that I and other honourable members have had with group tax remittances and the way in which the ATO has dealt with them, particularly in view of the new authority which this Bill will afford to the tax commissioner: the opportunity that it presents to the tax commissioner to proceed on the basis of estimates rather than actual calculations of figures. That is an appropriate provision to ensure compliance. I simply put it to the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and the Australian Taxation Office that they need to do that with some compassion and consideration, particularly in this period of transition where its own administrative procedures have now been far more effectively honed. I hope that the Treasurer and the Australian Taxation Office will take those matters on board.

Having said that, I repeat my earlier comments in respect of the payments in toto. They are employees' wages. They should never have been used by employers for any purpose other than payment of tax. Those employers who did that were not only breaking the law but also breaking the confidence and trust that their employees had in them on those occasions where it has occurred. I will not pursue the issue any further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think anybody could disagree with the stated prime objective of the Insolvency (Tax Priorities) Legislation Amendment Bill, which is that the Commissioner of Taxation should get in the queue with other creditors when a bankruptcy occurs. The Commissioner of Taxation should not have a prior claim, and there would be few people in business who would not recognise the fact that the commissioner at times has, by initiating a claim, been to the fore in seeking to recover tax by creating a situation where a bankruptcy or liquidation has occurred.

PARA.TAB: I do not think it is necessarily the role of an agency of the Australian Government to be at the forefront in creating closures and losses of jobs in Australia. The commissioner will say from time to time, `We do not initiate these processes', but the commissioner can be very pressing and almost coercive in the way in which he applies pressure in order to recover taxes, whether it be unpaid tax, unremitted tax from PAYE, prescribed payment tax or any other tax that has not been paid. It may be company tax itself. Those with experience will recognise that the commissioner, once set on a course of action, is very hard to deny.

The House is considering the removal of the commissioner's priority and his claim to recover tax in the specific areas of pay-as-you-earn tax, prescribed payments tax, natural resource and other unattributed income payments and withholding tax. On those four basic heads of taxation owed to the commissioner where there is trouble with a company, the commissioner will have to get in the queue with everybody else.

That is a laudable objective, but I think that when considering laudable objectives it is necessary to get behind the screen and the statement first expressed by the Government and enunciated by members of the Government as a `win for workers'. The Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) in a press release made on 19 May claims in the headline , `Workers rights are elevated'. I think few workers would recognise or know whether a company or an organisation had failed to make a payment of the deductions that had been made from wages and salaries.

The Commissioner of Taxation, however, has got into the queue ahead of those with claims for the first payment of wages and salaries. In that way workers' rights have been denied, as have the rights of a whole range of other people—whether they be suppliers, people leasing property, landlords or others—who come together when there is difficulty in a company and make a decision about whether a settlement can be reached or whether a closure is warranted. The commissioner has said, `We will get in the queue with the rest and not claim a priority'.

That is a laudable objective but concerns about its operation have been expressed by many notable lawyers and people familiar with the application of the Corporations Law Reform Bill and knowledgeable about the practice of insolvency in Australia. During the month of April the newspapers were filled with speculation about the provisions being considered under the Insolvency (Tax Priorities) Legislation Amendment Bill: are they fair; do they create more problems than they solve; should not the Government delay the introduction of the legislation?

I believe that the Government needs to approach the matter with care. Since there is so much uncertainty about the proposals, a period of consideration is warranted. The prime objective is stated up front, but I have doubts about other measures proposed in the Bill. The first relates to the estimation of unremitted amounts. For some time the commissioner has expressed concern for the fact that, in order to make a claim when an insolvency occurs, the commissioner must receive an accurate estimate of the amount of money to be withheld before a claim can be made. This legislation will allow the commissioner to estimate the amount of unremitted funds held by a company. Provided the commissioner is careful, most people would agree that that is a sensible approach; but the commissioner is not always careful and not always accurate. For example, the commissioner is not always careful towards the end of the financial year, when there is a requirement to make the deficit look good. The commissioner is not always careful about the needs of companies and individuals employed by private enterprise.
The Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan), in his second reading speech, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The main objective of the new regime is to recover the actual deductions made. Ample opportunity will be provided to the person who did not remit the deductions, as required under the tax legislation, to inform the commissioner of the actual amount deducted.

That is a laudable commencing statement. However, we find that where wide discretion is allowed—and the tax commissioner is allowed wide discretion—the commissioner does not hesitate to change the rules. He will make a finding or determination that will suit the operation of the Tax Office but will not always necessarily be in the best interests of the Australian community. As has been mentioned by speakers on both sides of the House, the estimation of unremitted amounts is an area which needs to be approached with great caution. That alone is a reason for a more detailed examination of the precise section.

PARA.TAB: The area which seems to me to unwind the basic thrust of the Bill is the provision requiring directors to be responsible for unremitted amounts. The proposition is that when the commissioner cannot get at funds that he wants he can make an estimate. Then, if the company does not fulfil certain requirements within 14 days, the commissioner can go behind the company to the directors and demand from them payment within 14 days. The careless or unjudicial application of this provision, to my mind, completely overcomes or turns on its head the original proposition that the commissioner get in the queue with the rest. Pressure on directors to find funds will ensure that payment is made to the Tax Office first of all. In my view, this overturns the original proposition by putting pressure on individual directors to meet the payment of outstanding amounts from their personal funds, and it will mean that the commissioner has first chop anyway.

I would like the Minister to acknowledge that the pressure, stated or unstated, on directors to pay up overturns the proposition that the commissioner's priority in the queue has been removed. Certainly, there is pressure on directors to pay the Tax Office ahead of anybody else, and the proposed legislation would allow the commissioner, ahead of anybody else, to go to directors and require them either to pay up personally within 14 days or see that the company pays. That is an area which I would like to see drawn out and examined carefully.

The Bill contains defences for directors involved in recovery proceedings instituted by the commissioner. That is proper. If a director is sick, unaware or uninformed then there is a cop-out for the director. Many Australians believe that directors of Australian companies have at times been cavalier in their approach to their responsibilities, and I do not encourage that. However, I do believe that the extraordinary powers given to the taxation commissioner, in this instance, for the recovery of unremitted amounts, puts the commissioner back at the head of the queue. I believe that the commissioner already puts himself in that position completely and that this legislation will ensure that he continues to do so.

The conditions under which the commissioner can go to the directors are in themselves of interest. The commissioner can go to the directors if, within a period of 14 days after notice is given, the company has not done certain things. The company will stop the commissioner—or the process of the commissioner going to the directors will be stopped—in the following circumstances: if the liability for the unremitted amount has been discharged, meaning that the funds have been paid out; if an administrator has been appointed; or if the company is being wound up. Those are the three grounds upon which the commissioner may not go to the directors.

At the expiration of the 14 days notice given by the commissioner to the company, the directors are given 14 days notice of the penalty incurred and their requirement to remit the penalty. I think that is too short a time. It is only a 28-day period, involving notification of the company and notification of the director, before the commissioner moves in and recovers the funds. Meanwhile, the suppliers and other creditors are lined up waiting for their money, as they have always had to do. I do not see the change being brought into effect that was intended by the legislation. Although the intention seems to be to make the directors responsible—an intention with which I agree—there are shortcomings in the process.

The Government and the Tax Office need to be careful in the application of the legislation. We have debated in the House many times, particularly before the election, the impact of the recession on private enterprise and its capacity to employ. In 1990 there were 8,500-odd bankruptcies; in 1991, 30,000; in 1992, over 16,800; to the end of the March quarter of the 1993 financial year, 11,123. The number of bankruptcies in Australia have skyrocketed, and that has been brought about by the recession. It is my view that care is needed—fairness but care. We do not want cavalier behaviour and we do not want the cowboys, but the Tax Office must be careful because not in every instance has it enjoyed a good reputation.

I conclude by summarising the main thrust of the legislation, as I see it. Firstly, there is the proposal for the removal of the commissioner's priority, which is well-intentioned. Secondly, there is the proposal for the estimation of unremitted amounts, which is another reasonable proposition, particularly if the affairs of a company are confused and not properly known. But I am worried about the requirement to be placed on directors which could see the commissioner's willingness to forgo priority overturned.

Within the last few days the Parliament has received the Auditor-General's report on the Australian Government. I am not saying that if the Government were a private undertaking it would be declared bankrupt, but statements by an auditor of this type would cause any company grave concern. We are talking about bankruptcy and the attitudes and financial good management of the Australian Government. Here we are legislating in regard to private enterprise when the Government itself needs to take note of statements from the Auditor-General such as:

SPEECH.PARA: Funding decisions taken by the Government lack the benefit of the information that would normally be available in any well run company which manages the level and impact of its obligations on future cash flows, costs and investment decisions so as to protect its future viability and maximise its return to shareholders.

That is a pretty serious statement from the Auditor-General. The Government should be careful when pontificating on the insolvency of others. The Government has to be careful that it is meeting all its obligations under proper management procedures. The Australian National Audit Office also has something to say about the management of Australian business—Australian Government Inc. One of the opening paragraphs says:

The ANAO considers that the information currently provided is deficient to such an extent that the Parliament and the taxpayer is not in a position to assess the Government's management of its obligations and whether, in the management of programs, the Government has considered the impact on the level of obligations and the consequences to both existing and future taxpayers.

That is a serious statement. If that were a prospectus, nobody would buy a single share in the Australian Government. If it were a statement before the tax commissioner, he would be starting to worry about whether there were some claims he should be making for unremitted funds against that company.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Government has been writing laws in a very fast fashion. The statement was produced on 2 December 1992—into the Senate, no discussion—and eminent lawyers saying, `We don't think you have got it right; we want to stop and look at this', and, bang, it is through, and it has not demonstrated its competency to run its own company, the great company of Australia. The directors of the Australian company, the Australian Government, have been caught short by its own Auditor-General's report which clearly states that it is not up to it and it has not done the job. The tax commissioner, the liquidator or the assessor ought to come in and look at the affairs of the directors to see how they are going and see how good they are at their job. For that matter, they might investigate the personal affairs of the directors.

There have been many hints that the Government is struggling to establish a proper framework and a proper Budget to help solve these problems. The Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) has hinted that we are to have cuts in government expenditure, yet the head of Treasury has said, `We don't know whether we can make the necessary cuts'. The Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) has said that the report of the Auditor-General is hardly worth the paper it is written on. He further says that the Government would keep its promise to provide tax cuts. Mr Willis says that the Government is going to do other things.

The Government is all over the place on this issue. This is a bankruptcy Bill. The comments of the Auditor-General have been such that they would raise concern in any private company. I will not go into further details about what other people out in private enterprise have said about the management of the Australian Government, but I will reiterate my concern that this legislation appears to be overturning the details that the Government enunciated through the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) when he made his statement on 19 May. I think the Assistant Treasurer has overstated the benefit to the Australian community because he has not really assessed the commissioner's powers under this legislation. No-one else has been able to make a full assessment of what this legislation will mean.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank all honourable members who have participated in the debate today on the Insolvency (Tax Priorities) Legislation Amendment Bill. I think the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) missed the point. The Government is not after company tax but the remittances of the employees which should have been sent to the tax office.
—Yes, I understand that.

—Then I do not know what we are arguing about. Unfortunately, I was called away earlier, but I have been told that there were a number of concerns with this Bill, the first concern being that it was unduly hasty. The announcement on 2 December last year allowed quite a bit of time for negotiations. I am sure all interested parties have had ample time to make their concerns known to government. Anybody who has been in Parliament for some time knows that people are fairly quick out of the box in getting their views known when they believe that there is a piece of legislation that may affect them. The Bill was in the Senate for a week, which allowed honourable senators plenty of time to scrutinise the legislation. It is now back here.

PARA.TAB: The second suggestion was that we should pass part of the Bill but not all of it. I indicated in the second reading speech that the Bill will protect the revenue by allowing for the concessions made by the Commissioner of Taxation to be picked up in another way. The third concern was that the estimate should not be used to allow the commissioner to start proceedings to collect the tax. The simple fact is that without this procedure it can be dragged on. As we all know, the slippage in tax means that the tax is not paid on time, and that is a cost to the revenue. I believe the Government is fully justified in bringing forward this legislation today. In years to come we will look at the points made in this debate and we will see that many of the fears that have been raised were unfounded.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Administrative Appeals Tribunal Amendment Bill 1992 will amend the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975. The Bill contains amendments to the Act to give effect to recommendations of the report of the review of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The Bill will also amend the Act to provide for mediation and to provide that documents may be lodged by electronic means. The Bill contains amendments of a minor policy nature and makes minor technical amendments to the Act. None of the amendments concern major policy proposals or sensitive policy issues. They are explained in the explanatory memorandum circulated with the Bill. It is expected that the proposed amendments will not have any financial impact.

PARA.TAB: In January 1990 the Act was amended by the Courts and Tribunals Administration Amendment Act 1989 to provide that the president of the tribunal is responsible for managing the administrative affairs of the tribunal. Similar amendments were made to the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976 and the Family Law Act 1975 to provide that the chief justices of the federal and family courts are responsible for the administrative affairs of their respective courts. The process by which the heads of jurisdiction are responsible for the administration of a court or tribunal is known as separate administration.

Following the commencement of separate administration it was agreed that the operations of the tribunal should be reviewed to assess the delivery of services by the tribunal and the effectiveness and efficiency of the tribunal's existing administrative operational arrangements and structures. The review was conducted by representatives of the tribunal, the Attorney-General's Department and the Department of Finance. Similar reviews were undertaken in the Federal Court of Australia and the Family Court of Australia.

The review was deferred until the new president, the Hon. Justice O'Connor, had the opportunity of familiarising herself with the operations of the tribunal. Justice O'Connor was appointed as president in June 1990 following the death of the former president, the Hon. Mr Justice Hartigan. The review was undertaken between October 1990 and November 1991. The report of the review made some 200 recommendations for reform. Many of those recommendations related to the internal operation of the tribunal and have been implemented by the president of the tribunal. The review also made a number of recommendations for amendments to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act.

The proposed amendments are directed at streamlining the procedures of the tribunal and clarifying the powers of the tribunal in procedural matters. The amendments will enable the tribunal to operate more flexibly and will assist the tribunal to achieve maximum efficiency. The amendments to section 20 of the Act will provide a clearer statement of the president's role and functions in relation to the arrangement of business of the tribunal and will provide that the president may give directions as to the procedures to be followed generally in proceedings in the tribunal and in particular to enable directions that members shall sit at particular places.

At present, subject to any provision to the contrary contained in an enactment conferring jurisdiction on the tribunal, the tribunal may be constituted in any one of the five ways as listed in section 21. Clause 6 will amend section 21 to provide for two additional combinations of members, three deputy presidents or two deputy presidents and a non-presidential member. This will give the president greater flexibility in constituting the tribunal in important or complex cases. Section 29 of the Act specifies the manner of applying for a review. Clause 9 will amend section 29 to provide for an address for service where an applicant has failed to provide an address for service in the application. This will ensure that the processing of such applications is not unduly delayed by uncertainty as to the appropriate address for service.

In the recent decision of the Federal Court in Angus Fire Armour Pty Ltd v Collector of Customs (1988) 83 ALR 449 the court held that, on the proper construction of section 29, an application to the tribunal for a review of a decision is validly lodged notwithstanding the failure of the applicant to pay the application fee prescribed by the regulations. In these circumstances, although the application would be deemed to be validly lodged, there would be no obligation on the tribunal to process the application. Clause 10 will insert new section 29A which provides that an application is not taken to be lodged unless the prescribed fee has been paid.

The tribunal currently makes extensive use of directions hearings. Section 33 of the Act provides for the procedure to be followed by the tribunal. Clause 11 will amend section 33 to give formal recognition to directions hearings and to provide that a member convening a directions hearing may give such directions as are considered necessary, at any time in relation to any procedural matter, whether or not the president has expressly authorised the person to give directions.

Section 34 of the Act provides for conferences to be held. The tribunal has developed the practice of convening preliminary conferences to determine the matters in issue prior to the hearing. As a significant proportion of cases are resolved at the preliminary conference this practice has proved an effective means of dealing with the workload of the tribunal. Clause 12 will amend section 34 by giving the president a discretion to determine whether or not a conference should be held. It will also amend subsection 34(1) by deleting the reference to consideration of the material lodged so that the president may direct the holding of a conference without doing so. These amendments should further enhance the use of preliminary conferences.

Subsection 34(2) provides that where the parties reach an agreement at a preliminary conference, the tribunal must, subject to certain procedural requirements, make a decision in accordance with the terms of that agreement. The Bill inserts new section 42C which will replace subsection 34(2). This section gives the tribunal a discretion to decline to make a decision in terms of the agreement if it appears to the tribunal that it is appropriate to do so. This discretion is consistent with the role of the tribunal to review decisions on their merits and to substitute its decision for that of the decision maker. In making a decision the tribunal, in effect, stands in the shoes of the decision maker. It is inconsistent with the role of the tribunal to require it to make a decision adopting the terms of an agreement between the parties where it considers that, in the circumstances of the case, the agreement would not result in the correct or preferable decision being made.

In 1991 the tribunal began to consider the introduction of mediation as an alternative dispute resolution mechanism. A feasibility study recommended that participation should be voluntary, that mediation should be confidential, that cases should be selected on the basis of their suitability for mediation, that mediation should be conducted by suitably trained and accredited mediators and that there should be ongoing evaluation of the mediation process.

A pilot program was introduced in September 1991 and has been extensively evaluated. The result of the evaluation is that the tribunal has extended the scope of the program. Further extension of the program is expected following further evaluation. In mediation, a neutral third person assists the parties to arrive at their own solution to their dispute. The essence of mediation is that the parties are empowered to produce the result that is best suited to their own circumstances. In the tribunal, mediation provides an efficient and cost-effective method for the resolution of many disputes.

The Government supports the availability of a greater choice of methods of dispute resolution and to this end has already provided the legislative framework for mediation and arbitration to be provided in the Federal Court and in the Family Court. The Courts (Mediation and Arbitration) Act 1991 amended the Family Law Act 1975 and the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976 to provide a framework for those courts to develop alternative forms of dispute resolution, in particular mediation and arbitration. The Act amended the Family Law Act and the Federal Court Act to allow those courts to refer suitable matters to mediation and arbitration and to make rules of court defining the procedure to be followed. This Bill provides a similar legislative framework to facilitate the use of mediation in the tribunal.

The tribunal actively encourages the use of mediation. However, it recognises that not all cases are suitable for mediation, such as those where the matter in dispute is of sufficient public importance for a decision to be made by the tribunal on the merits of the case, or where there is a degree of animosity between the parties which would inhibit the mediation process. The tribunal has developed procedures to ensure that only suitable matters are referred for mediation. Mediations are conducted only by members or staff who have been accredited as mediators.

The tribunal has made extensive use of the telephone for hearings, parts of hearings and for conferences. Clause 15 of the Bill will insert section 35A which expressly provides that the tribunal may allow a person to participate in proceedings by telephone, closed circuit television and any other means of communication. This provision will also allow persons to participate by means of video conference.

Clause 18 of the Bill will amend section 42A to expand the tribunal's powers to dismiss applications. The new powers to dismiss matters include the power to dismiss matters for delay in pursuing the application, where there is not a reviewable decision, and for failure to appear at a directions hearing or mediation. Section 42A will also expressly provide where a matter has been dismissed the applicant may apply for a reinstatement.

At present there is no power for the tribunal to dismiss an application that is frivolous or vexatious. Such matters, although few in number, are very resource intensive and divert resources away from legitimate applications. The new dismissal powers will also include the power to dismiss an application which is frivolous or vexatious. I table the explanatory memorandum for the Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
Leave granted for debate to continue forthwith.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Administrative Appeals Tribunal Amendment Bill 1993 was first introduced into the Senate on 17 December 1992, but faded away at that time. It seeks to implement some of the recommendations of a review of the operation of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. As the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General (Mr Duncan) has indicated, that review was carried out pursuant to arrangements between the then Attorney-General and the president of the tribunal, Justice Deirdre O'Connor. The final report was provided in November 1991. As was also indicated, most of the recommendations, of which there are many, have apparently been implemented administratively.

PARA.TAB: While some of the provisions of the Bill might be regarded as matters of procedural detail, it has to be remembered that unlike most courts and some other tribunals, the tribunal does not have rules of procedure separate from the Act which establishes it. All the procedure is dealt with in the Act itself. Of particular note in this Bill are the provisions dealing with alternative dispute resolution. Mediation is introduced to the tribunal's repertoire. It will be interesting to see to what extent this method of resolution is used and to what extent its use is successful.

In its 17 years the tribunal has broken many barriers. It has enabled many citizens to expose for review the decision making processes as well as the decisions of the Commonwealth Government. It deals with a diverse range of decisions and has the capacity to be very flexible in its procedure. Among its members, both presidential and non-presidential, are people from a variety of backgrounds and experience. The Opposition supports this Bill.

In relation to it, I specifically invite the attention of the House to the speech in the Senate on Tuesday, 18 May 1993, of Senator Peter Durack. Senator Durack, who first sat in the other place in July 1971, is delivering his valedictory speech tonight. He was involved in the creation of the tribunal and as Attorney-General from July 1977 to March 1983 was closely involved in its early years. His commentary, both historical and analytical, is a valuable perspective on the tribunal. It is very pleasing to note that in his estimation the tribunal has largely been able to achieve its original objectives.

In the context of this debate it is appropriate also that it be recorded and acknowledged in this House on his last day of sitting that Senator Durack has made a very significant contribution to Australian public life and, I would add, particularly as Attorney-General for nearly six years and as a highly respected member of the Senate for nearly 22 years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melham Mr D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments contained in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Amendment Bill 1993 Bill are directed at streamlining the procedures of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and clarifying the procedures of the tribunal in respect of procedural matters. The amendments will increase the flexibility of the tribunal and allow it to adopt the most suitable method of considering applications.

PARA.TAB: The main changes proposed by this Bill will clarify the role and powers of the President of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal; provide that an application for review of a decision by the AAT will not be taken to have been made unless the prescribed fee is paid; give an express legislative basis to directions hearings and mediation; and extend the AAT's power to dismiss an application for a review of a decision.
Tonight I want to concentrate on the mediation aspect of this Bill. The honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams) in his comments earlier said:

SPEECH.PARA: It will be interesting to see to what extent this method of resolution is used—
that is, mediation—
and to what extent it is successful.

It is reported in the AAT's annual report for 1991-92 that the AAT began to offer mediation as an alternative dispute resolution procedure within the AAT during 1991-92. A pilot mediation program was commenced in the social security and customs jurisdictions in Brisbane and Melbourne in September 1991 and in Sydney in March 1992. Following evaluation of the pilot program the AAT decided to adopt mediation as part of its pre-hearing process.

PARA.TAB: It is significant that parties are not compelled to take part in mediation. Those participating in mediation are required to sign an agreement of confidentiality. Mediations are only conducted in the AAT by members and staff accredited as mediators. As at 30 June 1992 the AAT had held 64 mediations. Of the 55 mediations held in the social security jurisdiction, approximately 85 per cent resulted in a settlement agreement. Of the four mediations held in the customs jurisdiction, two were settled. Mediation currently occurs in conferences conducted under section 34 of the principal Act.

Proposed new section 34A, which expressly authorises the AAT to use mediation will be inserted into the principal Act. Proposed subsection 34A(1) will allow the president, where it is thought desirable and the parties consent, to direct that a proceeding or any part of a proceeding or any matter arising out of a proceeding be referred to a mediator for mediation. Proposed subsection 34A(2) provides that a mediator is to be a member or officer of the AAT directed by the president to mediate in a particular case.

Where the parties to a mediation agree on the terms of a decision, the terms of the agreement are put in writing signed by or on behalf of the parties and lodged with the AAT. Proposed subsections 34A(4) and 34A(5) provide that if the AAT is satisfied that a decision in the terms of the agreement would be within its powers, it may, if it appears appropriate to do so, make a decision in accordance with the terms of the agreement.

I think this is a positive way to go. Frankly, in a number of jurisdictions it is the only way to go. Our society today is becoming more and more litigious and that litigation is becoming more and more expensive. Alternative dispute resolutions need to be explored by government and encouraged so that the log jams in our tribunals and courts can in some instances be removed or alleviated. As an example, community justice centres in New South Wales have proved very successful in resolving neighbourhood disputes.

There is no doubt that, if the figures I have quoted this evening are carried through after this legislation is enacted, there will be considerable cost savings to the community. In addition, if it is deemed that the merits of a case could establish useful guidelines, that is not the sort of case that will be sent off to mediation; that will remain in the mainstream. But it is the way to go.

The problem that we as a parliament need to address is giving people access to tribunals and courts. That is the big problem at the moment. One needs to be very, very rich or very, very poor. In New South Wales the Legal Aid Commission has now declined to grant legal aid in civil cases, irrespective of the merits. That cost cutting measure has been introduced by the Legal Aid Commission. It is a policy decision that I personally do not agree with, but it is one that members of the commission argue was their only alternative, because the legal aid dollar has not been matched at a State level because of other factors and priorities.

My experience in the legal system in New South Wales is that alternative dispute resolution is the way to go with many neighbourhood disputes and local court matters. The same can be said of the AAT. It is pleasing that these amendments tonight do have opposition support. We are really talking about motherhood stuff and for that reason I will not keep the House much longer save to say that I applaud this aspect of the Bill. It is something that we as a parliament should look to more and more in other levels, tribunals and pieces of legislation. We need to remove people from this adversarial system that is being encouraged with every piece of legislation we introduce into this place and into the State courts.

Ultimately we are all paying. We are all paying when people are denied access. My view in relation to this legislation is that, by streamlining the process and allowing the AAT to have the extra options, more people will be able to avail themselves of the facilities of the tribunal.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I will briefly respond to thank honourable members who have contributed to this debate and the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams) for his thoughtful contribution. I want to associate myself with his brief remarks about Senator Durack. I did not often agree with him on political matters, but I always found him to be a very worthy opponent and someone who was very approachable.

PARA.TAB: When I was serving with Senator Durack on the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General I always found him to be someone who attempted to find common ground. I always appreciated his approach and his very pleasant company from time to time. I am pleased to associate myself with the remarks made by the honourable member for Tangney—and I am using this Bill as a peg to hang my hat on—on this day which is the last day on which Senator Durack will formally sit as a member of this Parliament.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.

TALK.START.PARA: —As required by standing order 28A, and as chairman of the Committee of Members' Interests, I present the report of the Committee of Members' Interests on the operations of the committee during 1992. I seek leave to make a short statement in connection with the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The newly established committee in this Parliament does not have in its membership any member who was a member of the Committee of Members' Interests in the previous parliament. Due to the dissolution of the House of Representatives on 8 February 1993 that committee did not have an opportunity to adopt a report on its operations during 1992.

PARA.TAB: However, the chairman had prepared a draft report which he had circulated to members of the committee. This committee has decided to adopt that draft report in full and it is that report which I have just presented. I wish to point out to the House that in the report I have just tabled the former committee draws attention to three outstanding recommendations it had made previously and upon which the House has not to date taken action.

Those recommendations relate to whether there is a need for the registration of the membership of all organisations, the need for the registration of interests held during the period from the dissolution of the House in one parliament and the provision of statements of interest in the next parliament and the need to update the value of gifts requiring registration to reflect current values since those values have remained unchanged since the introduction of registration requirements in 1984. I hope it will be possible for the House to consider those recommendations.
