TALKER.NAME: Mr ANDERSON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill which we support and commend gives legislative backing to a revised Murray-Darling Basin Agreement between the Commonwealth, New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia for the improved management of the land, water and environmental resources of the Murray-Darling Basin. It was originally introduced last year but, because of the election and so forth, it was not followed through in this place and it has now been reintroduced for debate.

PARA.TAB: By way of background, the Murray-Darling Basin covers about one-seventh of Australia and produces about half of Australia's agricultural and forestry output. The area supports 25 per cent of Australia's cattle, a higher percentage of Australia's dairy production, about 50 per cent of its sheep, lambs and crops and almost 75 per cent of its irrigation land.

The approach adopted and extended tonight has seen a genuinely holistic approach to the management of the basin's resources increasingly become a reality. That is important, because the production from this area is very substantial. It is about $10 billion a year and that needs to be seen in the context of very depressed commodity prices. The future in terms of potential production and value—which I will say a little more about later—is almost unlimited. We have both an economic and very strong cultural and environmental reasons for looking after this resource to the best of our ability.

In 1914 the first River Murray waters agreement was signed and the River Murray Commission established. It divided and regulated the river flow between the three States and this was particularly important for South Australia as a State at the bottom end of the river system. In 1987 the River Murray waters agreement, which established a ministerial council and the Murray-Darling Basin Commission, was signed by New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and the Commonwealth. Complementary legislation was passed shortly afterwards by the States.

The ministerial council was to provide effective planning and management for the equitable, efficient and sustainable use of the water, land and environmental resources of the basin, while the Murray-Darling Basin Commission was to assume regulatory responsibilities and to act as an advisory body to the ministerial council. To allow the people in the basin itself—and of course that involves many farming communities; the people at the coalface, so to speak—a greater say, a community advisory committee was established to provide a better communication link between the council and the people. Again, I think its work has, by and large, been commendable. I have had the good fortune to attend meetings held by that advisory committee. I can think of one in particular in Moree which all who attended would agree was of great value.

The Murray-Darling strategy aims to reduce the average salinity levels in the Murray River by 20 per cent and, at the same time, to drain and dispose of waste water on some 500,000 hectares of land affected by waterlogging and salinisation. Since 1988, more than $74 million has been jointly spent by governments on salt interception schemes and joint government and community based drainage and salinity management plans. Major interception works have been completed at Woolpunda and others started at Mallee Cliffs and other places. Drainage programs are under way in the Shepparton, Deniliquin and Murrumbidgee regions. Currently new strategies for irrigation management and water quality management are being developed, and I think it should be noted that there is no doubt that water quality is improving.

The Bill before us is a result of a review of the Murray-Darling Basin by the ministerial council. The most significant amendments to the agreement are the inclusion of the salinity and drainage strategy. This has been achieved by intergovernmental cooperation, which has now reached the point where it can be given legislative backing by all partners to the agreement.

The amended agreement provides for water allocation through a system of continuous water accounting. This will allow New South Wales and Victoria to draw on their annual water allocation according to need. Unused allocations will be carried forward as credits and above allocation drawings will be carried forward as a debit against future entitlements. By allowing unused allocations to be carried forward, it removes the incentive for people to use irrigation water which perhaps they might not need at any given time. The Ministers involved believe this will facilitate the optimal use of a shared resource without disruption of fundamental access guarantees.

The Bill also gives the commission more financial flexibility by allowing it, with council approval, to carry over limited funds from one year to the next. The legislation also empowers the ministerial council to modify the agreement through the approval of additional schedules to incorporate new strategies.

Following a successful passage of this Bill, the first schedule to be brought forward for approval will be one authorising the addition of Queensland. It is always desirable to lock in the Queenslanders if we can. Almost 25 per cent of the basin—a very substantial part of it—lies in Queensland, very productive country, and that includes the headwaters of the Darling River, which is the major tributary to the Murray River. Queensland's presence will ensure a whole-of-basin approach.

There is also provision for the commission to have an independent president who is to be appointed by the ministerial council. The Commonwealth appoints two commissioners and two deputy commissioners, as do the participating States.

I have been asked to make reference to some people on the Murray River between Lake Hume and Lake Mulwala who are concerned because they have suffered some three years of flooding, whereas the previous seven years had been flood free while the water was being diverted to Dartmouth Dam. The submission is put together by the River Murray Action Group and it is entitled Submission by the River Murray Action Group on the management of water flows in the River Murray between Lake Hume and Lake Mulwala. These people actually live on a two- to three-mile wide flood plain—flood plains often present enormous difficulties for farmers—and prior to the building of the Dartmouth Dam, flooding in this area had been a not unheard of occurrence; it happened from time to time.

The group has formed the River Murray Action Group—I think it calls itself RMAG—and has put a submission to the Government and the Murray-Darling Basin Commission requesting that the flows of water be managed to prevent flooding and loss of income. The group wants greater emphasis on flood mitigation and land management in order to prevent land degradation, which it believes is caused by high regulated flows and flooding. It wants the Hume Dam to be filled not beyond 96 per cent of its capacity so that, if necessary, it could handle another four per cent which would lessen the impact of flooding. It would also like to see land-holders between the Hume Dam and Albury notified of the release of water, and the flood level at Albury to be reduced from 4.3 metres to 3.65 metres.

The submission also calls for regulated flows to be kept at no more than 23,000 megalitres a day; the establishment of a body to advise the commission on total flood plain management; more research into shrubs and plants to protect river banks; and the prohibition of recreational boating and waterskiing in certain areas. The group says that if water management is improved, it will assist with Landcare management of the river banks.

Whilst the commission sympathises and agrees that flood mitigation works would assist this particular problem, it is a matter of cost. It is also a matter of undertaking works which might well have unforeseen implications for other irrigators. In short, it is not a straightforward matter. For example, the cost of the riverbank stability works would run into many millions of dollars and, in the view of the commission, the people in Deniliquin and on the Victorian side of the Murray might well suffer a reduction in their water supplies. I am told that this could mean that $20 million to $30 million worth of production would be lost in these areas, which is more than is lost through the current flooding in the Hume to Mulwala area.

Therefore, the answer is not simple, but I hope and trust that the commission will study this submission and undertake whatever practical steps it can to at least minimise the damage from flooding. For example, it seems to me that warnings of release could be made in accordance with the desires of the action group without any significant cost.

I am pleased to say that this new agreement between the States and the Commonwealth allows the commission to take matters other than the quantity of water for farm irrigation into account, and many people hope to see an allocation of water for environmental purposes, particularly to the regular watering of the magnificent Murray River red gums.

The overall objectives of improving water quality and managing the resources in the basin—this huge and very productive area of Australia—are, of course, totally desirable and we all support them. But I would like to touch very briefly on the problem created by the current very poor terms of trade and difficult circumstances—particularly relating at the moment to many people in the basin in seasonal terms—and the effect that this is having on the environment in the basin.

The entire length and breadth of the system sees environmentally conscious farmers—and the great bulk of Australian farmers today are only too conscious of the need to look after the resources they manage—who cannot do everything that they would like to do on their own farms in relation to water and soil conservation works and the like to address land and soil degradation. Land and soil degradation are surely our greatest peculiarly Australian problem—as opposed to the global environmental problems that we all face together. I am concerned that this lack of financial capability on the part of many farmers is holding back their desire, which we would want to support, to get on with certain environmentally wise actions they would like to take.

I want to hold out a bit of hope. It is my belief that the terms of trade problem that has so restricted farmers' incomes will, in the next couple of decades, in all likelihood turn around. We have had something like nine decades—or 90 years—of declining terms of trade for farmers when the real price of agricultural product, food and fibre has been dropping. But for a variety of reasons—some of them unhappy—that may be coming to an end.

Given the rapidly expanding world population, given the increasing urban sprawl and its effect on the world's rich agricultural areas, given environmental restrictions on what can be produced and the quantities that can be produced in some agricultural parts of the world and, above all, given the rapidly expanding prosperity of the Asian nations to our immediate north, in my view it is quite likely that real agricultural prices will start to lift in the next few years. This is significant. Regardless of our political persuasion, we would all like to see farmers and farm communities benefit from increased returns in their current most unfortunate financial situation, but it does have environmental and major economic implications for the nation as a whole.

As we look at the Murray-Darling Basin Commission, I think it is worth contemplating for a moment that we have two apparently conflicting needs: on the one hand, there is the economic imperative of ensuring that there is enough water to keep agricultural production up and in the future to take advantage of expanding opportunities and, on the other hand, there is the need to ensure that sufficient water is in the system to be able to ensure regular flushing of the river. That will not solve the blue-green algae problem or the salinity problem, but it may be a necessary and integral part of any long-term solutions to those problems.

Consideration of these quite weighty matters, on the surface, with some apparent in-built contradictions, has led to a considerable revival of interest in some parts of the State for a northern inland water transfer plan. This is not a new idea. It centres on the idea that we can build perhaps a junior version of the Snowy Mountains scheme and divert some water from the coastal river systems in the northern part of the State into either the border river system on the New South Wales-Queensland border or the Copeton Dam on the Gwydir River. The engineering aspect would represent a task of only a third of the size of the Snowy Mountains River scheme, as I understand it. At the moment the cost puts it out of economic range; it does not add up in terms of its potential for increasing production.

The other point is that we are talking about a total transfer of perhaps 750,000 megalitres a year compared with the two million megalitres currently drawn from coastal rivers in the Snowy Mountains River scheme. I think the time may be ripe for a re-examination of this proposal for two reasons: firstly, the need for increased water in the Murray-Darling Basin for environmental reasons and, secondly, farmers terms of trade are changing and the pure economics, cost-benefit analysis, of such a construction project may very well change in the future. Nobody is suggesting that this might not have enormous implications for environmental matters and a great deal of study and research would need to be undertaken before anybody could take the proposal any further.

I mention that tonight because we do have to grapple with our economic problems and with the likelihood that increased agricultural production, premium food exports into Asia and so forth, may well present us with opportunities we cannot afford to be without in the future. We need to examine all possible solutions on river flow in the inland system. We support the legislation and wish those involved all the best in seeking the best possible outcome for our Murray-Darling Basin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio The Hon J.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs CROSIO
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I too join with the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Anderson) and previous speakers in supporting the Murray-Darling Basin Bill before the House tonight. I am very proud to do so. As the Deputy Leader of the National Party has said, I was part of the group which formulated the agreement between the three Labor governments and the Commonwealth, which we are amending tonight. When I was in the New South Wales Parliament I was privileged to be part of that joint governmental effort to manage what is a very important national asset.

PARA.TAB: I would like to say a couple of things to the Deputy Leader of the National Party about the addition of Queensland in the agreement. I can assure the honourable member that for about four years we encouraged Queensland to become part of it. It feared that a cost would have to be borne by it. When I chaired the meeting in 1986 I was pleased to invite Queensland to participate as a delegate, which it did, and its interest has grown. It has finally realised that water pollution does not stop at a particular State's border—it is something that all States, in conjunction with the Commonwealth, have to take steps to overcome.

When mentioning farmers, I am concerned about the change of crops over the 90-odd years of settlement along the Murray and Darling rivers. Years ago cotton was not seen to be the basic crop that it is now. Cotton requires a regulated water flow. I remember very vividly visiting the irrigation areas but we did not see the growing of rice such as we have now. I know many rice growers do not agree with me, but I have always regarded rice as a weed in this country because we seem to percolate the ground for approximately 140 days a year and then we have problems overcoming salinity.

In future we should have more consultation and government agreement. We should also go through an education process with our farmers in our environmentally suspect areas. Perhaps we will have to look at changing crops and the way in which those crops are fertilised and watered.

This Bill before the House will revise the Murray-Darling Basin agreement between the Commonwealth and three States: New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia. The history of joint government action to manage the great resource of the basin goes back to soon after Federation. The Commonwealth Government and the State governments in New South Wales—my home state—Victoria and South Australia first joined together in a non-legislatively based agreement in 1914. This was the first River Murray waters agreement and it established the River Murray Commission. The agreement principally encompassed a cooperative approach to the use of the water from the river for agricultural irrigation purposes. Finally, it was the subject of Commonwealth legislation in the Murray-Darling Basin Act 1983. The Bill before the House tonight will repeal the Murray-Darling Basin Act 1983.

The River Murray waters agreement faced a significant test in the 1980s as community concern regarding environmental issues facing the basin was brought to the foreground. The four governments—and I am pleased to say at that time they were all Labor administrations, which made it easier to consult and get agreement—strangely enough were all party to the original 1914 agreement. We took decisive action and entered into a new agreement to adopt a cooperative approach to the broader management issues—the management of the land, water and other environmental resources of the basin.

That cooperative approach is a feature of our Labor governments and is consistent today with the approach that the Keating Government is now taking in addressing the issues facing our nation. There is no better evidence than in our Government's reform and restructure of our economy when we look at the consultation which has occurred with all sectors.

As Minister for Natural Resources in the Wran Labor Government in New South Wales I was privileged to take part in forging that wider agreement we are debating here tonight. This work culminated in an amended River Murray Waters Agreement in 1987 which led to enabling legislation in all parliaments at that time. The new agreement created a ministerial council and the River Murray Commission was replaced by the new Murray-Darling Basin Commission which was responsible to the ministerial council. I am pleased to say that this work laid the foundations for the impressive achievements to date in redressing environmental damage to the Murray-Darling Basin.

This Bill tonight annexes a fresh agreement regarding the Murray-Darling Basin. It sets out the natural resource management policy of the Commonwealth and the three State governments for Australia's most important agricultural region. It is a region which is vital to all Australians, producing approximately 50 per cent of Australia's output from natural resource based industries.

The Bill reflects that the governments involved are taking serious action in meeting the challenges that our community faces regarding the Murray-Darling Basin. The region is facing the legacy of environmental degradation, including rising levels of salinity and other pollution which has culminated in the algal blooms of recent times. Reflecting this, the Senate Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts in its December 1992 discussion paper noted, `In 1991, algal blooms extended over 1,000 kilometres of the Darling River'. This, of course, resulted in the declaration of a state of emergency.

The concern over the degradation of the basin as a whole led to our Prime Minister (Mr Keating) including major programs to address these problems as a critical part of his 1992 Statement on the environment. The statement reflects the real concern that our Labor Government demonstrates for the environment. It is a recognition of the international need for protection of the environment. I would like now by way of background to reflect on the environmental concerns of our Government.

Very few of us would willingly reduce the standard of living that we enjoy. However, it is a sad fact that our lifestyle is underpinned by what is often claimed to be excessive use of our natural resources with which our nation abounds. One significant area where we pay a high price for our standard of living is through the pollution of our oceans and waterways. There has been no more disturbing example of this than witnessed in the widespread algal blooms experienced last summer. The Prime Minister recognised this in his 1992 Statement on the environment. In the statement he highlights that, for Australians living on an island continent, pollution of our waterways must be our prime concern.

The protection of our environment is essential for a vast number of reasons. First and foremost, we have an obligation to preserve our environment for posterity, for our children and grandchildren. The quality of life which we enjoy is one which is based on enjoyment of the natural environment. One of the most defining features of our nation is that we have ready access to some of the most beautiful seas and waterways in the world. On a wider scale, we have an obligation to the world to ensure that we play a part in the international protection of this vast asset.

The environment is also critical to our economic survival—for agriculture and for tourism. Agriculture is an extremely large employer and, despite the broadening of our economic base, rural exports still comprise 22 per cent of our exports. Protection of our natural environment is also critical to the ongoing growth of our tourism industry. It is no mistake that the major tourism campaigns for Australia provide a view of Australians and visitors enjoying themselves by the water; indeed, the Sydney Harbour Bridge and the harbour area have become one the world's best known attractions.

Our Government has a proud record of achievement in the protection of our environment. In 1983, as one of the Labor Government's first decisions, it moved to protect Tasmania's Franklin River which was World Heritage listed. In 1984 the Kakadu National Park was doubled in size, protecting internationally significant waterways. Significant areas have been World Heritage listed to protect them for our grandchildren. These include: New South Wales rainforest areas, Uluru, the Queensland wet tropics, Kakadu National Park stage 2, Shark Bay in Western Australia, Fraser Island in Queensland and the Great Barrier Marine Park which made the reef the largest marine protected area in the world.

Our Government has also taken a leading international role in protecting the environment through opposing mining in Antarctica. The international significance of this area can be gauged through realising that it and the seabed are the world's only two remaining frontiers. Also, I am proud to say, as a nation we participated in the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development and all Australian governments adopted interim planning targets for greenhouse gas emission reduction.

Where this has been appropriate, our Government has ratified relevant conventions. Many have been ratified and one of particular concern in the context of this debate is the convention on the prevention of marine pollution by dumping of wastes and other matter which was ratified in 1985. Protection of our rainforests has also been a major achievement of our Government. The rainforest program was established in 1986 as a comprehensive $22 million project. Importantly, tax deductions have also been made available for measures to address land degradation.

Late last year, the Prime Minister made his historic Statement on the environment, to which I have referred a number of times tonight in this speech, which consolidates and builds on the progress we have already made. Its focus is on programs to combat the degradation of our land and our waterways. It commits a massive investment of $426 million to rehabilitate huge tracts of land. A key element in the statement is a major effort to reclaim the Murray-Darling river system which we now know is in a state of degradation. The Prime Minister in his statement outlines how this degradation has cost the nation dearly in money terms and poisoned vast areas of formerly productive land. The action that will be taken as a result of the passage of this Murray-Darling Basin Bill will be a key step in dealing with these challenges.

The matters set forward in the Bill reflect that the Government is serious in encouraging community wide involvement and change which will continue to result in better management for the basin. There are several features of the Bill which I wish to particularly mention and applaud.

The revised agreement will bring into legislation the salinity and drainage strategy. It recognises that the proper management of these issues is vital to the productive future of agriculture in our nation. There have already been impressive achievements in redressing salinity and drainage through the salinity and drainage strategy, which is a key element of the natural resources management strategy of the current agreement.

Over $74 million of joint government funding has been expended on schemes to manage and reduce salinity levels in the river. There has been major progress towards the goal to achieve a 20 per cent reduction in river salinity. The governments involved have recognised that the development of this strategy has advanced to the point which enables it now to be formally included with the authority of the legislation.

The passing of the Bill will also give another significant outcome. Queensland, in which over one-quarter of the basin is situated—including the headwaters of the Darling River—will be authorised to accede to the Murray-Darling Basin initiative. Following passage of the Bill, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) has indicated that the first schedule to be brought forward will authorise this accession. In a 13 May 1993 press release the Queensland Minister for Primary Industries, the Hon. Edmund Casey MLA, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Goss Government recognises that major catchment areas cannot be managed in isolation from other States. The former National Party Government refused to recognise this and would not join any basin agreement for decades.

How true those words were. The Bill also allows a more flexible approach to the management of water resources through a system of continuous water accounting. It provides that the signatories to the agreement will be able to draw upon their set water allocation on a flexible basis; to draw more or less than their current entitlement—if circumstances require. Such increase or decrease in allowance will be carried forward to future accounting periods. This flexibility—under controlled circumstances—cuts through the red tape which could have had undesirable consequences for the major agricultural users who depend upon the waters of the basin. In this way this amendment permits governments to deal with the fluctuating demands of agriculture while protecting our environment.

PARA.TAB: The Bill is one that I commend to the House. The Government has a proud record in protection of the environment in Australia and this Bill will ensure that Australia can continue to uphold its international reputation in the forefront of nations regarding this important work for our nation's heritage.

The Deputy Leader of the National Party commented on what we should be doing with our waters and how we should be diverting them. I have a tremendous worry about that. I believe it is possible through engineering to solve these problems. The problem I have is what effect this would have on the environment if we were to follow this course. Would we transfer the problem from one area of our State to another? We would never be able to replace that destroyed by such an environmental disaster.

That is why I always treat with a great deal of trepidation and concern comments by people who say we should really transport our waters in a different direction. We should be taking them inland and looking at future studies. Perhaps one day there will be a solution to overcome that so we do not see continual waste during floods when we do not have adequate storages. In times of drought we would feel that we should have really better preserved that water. I believe those solutions will continue because of ongoing consultation with the States and this agreement will allow the States together with the Commonwealth to build on the expertise for a magnificent basin.

Bill returned from the Senate with amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is again my duty to advise the House that an amendment of the Senate needs to be considered in light of the requirements of the Constitution. As I understand it, by its second `amendment' to this Bill, the Senate would have the Sales Tax Assessment Act 1992 amended in such a way that would effectively increase certain liabilities for the payment of sales tax—although some offsets will be allowed.

PARA.TAB: The third paragraph of section 53 of the Constitution provides that the Senate `may not amend any proposed law so as to increase any proposed charge or burden on the people'. The history of the consideration of this provision as between the Houses contains many references to proposals concerning Commonwealth expenditure. It can, however, be argued that the phrase `charge or burden on the people' may also be read as encompassing measures relating to taxation.

The second paragraph of section 53 prohibits the Senate from amending proposed laws imposing taxation. Still the Senate is not prevented from amending laws which merely relate to taxation—that is, Bills which in themselves do not actually impose taxation.

The issue for the House, when faced with a Senate `amendment' to a Bill relating to taxation—such as the present Bill—is to consider whether it regards the amendment as increasing any `proposed charge or burden on the people'.

On the information available to me, and having regard to the opinions of eminent counsel on the constitutional provision, it would seem that the effect of the second of the Senate amendments to this Bill should be seen as increasing a charge or burden on the people. The House may regard this as infringing the limitations imposed on the Senate by the Constitution. Again, it is for the House to consider what action it may wish to take on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank you, Mr Speaker, for your comments on the measure. Unhappily, it does seem that fate conspires to have such issues confront the House in the last days, or even in the last hours, of a sitting period. I suppose that is inevitable, given the way in which business effectively has to be conducted, with the legislation amended by the Senate coming on with a rush. It is often difficult in the circumstances to give these issues due attention.

PARA.TAB: I endorse your reservations on this matter. I appreciate that we can all have differing views on the interpretation of constitutional provisions to particular situations. But these provisions should be respected. These are not party or political matters but, rather, matters of constitutional and institutional significance. The Government finds that in the circumstances it must accept the Senate amendments in their present form. I must make it clear that the actual proposals themselves reflect government policy.

I will shortly move that the amendments be agreed to, but I am sure that honourable members would not want such action to be interpreted as anything other than a commonsense desire to ensure that the community did not suffer on account of a technical dispute over the form of the measure, important though that aspect is. I hope that members in each House will be able to give the approach to these matters some consideration over the winter break. Accordingly, I move:
That:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)the House endorses the statement of the Speaker in relation to the constitutional questions raised by message No. 35 transmitted by the Senate in relation to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993;

(2)the House, having regard to the fact that the public interest demands the early enactment of the legislation, refrains from the determination of its constitutional rights in respect of Senate message No. 35;

TALK.START.PARA: —Having just heard of this for the very first time, the Opposition is at a loss to know whether it is the amendment which applies to containers or to motor vehicles. In the absence of that knowledge, we are not able to contribute to the motion moved by the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) to Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993.

PARA.TAB: I take issue with his statement that this is inevitable because the business of the House is arranged the way it is, as though this is somehow an excuse for getting ourselves into this predicament. It must occur to you, and certainly to the coalition, Mr Speaker, that if the Parliament were to sit, as we so often urge, sufficient hours and on sufficient sitting days we would not strike this problem.

Indeed, had the House been given the opportunity to debate this Bill completely in the first place, it is doubtful whether we would have needed to consider valid or invalid amendment to the legislation from the Senate. That is a crass claim by the Leader of the House. He knows it. In part of his preamble he half acknowledged that. But the real point of my rising is to seek information—to find out which of the clauses is the offending clause, as it were and why that might be so in the case of one clause and not another.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) for his earlier information. I am sure that he understood that we were operating in a bit of a vacuum. With respect to the sales tax on containers, I see that the Government, albeit in a very limited way, has picked up the coalition's GST principles, which attracted so much controversy, and will allow tax on a container of finished product—presumably, manufactured or processed food—to be credited in exactly the same way as it would have if the GST operated. PARA.TAB: The Opposition supports the amendment, and that is one reason why we did not object too much to the earlier motion and saw no reason, given the absence of earlier advice, to question what the Speaker had to say on the matter. We are in his and the Government's hands on that matter, and I want the committee to understand that we in no way endorse the procedure that we are about to adopt.

PARA.TAB: The second matter on which I wish to comment is that of locally produced utility vehicles. We acknowledge that had the Bill remained as it was originally proposed and passed by the House of Representatives without question—either because of an absence of time or any dedication to real debate on legislation in this place—it would have been tantamount to discrimination against Australian produced vehicles. We are talking in particular about vehicles either currently in production, with the longer wheel base, or vehicles that will be produced at some future time, near or otherwise.

We would not be happy—I do not think any member of the House or the Senate would be—to see Australian produced vehicles disadvantaged by competition from imported vehicles of a similar kind, which would otherwise have been the case. We support the amendments, albeit with the one or two caveats contained in the remarks of the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott).
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.
Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to have an opportunity to participate in the debate on the Murray-Darling Basin Bill. I am particularly pleased because I referred to this Bill and to the basin in my maiden speech in this House 10 years ago. As one who has had a lifelong involvement in the Murray-Darling Basin, I have a particular interest in any legislation that comes before the House which has an impact on the basin.

PARA.TAB: All speakers in this debate have focused on the enormity of the basin and the impact it makes on the economic viability of our nation. In his second reading speech the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear), as did subsequent speakers, referred to the fact that 75 per cent of Australia's irrigated land is caught up in the Murray-Darling Basin. Twenty-five per cent of our cattle and dairy herds are also contained within that basin. It is the predominant horticultural area in Australia and, as other speakers have said, it generates in excess of $10 billion annually for Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Maranoa contributes to it.

—Let me take that one step further. To keep the whole debate in perspective, and to let Australians appreciate just how important this basin is, we need to be aware that not only is it one-seventh of the area of Australia—I know that the electorate of Maranoa is a large one but even it is not one-seventh of Australia—but it is as large as the Republic of South Africa and six times the size of New Zealand. So the importance of the basin and the importance of the legislation before the House cannot be overstated.

PARA.TAB: The basin has been characterised by its dependence on its rivers, particularly the Murray and Darling rivers. We are all aware of the impact that development of the basin has had on our environment, a point that was made by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio). Most honourable members know that, as a result of the Murray-Darling Basin having once been part of an enormous inland sea, no matter what the people of the 20th century do by way of development in this basin there will be an ongoing salinity problem. If there were no irrigation at all in the Murray-Darling Basin, and if there had been no European development, there would still be an enormous salinity problem as the remnant of what was once an inland sea makes its way via the Murray and Darling rivers to the ocean.

It has been said that the Murray and Darling rivers carry 1.4 million tonnes of salt to the sea every year. If someone sat at a property on the border between New South Wales and South Australia and watched the Murray River flowing past, that person would be watching the equivalent of a semitrailer load of salt go by every 12 minutes. That sounds unbelievable. I suppose that it is a figure that applies when the river is at its most saline, but the point that needs to be made to keep this debate in perspective is that the salt load exists, not because of irrigation development and not because of European settlement, but because the area was once a vast inland sea.

Contrary to some of the implications made by the honourable member for Prospect, there has been a bipartisan effort to address the problems of the basin. Over two decades successive governments have recognised the importance of pouring money into rehabilitation in the Murray-Darling Basin scheme. Whether it was the Fraser Government, the Hawke Government, or the Keating Government, there has been a commitment to do something about the salinity of the Murray-Darling Basin. This salinity occurs both naturally and as a result of European settlement.

It is easy to take a negative view of the basin. We have all seen those classic television documentaries showing dying red gums and vast areas of dry land salinity highlighting the problems that have occurred in drainage areas as a result of flood irrigation and, in recent times, making so much of blue-green algae infestations. They have left us with the impression that the Murray-Darling Basin was some sort of disaster area.

But in reality it is rather an idyllic place to live, with salinity levels largely under control—thanks to the joint efforts of governments over the last two decades. A point I want to make, which I think was overlooked by the honourable member for Prospect—I do not say that critically—is that it is not a matter of the way we may manipulate rivers in the future or choose to make water flow inland. The reality is that the River Murray—and to a lesser extent the Darling River—has already been manipulated.

In a continent like Australia rivers normally have a high flow in the wintertime and a low flow in the summertime, and that was characteristic of the Murray. As a result of astonishing engineering efforts, and as a result of people's enthusiasm for development, we now have a Murray River that has a discouraged flow in the wintertime through locks and an encouraged flow in the summertime. The vast lagoons and billabongs of the Murray that once filled up in winter and emptied out in summer now remain as enormous lakes.

Whether we like it or not, in order to sustain the lifestyle we have and in order to generate $10 billion worth of exports annually, we have created an environment in which the Murray and the Darling, rather than being perpetually flowing streams that have high rivers in periods of high rainfall and low rivers in periods of low rainfall, are now a series of lakes locked in place by the weirs and locks that cross them.

So the environment has changed. It may not have changed for the better in ecological terms, but change is inevitable. We all depend on the changes that have occurred. Horticulturalists depend upon them in order to have a reliable supply of irrigation water. Cities in the eastern States and in my State of South Australia are totally dependent on this water source. If it were not for the series of lakes that we now call the Murray-Darling Basin, there would be no development in the iron triangle cities of South Australia, and very little development in the city of Adelaide. People from South Australia and the eastern states depend upon the river for recreation, and rely on the fact that it will always have an adequate flow not only for recreational purposes but also to sustain the lifestyle that we now take for granted.

This area was once a huge inland sea and there is still this huge salt load in the catchment area of the Murray-Darling Basin. This salt load is endeavouring to make its way to the sea and is being caught in this system known as the Murray-Darling Basin which we have now successfully locked into a series of lakes.

To their credit, this Government and previous governments have gone out and identified where these natural highly saline inflows exist and intercepted them with pumps and bores which have picked up the highly saline inflow. I am familiar with the Wilpunda and Waikerie areas. The Wilpunda scheme has 24 interceptor bores already completed, discharging saline water into an evaporation basin deliberately set well back from the river in a relatively impervious clay area in order to minimise the natural saline inflows that occur in the Murray-Darling system. This has involved an investment of $74 million in salt interception in order to meet the target jointly recognised as ideal by all governments—reducing salinity in the Murray-Darling Basin by about 20 per cent.

Apart from the interception of the natural saline flows, other initiatives have contributed to the environment of the Murray-Darling Basin. Irrigators are now much more selective in the irrigation techniques that they apply. The widespread use of flood irrigation that provided all sorts of inherent drainage problems has been replaced by overhead sprinkler irrigation, microjet irrigation where a small sprinkler is apportioned at low level to each tree or vine, or dripper irrigation which allows an even more accurate use of water. The more accurately the water is apportioned to each plant the less the drainage build-up and the greater the opportunity to keep this water from flowing back into the river and picking up salts on its journey.

I commend the role of governments, both State and federal, and of irrigators in endeavouring to do something about the state of the Murray-Darling Basin. Only last week I visited Renmark with Senator Sherry who is conducting an inquiry into the citrus industry. At Yandilla Park the growers have deliberately chosen not to plant some areas that would automatically have been planted as recently as a decade ago. They are providing an even soil type and irrigating the plants only with sufficient water for their needs, thus minimising potential drainage run-off.

The significance of the Murray-Darling Basin Bill is that it provides for a revised agreement on the way in which the Commonwealth, New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia go about the management of the Murray-Darling Basin. For the first time it includes legislative recognition of salinity and drainage strategies deliberately designed to improve the environment of the Murray-Darling Basin. In addition, for the first time the States of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia will have continuous water accounting so that a State that uses less than its allocation of water can claim a credit, and it can use up that credit in a dry year when more water is needed—presuming more water is available without robbing other States of their allocation.

This system of deliberate water accounting is a credit to the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall), a former premier of South Australia. He put his political career on the line in order to initiate the present negotiations between the States that allowed the States to recognise that the River Murray particularly, and the Murray-Darling area in total, was an area that could not go on sustaining the development that was being demanded of it.

I well recall the debate that ran so furiously in South Australia over the future of the Dartmouth Dam and the provision of sufficient water, and I recall the honourable member for Boothby's determination that South Australia should have a guaranteed allocation of water. It is to the credit of the honourable member for Boothby and my State that the government of the day was prepared to legislate to ensure that South Australia got its allocation of water. It is somewhat to the discredit of the New South Wales and Victorian governments of the day that they were not prepared to take similar steps, and so now in some seasons and in some instances they find themselves making a greater demand on the Murray-Darling Basin than it is able to meet.

I commend the Government and I endorse the changes that are currently before the House for continuous water accounting, but I would put this codicil in: as a South Australian, I want assurances from the Government that my State will not ever be denied its allocation of water—I guess that is fairly obvious and the Government would say, `No, that won't happen'—and that my State will have the opportunity to continue the practice of having from time to time the sort of high river that allows South Australian irrigators to flush out some of the lagoons and backwaters with a flushing flow that carries what would be a saline build-up in those lagoons and backwaters out to the sea, so minimising the total salt load being borne by the Murray-Darling Basin Commission.

An important result of these legislative changes will be the opportunity for Queensland to be included in the Murray-Darling Basin Commission. I do not want particularly to focus on the comments of the honourable member for Prospect, but she was just a shade critical of the former National Party government in Queensland for its reluctance to participate in the Murray-Darling Basin area. I think that was a little unfair. It is this legislation that allows Queenslanders to participate. It is this legislation that gives teeth to what we would want the Queenslanders to do: that is, give them a legislative platform on which to become involved totally and legislatively in the Murray-Darling Basin area and ensure that the Queensland Government—in this case, the Goss Government—passes legislation that will be complementary to the legislation passed in New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia, thus encouraging four-State management of the Murray-Darling Basin Commission.

On my way to Canberra this week I visited Albury to see some of the work being done in the Murray-Darling Freshwater Research Centre. For all that has been negative in this debate and for all of the concern that has been expressed about such things as blue-green algae, at the Murray-Darling research centre in Albury, in the electorate of the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), I saw some very encouraging work being done on the control of blue-green algae. I pay tribute to the director of the centre, Dr David Mitchell, and to all of his staff, but particularly Dr Terry Hillman and Dr Rod Oliver, whose work I found particularly interesting.

I refer to two particular areas of research currently being undertaken by the Murray-Darling Freshwater Research Centre. The first is the work being done in monitoring the outflows of the newsprint mills at Albury. The honourable member for Indi (Mr Lieberman), who is to follow me in this debate, will be very familiar with this matter and the concern that has been expressed about the development of the newsprint mill. As a result of the consultancy work being done by the Murray-Darling Freshwater Research Centre, there is now an opportunity to monitor the river both above and below the mill. I am pleased to report that at this time the mill outflows are not causing any traceable impact on the Murray-Darling Basin environment. I think that is very much to the credit of the mill management.

The other encouraging work I discovered at the centre was that being done in blue-green algae control. Here it is worth noting that the centre has been collecting the zooplankton from the base of the river, identifying it and putting it into various species so that, for the first time, we have a list of what sort of species make up the Murray River environment in the Albury area.
Mr Lieberman interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I will pick up the point made by the honourable member for Indi. It is encouraging that among the zoo plankton that has been collected is zoo plankton that actually lives off the blue-green algae. Unfortunately, this zoo plankton is also currently depleted by introduced fish stocks in the River Murray. If we could do something about introduced fish stocks, we would take a major step towards cleaning up this problem of blue-green algae.

PARA.TAB: As the honourable member for Indi said, the only work being done inland in Australia in freshwater research is being done by the centre at Albury. If I were to make a plea to the Government, it would be that they recognise the work of the centre, of which they are already assisting in the funding to the tune of about $2 million a year.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is $300,000 short.

—As the honourable member for Indi has interjected, the Government should recognise that every year for the next three years the funding for this centre is to be reduced. I know that we are living in difficult economic times, but given the priority that water ought to be given it is hard in my opinion to defend this reduced funding. The centre has responded by endeavouring to do as much consultancy work as possible, but what is needed more than anything is an opportunity for the centre to expand into the mid-Murray area, into the Mildura or Loxton area, and to allow some sort of supervision of blue-green algae growth below the Darling to occur as well as the current investigative work being carried out above the Darling.

PARA.TAB: My plea to the Government is not only to fund what is happening at Albury but also to look seriously at a mini-laboratory at a $1 million outlay in the Mildura-Loxton area—I do not want to be parochial about it—to pick up the very important work that is necessary if we are serious about preserving the Murray-Darling Basin. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns The Hon G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to involve myself in this debate on the Murray-Darling Basin Bill. May I say how much I enjoyed the speech of the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew). He lives in the basin and knows a great deal more about it than I. I am sorry I have to exclude the honourable member for Indi (Mr Lieberman), as I understand we are to close the debate after this.
—I will be here in August.

—Good. It will come back in August. I want to involve myself in this debate not only because I am old geographer and I live outside the basin in Brisbane—it starts at Toowoomba as far as Queenslanders are concerned—but also because I want to retrace some of the ground which finally got Queensland into the arrangements under the new Bill. It took us a very long while.
—It was a letter from me.

—Was it a letter from the honourable member for Indi when he was in the State Government? It reflects somewhat on the culture of Queensland, about which I do not want to make a great play. Fifteen per cent of this basin is located in Queensland. Although only about four per cent of the water flowing through the system emanates from Queensland, it is some of the most important run-off that has an effect further down the system.
—It starts in Maranoa.

—It does, and I guess the reason why Queensland eventually joined in June or July last year—Premier Goss signed a memorandum—was that we thought it was a good and neighbourly thing to do and realised that the important element here in the preservation of our natural environment was total water catchment management and that water catchments have no regard whatsoever for State borders.
—Like Lake Eyre?

—Yes, that is a good debate—and that Queensland ought to finally join in this. But it was not all that easy, because I have some correspondence from the Queensland Minister for Primary Industries, Mr Ed Casey, who was reflecting on some negotiations he had had about Queensland joining the agreement, and in a letter of 23 June 1992, of which I have a copy: he noted:

SPEECH.PARA: The community feedback from the workshops was clearly of the opinion that Queensland should not join the initiative mainly because they perceived it as a threat to Queensland development potential.

In other words, there was still significant community opinion that Queensland should not become a member of this agreement, which is now a three-State-with-us-added agreement plus the Commonwealth. It is more by way of saying it took a Labor government a couple of years to work through some of the issues that surrounded the question of Queensland finally joining in with the Murray-Darling Basin Commission and the marvellous work that it does. But there was significant community resistance. It was a disgrace that the previous National Party government of 30 years had refused in all those years to ignore State boundaries and understand the importance of the management of total water catchment areas and that we cannot just regard State boundaries as being of no consequence whatsoever.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that apply to Lake Eyre?

—Let us stick to the Murray-Darling because that is the one that concerns me most. I remember talking to Ed Casey when he first came to power in 1989. His public servants from the Department of Primary Industries approached him and said, `Minister, are we now allowed to telephone our Commonwealth public servants and talk to them about these matters?'. Under the Bjelke-Petersen Government, Queensland public servants were forbidden to talk to Commonwealth public servants about these matters. That was the sort of paranoia under which we lived in those days. So we had to change not only a culture of relationships between the Commonwealth and the State, and change the community recognition of the importance of Queensland's joining in with the commission, but also we had to determine for ourselves the importance of joining in.

PARA.TAB: Queensland, for its part, has promised to pay, I think, $150,000 a year into the funding of the commission. In return, Queensland can now play a part in the various programs and in the management of the entire basin and system; it means that it will be eligible for federal funding which, no doubt, played a big part in Queensland's entry into the entire scheme.

I wanted to give some background to Queensland's delay in joining, and to outline the work that has taken place since it joined because it does affect a group that I am closely associated with and which I want to mention in the debate. Ed Casey, State Minister for Primary Industries in Queensland, has outlined a strategy which the Queensland Government will develop now it has signed the agreement to be part of the management of this marvellous river basin. The strategy has now been published in a document that was the outcome of community discussions during the period July to December 1992; that is, immediately following the Goss Government's signing into the agreement.

The key element of the strategy is to address natural resource management issues in the Murray-Darling Basin in Queensland through a community based structure. The initial steps outlined here are as follows: first, to form catchment coordinating committees drawn from a broad community base in the Condamine, border rivers, Maranoa-Balonne and Warrego-Paroo catchments; to form a regional catchment coordinating committee which provides a forum for overview of natural resource management in the total catchment; and to develop catchment management strategies to address both the short- and long-term natural resource issues identified by the community and government. He goes on to say that the outcome will be a viable, productive community, and long-term sustainable and balanced use of our land, water and related biological resources, which of course is the hope in these matters.The Queensland State Government has initiated these regional catchment coordinating committees and local strategies.

A group in which I am involved, the Australian Trust for Conservation Volunteers, was first formed in Ballarat by a farmer in, I think, the early 1980s. This group sends out volunteers in order to do good works in the reclamation of land, often at the behest of farmers, but not for commercial work. It does a great deal of work—as much as community volunteer effort counts.

I am sending a signal here to my Queensland State colleagues that they need to appreciate the work of the Australian Trust for Conservation Volunteers. As part of their initiative in stimulating community work about the management of these subcatchment areas my colleagues ought to get in touch with the ATCV to continue the good relationship that has started to build up with the trust. I refer to some notes which the ATCV has provided for me about its work in the Murray-Darling Basin:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Trust for Conservation Volunteers exists to involve the community in the care and maintenance of its environment. This is achieved by the organisation of practical conservation projects and associated activities involving schools and community groups.
It claims, and this is true, that it is well suited to working in the Murray-Darling Basin, which is sparsely populated and covers an enormous area.

PARA.TAB: The ATCV is, in effect, a highly mobile community group, able to concentrate its resources in particular areas for a specific length of time. Resources include a team of up to 10 volunteers, an ATCV team leader, an ATCV vehicle, trailer, tools, first aid equipment, food and camping equipment. These teams have worked in the Murray-Darling Basin for many years, carrying out a wide variety of projects ranging from maintenance of the Alpine walking track at the headwaters of the Murray to seed collection in some of the driest areas of the basin near Broken Hill. Other projects have included a mallee fowl survey in conjunction with landcare groups, wetlands rehabilitation at Wellington in New South Wales and improvements to an arboretum in southern Queensland. Besides the numerous hands-on projects, the ATCV has also targeted numerous students in the basin. At Cobar in New South Wales local students were given the opportunity to visit and work with local mining companies on mine rehabilitation. At Echuca in Victoria, the ATCV assisted a local school to regenerate a degraded bushland adjoining the school.

In early 1993, an ATCV team travelled to remote schools in the western district of New South Wales, raising environmental awareness by a mixture of talks and workshop activities. As a result, most of the schools resolved to form environmental committees which subsequently identified projects and formed strategies, taking into account local issues which had been discussed during the visit. The ATCV has a Murray-Darling Basin project officer, funded by the Federal Government through the natural resources management strategy. This officer is based in Canberra and travels throughout the basin, generating projects in conjunction with the appropriate ATCV State managers.
In Queensland, the ATCV has worked consistently in that part of the State which lies in the Murray-Darling Basin. It makes comment, and this needs to be said:

SPEECH.PARA: However, the signing of the Murray Darling Basin agreement by the Queensland Government has yet to make any noticeable difference to the work of the ATCV in Queensland. A series of community workshops were held in the Murray Darling Basin in September 1992. The outcomes of these workshops were to form the basis for the initial strategic plan. The strategy has just been released by the Queensland Government and as a result no projects have been implemented under the Murray Darling Basin initiative in Queensland involving ATCV.

I make a plea to the Queensland Government, now that it has become involved in the management of the entire area, to include all of those who want to work to help to rehabilitate and better manage this area.

PARA.TAB: One of those groups is the Australian Trust for Conservation Volunteers. I think that group is worthy of support. It is a means by which we can take city people and put them out in the bush to help the likes of those good people, such as the honourable member for Wakefield, who understand the area better but could do with a bit of assistance from people in the city. If the Queensland Government can see its way clear to assist these sorts of projects using volunteer labour from the city, then I would certainly encourage it to do so. I support the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Bruce Scott) adjourned.
Motion (by Dr Theophanous) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it rather fascinating this evening—on the very same day as we missed out on Question Time and missed out on an opportunity to debate a matter of public importance due to the importance of Bills that were going through this House—that, all of a sudden, at 9.50 p.m., the House is debating the motion to adjourn. I find it astounding that in the House today when we were trying to ask very important questions of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) at Question Time we were told by the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) that these Bills were far too important to allow Question Time or to allow the MPI to continue. Yet at 9.50 p.m., before debate on the Murray-Darling Basin Bill has concluded, and before the Primary Industries Legislation Amendment Bill has been introduced, we are debating the motion to adjourn.

PARA.TAB: When the Leader of the House was in the chamber he said that the Prime Minister was happy to take any questions from the Opposition. I would have to ask honourable members opposite: how genuine is that comment now? If the Prime Minister were genuinely interested in taking some of those questions, maybe he should have allowed Question Time and allowed discussion of the matter of public importance and other issues that really need to be raised.

We have talked about this Government's lack of organisation and maladministration. I would have to say that the sort of attitude displayed this evening would be the height of that maladministration. This Government is treating the Parliament with utter contempt. It is saying, `We will run things the way we want. If we want to say that something is important at 2 o'clock in the afternoon, that is fine; but by 10 minutes to 10 in the evening all of a sudden we have a change of heart.' The Government's behaviour is just unbelievable.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can we have an MPI now?

—As the honourable member for Fisher says, maybe we should be asking the Government whether we can have an MPI and Question Time now that it has discovered that it is not really as important as it thought it was to continue to deal with these Bills. I just do not believe that we can have such a lack of organisation by the Government that it can say that these Bills are so important. I wonder what caused the change of heart.

PARA.TAB: We have been arguing all day. In fact, the Manager of Opposition Business, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) said that the business to be dealt with was not so important that we could not have Question Time to ask very important questions of the Prime Minister on the issue of this Government's administration. The only conclusion that I can come to is that the Prime Minister was frightened to come into this place and answer some of the questions about the Government's administration. That is the reason he wants to shut the place down and not allow questions to be asked; that is the reason he did not want us to discuss the matter of public importance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about the guillotine.

—That is right. As the honourable member says, the Government has used the guillotine regularly in this place to stop decent debate. If it wants to run the Parliament in that way, let us make sure that the public is aware of the way this Government is treating this institution. I happen to think—as do my colleagues—that the institution of parliament is too important to be treated in the manner that those opposite have done in the past few years, but particularly today. I think the Government really needs to look at the way in which this Parliament has been treated and I hope that the media recognise that the Prime Minister is actually saying to this place, `We do not want to discuss the issues because they are a bit too difficult for us to handle.'

PARA.TAB: The problems associated with pay TV, the general administration and the report by the Auditor-General are just a bit too difficult to deal with. For the Leader of the House to come in here and say that the Prime Minister is prepared to take questions is ludicrous. I believe that we need to send the message clearly home, and there is no better illustration than a day like this when, at 2 o'clock, we had such important business to deal with but, all of a sudden, it turns out to be not important business at all. I hope that this Government will start to take seriously the business of this place, as do we in the Opposition. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise in this House an issue of extreme importance: the rapidly rising rate of crime in Tasmania, the inadequate policing and crime prevention system in my home State and the consequential discrimination that has occurred through the policies of insurance companies.

PARA.TAB: Tasmania is experiencing serious economic problems which are currently being exacerbated by a State government that has weak leadership and is lacking direction at this critical time. The results of these two problems are a rise in the number of burglaries and vandalism and other frightening signs of social breakdown. When this type of breakdown occurs no sector of the community feels it harder than low-income housing areas. It is also true to say that these areas are least well equipped to cope with these types of problems in terms of their ability to buy their way out of these problems or to strongly advocate for themselves.

A significant consequence of the problems I have briefly outlined is that some insurance companies have identified so-called `high risk areas'. Those areas are not affluent areas, nor middle class, but broadacre public housing areas. It is not clear that there are any more burglaries or any more vandalisms occurring in public housing areas than there is in other areas of our community. I challenge insurance companies to provide information that would show that this is the case. However, the point is that people on low incomes are not in a position to buy back items that are stolen from their homes or, at worst, find accommodation if their home is lost in a fire.

My office has carried out a survey of 17 insurance companies that operate in southern Tasmania. I am pleased to say that some of these companies are avoiding policies of discrimination but I am appalled by those companies that have developed discriminatory policies that have clearly identified low income earners as insurance risks and have indiscriminately penalised those people for who they are.

I refer to the information that was gathered in the survey by my office. Of the 17 companies that were surveyed, only five claimed that their company did not have a policy of identifying areas of so-called high risk. Companies such as AAMI, Avco, MMI and QBE all claimed that any person seeking a policy would be treated equally no matter what area that person lived in. These companies claimed that they did not necessarily require deadlocks and other security fittings before a new policy would be considered. I commend those companies for their even-handed approach and applaud them at a time when there are obvious problems in the community that have implications for insurance companies.

But there are other insurance companies that have decided upon a different approach in their dealings with the community. Companies like the RACT, MLC, Mercantile Mutual, Sun Alliance, Commercial Union, AMP, FAI, Davey and Scurrah, the Tasmanian Government Insurance Office and CIC are less receptive when a potential client rings from a public housing area.

There are degrees of discrimination that are applied by these companies. For instance, AMP says that some of its best clients come from public housing areas. However, AMP has a policy that people who live in certain postcode areas which also happen to include public housing areas must pay an extra $5 a year for their policy.

In the case of Mercantile Mutual a member of my survey team was initially advised that this company did not decline to provide insurance in any area, but that before any further details were provided the name and address of the inquirer had to be given. As soon as the public housing suburb of Bridgewater was mentioned, the following questions were asked: have you any convictions for arson or breaking and entering, and have you made any claims in the last five years? I do not think that any member of this House who rang an insurance company inquiring about household insurance would be asked those questions. I do not think that anyone who rang from a middle class suburb would be asked those questions either.

I have identified a serious problem concerning the policies of certain insurance companies but I do not think for a minute that it is the underlying problem facing our community. Insurance companies are simply responding to serious problems in our community and are making commercial decisions. As I have pointed out, though, some of those commercial decisions are dubious at the very least. The real problem, the problem that insurance companies are responding to, is the lack of unity in our community, the lack of education and personal and group direction and inadequate crime prevention and policing.

It is clear that the Groom Liberal Government is struggling with the issues of unity, education, policing and crime prevention. Unity is certainly not an identifiable trademark of the Groom Liberal Government, particularly at this time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services (Dr Theophanous) in the debate on the Murray-Darling Basin Bill was very charitable in the comments he made about my speech. But the charity has been stretched to the point at which I must respond uncharitably—not to what he said, but to the actions of the Government. In the middle of debating a Bill early on a Thursday evening, after having been denied both Question Time and the opportunity to discuss a matter of public importance, we find ourselves—if honourable members will pardon the pun—cut off in midstream.

PARA.TAB: I ask you, Mr Speaker: what is the purpose of this exercise? I can stand here and be indignant, but I have had something to say about the Bill. How does the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) feel? Everyone in the Parliament was waiting for his contribution, and he is to be denied that until the third week in August; and he is not alone. The honourable member for Indi (Mr Lieberman), whose electorate adjoins the Albury area and who has a distinct interest in the Bill, is to be denied a contribution. The shadow Minister for the environment, the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus), has no opportunity to participate in debate on the Bill until the third week in August. Until almost September we are to be denied the wisdom of the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott), a Queenslander, who for the first time could have spoken authoritatively on what is happening to the Murray-Darling Basin. Not to mention the new honourable member for Mallee (Mr Forrest) who has a direct interest in this Bill, who had prepared comments on it and is to be unable to make a contribution.

Now the Government may say that the Bill is not urgent. If the Bill is not urgent, that is no excuse for suddenly giving us an early mark on this last sitting Thursday. I would have thought that in the driest State in the driest continent in the world there was a real urgency about any Bill that dealt with water. Now we are to be denied the very changes that the honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) said we most needed until August. Why? Here we are prepared to debate the Bill. Here we are, not even at the normal adjournment time of the Parliament, not only unable to participate in this debate which would ensure that the money is to be committed to the Murray-Darling Basin but also unable to give the legislative identity to the Queenslanders until August. Apparently it was not so urgent after all. Apparently the way in which the honourable member for Prospect chose to chasten previous conservative governments and suggest that it was only the Goss Government that had been prepared to do anything about this was in error, because it is no longer urgent enough to involve the Goss Government until September this year.

Furthermore, we are treating the Murray-Darling Basin, this Bill, the area and the Australian economy as if there were no crisis at all, no need for debate, no need for participation. Look at any one of the agricultural and horticultural industries in that basin. Any one of those issues could be the subject of debate in this Parliament. What do we choose to do? Not only do we refuse to debate those issues prior to the normal adjournment time, but we have sat, as the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) has said, only 10 days in eight months. We would have been happy to be here on Tuesday and had some debating. We would be happy to return next week. We are going to have a situation in which the Parliament will not even be convened in June. The Government chooses this in the light of what is not only a crisis in the Murray-Darling Basin—and that Bill is not to be debated—but also a crisis in the Australian economy. I cannot believe that the Government can be so cavalier. Here we are with Australians desperate for leadership and the Parliament chooses to adjourn early.

I speak not only for those people in Wakefield who elected me, the people in Bennelong who elected the honourable member for Bennelong or the people in Indi who elected the honourable member for Indi, but for those people who did not vote for me. They are entitled to a voice in this Parliament. They are entitled to be heard, and the simple reality is that they are to be denied that voice because the Government, in this cavalier fashion, chooses to adjourn the House early.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter I wish to raise relates to penalties for women who have received sole parent benefits while cohabiting with a male partner. Many of these women have been in vulnerable situations and may have been coerced by a man into claiming the benefit after entering into a relationship. I have a constituent, a young woman, who, at the age of 17, entered into a relationship with an older man. After the birth of a child, he forced her to obtain the sole parent benefit by falsely declaring that she was not in a marriage-like relationship and, in any case, he was not prepared to provide for her and the child.

PARA.TAB: When the relationship ended, he left his job in order to avoid paying maintenance for their then two children. Now that DSS has discovered that she obtained benefits under false pretences, the woman faces enormous repayments and the possibility of prosecution, while the real perpetrator, the older man, walks away. This case highlights a structural problem in the administration of social security benefits. Some people, chiefly women—and chiefly those otherwise eligible for sole parent pensions—may come into circumstances where, due to the differing social status of men and women, they are vulnerable to being bullied into accepting a man into their home, wallet and heart. A man who has no financial means of support—either none at all or none he is prepared to spend on support of the family—

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, dear!
—Just listen very carefully—exerts a great deal of influence, pressure or outright violence over the woman.
—Is this the new class?

—I hope, in his next life, the honourable member for Bennelong comes back as a woman. This places the man in the situation where, if he did inform DSS of his existence, she would lose any access to financial support for herself and her children. In many cases, the children of the woman are the children of a previous relationship. The man, who has come into her life, claims that he has no obligation to support them. She is entitled to child maintenance from the natural father but he may be a non-payer, absent, dead or in gaol or he may take the view that, if his ex is now in a new relationship, he, the original father, is not going to contribute a cent to the household of his rival.

PARA.TAB: Should the DSS investigate the circumstances and take the view that the arrangement constitutes a marriage-like relationship, it is solely the woman who bears the burden of making repayments and the threat of prosecution, notwithstanding that the man has had the benefit of the payment and has been instrumental in her obtaining the benefits. The woman may be able to take legal action against the man. However, the law dictates that during the relationship all assets, however derived, are shared.
