She can make a claim under the Family Law Act of a de facto relationship to recover the money from the man by way of spouse maintenance or property settlement but, if there are no available assets, then she is kicking an empty can. It is significant that legal aid is not usually available in these circumstances. Often there is no prosecution, only debt recovery action and the DSS has no power over the man unless as a result of prosecution.

In raising the issue, I am by no means condoning the actions of women who claim benefits illegally and I fully endorse the recovery of funds in these cases. However, I feel strongly that the men involved in these instances should share responsibility for repayment of the debt. This is particularly relevant when it is obvious that the woman has been in a vulnerable position and effectively under the control of her partner.

I think solutions can readily be found to this problem and I will be taking these up with the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin). An amendment could be made to the Social Security Act to create an additional offence of knowingly deriving or participating in the derivation of a benefit improperly or fraudulently obtained from the Commonwealth. The definition of beneficiary and pensioner could be amended to include those who voluntarily derive a benefit to which they are not entitled. It would also be possible to appropriately amend the debt recovery provisions of the Act, regulations and other documents to include persons benefiting from such payments. I hope that some resolution can be found to this problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight for a very special cause: to appeal to the Government on the grounds of equity to support funding for the Wanaaring contact children's mobile. I am not advocating any extra government spending, I am advocating a fair share for remote areas. There has been much talk in this country over recent months about child-care spending and the Government was splashing around hundreds of millions of dollars during the election campaign. I remind the Government that my electorate of Parkes takes in 40 per cent of New South Wales. While Dubbo is the major centre, the north-west corner of my electorate has a great need for children's education services. There are many remote properties, most of them tens of kilometres from their neighbour, hundreds of kilometres from the nearest small town and even a small town such as Tibooburra is 1,200 kilometres from Sydney.

PARA.TAB: The children's contact mobile was set up in 1987, funded not by the Government at all but by the Bernard van Leer Foundation. That funding cuts out on 30 June of this year. The mobile has a Toyota landcruiser, two teachers and backup and technical staff and travels to the most disadvantaged localities in New South Wales. It travels to towns such as White Cliffs, Louth, Yantabulla, Hungerford and Wanaaring and points further north over the Queensland border, covering an area greater than the size of Tasmania. The mobile visits something like 200 parents and children every month.

The contact children's mobile aims to overcome the social, cultural, educational and geographic isolation that those children suffer. Those children live on farms, many with no electricity at all. Some have no television because their parents cannot afford the dish. Most have no bitumen roads. More than half do not even have the support of the local government because they live in the unincorporated area, and most of them have a very deficient postal service. They are lucky to get one service per week.

These children have no physical contact with other children and have few social skills compared with those who live in more populated areas. They have limited opportunities to develop their language skills and limited speech opportunities. On top of that, there is the issue of the loneliness of the parents, particularly the women, and this is particularly heightened now at a time of severe rural recession.

The contact children's mobile calls in at a property, others come into the area, and the children have the opportunity to meet other children, play together, enjoy each other's company, participate in group activities, and partake in plays, music and other shared activities with the equipment and guidance of the contact children's mobile. The parents are welcome and encouraged to attend and assist, and they pick up useful ideas to take back home to use in their children's further education.

Health education is also a very important part of this mobile's activities. It puts out low-cost printed media facilities. It has audio and visual presentations and there is great community support and goodwill for what it has been doing.

The children's mobile has been running on a shoestring of a little over $200,000 per year, with purely voluntary funding up to date, and it has cut its budget to the bone. Its budget for next year is not much more than $100,000, and it believes that this time the Federal Government should come in, through the Department of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services, which already funds contact projects for isolated children. We believe the funding should be extended to this area where the need is even greater.

I appeal to the Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley, to hear the pleas of these people so that this contact children's mobile can continue. If it has to shut down after 30 June this year, it will be a tragedy indeed for those isolated and remote children who have lived under disadvantaged conditions until now. I believe this is the very least the Government can do so that children living in this area get a fair crack of the whip of the money that is being spent in child care and other areas in more populated areas.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: United Nations General Assembly: Broadford and Mansfield High Schools

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the invitation of the United Nations environment program, New York University and the International Education and Resource Network, a small group of students from Broadford and Mansfield in rural Victoria, within the federal boundaries of the electorate of McEwen, will make a direct broadcast to the United Nations General Assembly at about 3 a.m. Australian eastern standard time on Friday, 4 June. The students in these two small country high schools will talk directly to the United Nations General Assembly from the Broadford Secondary College using both telephone and some form of audio link displaying a visual image on a screen in New York. These two schools have been invited to make this presentation—along with schools from Kenya, Beijing and Israel—in recognition of their longstanding environmental education projects and their involvement in IEARN, the international education and resource network program.

PARA.TAB: Bill Coppinger, the geography and science teacher at Broadford Secondary College, deserves the congratulations of this House because he was the catalyst for the school's involvement in IEARN. For a few years the Broadford students have been heavily involved in practical environmental and education programs, especially International UV Watch, which they have pioneered and now network through IEARN. The school's magazine, Icarus, is now issued to schools all over the world. The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) wrote a large article for the first issue of the quarterly Icarus magazine.

The presentation on 4 June, which will be at noon on 3 June New York time, will focus on Broadford students' work on UV Watch and the Mansfield students' work as active participants in the ribbons of blue project. This is a project where students work with the community in monitoring salinity levels in local streams and assist with efforts by land-holders to reduce salinity. John Steele is the teacher responsible for the Mansfield end of this project.

It was interesting in 1989 that at my request the then Minister for Science and Technology, the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones), visited Mansfield and drew quite a large crowd from the local community. It is said by those in the area that his visit at that gathering acted very largely as a catalyst, and the people there have since become involved in ozone level and greenhouse effect monitoring. John Steele, a teacher at Mansfield, said:

SPEECH.PARA: I did not realise the high regard Victoria's schools and community `watch' programs were held by environmental groups around the world. Since becoming involved with overseas computer networks, I have had requests for details from all parts of the globe. We are fast becoming a Global Model for community based environmental monitoring, and our kids are at a cutting edge of the technology which will make the projects work on a global scale.

It is true, I think, that we in this House should send our congratulations to the students, parents and teachers at the Broadford Secondary College and the Mansfield high school for the work they have done and the fact that they are going to represent this country direct by visual audio link in the United Nations General Assembly on 3 June in New York.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise my alarm as a new member of this place observing the Government over the last eight days of sittings and seeing a dramatic illustration of Executive Government running rampant over the Parliament and the rights of the people. Whilst I congratulate the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) on talking about what the young people in his electorate will be doing—and I wish them well—I regret very much that from my observations of this place since the Parliament opened there has been nothing done by the Government at all to improve the prospects of those children and other children in Australia. In fact, their future is being undermined by this Government. If I had the temerity to give a report card on this Government for its first eight days of this new Parliament, I would give it minus 10, and that is a generous mark.

PARA.TAB: I will give an overview. Just tonight we have seen the curtailment of a debate on a major piece of legislation, the Murray-Darling Basin Bill. We have tried for years to include Queensland in it. Queensland is now in it, but the legislation which has already gone through the Victorian and New South Wales parliaments stopped dead in the Federal Parliament. Yet our largest resource, our greatest food producing basin in Australia, is waiting for the Federal Government to take a lead. What has it done? After 30-odd years of negotiation with Queensland, it has blown it. That is a very stark illustration of the stupidity of this Government.

Another point I would like to make is that we saw this week an attack on, in effect, an independent officer of the Parliament—the Auditor-General. We saw from the Government a shameful attack on the Auditor-General and, by the denial of Question Time today, a curtailment of the right to probe and question when, of course, the Government would have been held to be more accountable for the unwarranted criticism of the Auditor-General's report. The report only disclosed, mind you, what the liabilities of this Commonwealth are with respect to debt. That is an important issue and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), his Ministers and the Treasury attacked the integrity of the Auditor-General and his staff.

We have also had the TV fiasco—the so-called tender situation that I have observed. Other Australians have been alarmed at the way in which the tradition of ministerial responsibility has now been sullied and altered. We now have a report which the Government is hanging its hat on. I do not want to get personal about the person who wrote the report, but the effect of that report is that no Minister of the Crown, according to this Federal Government, can ever be made responsible or accountable at all so long as there is a cover sheet on the file on which there is an initial from a public servant or a permanent head saying `recommended'. There is no reason to probe or to question; there is no reason to evaluate the interests of the nation by a Minister of the Crown; there is nothing.

This Government has now laid down new and frightening standards—or lack of standards. That will be the mark of this Government for the next three years. I say, `Heaven help Australia; heaven help the Parliament'. Yesterday we saw a cowardly attack by the Prime Minister on the President of the RSL, Brigadier Garland, who had the temerity to hand a flag of this nation to his Prime Minister—in good faith, in good fun, in good humour. To hear the Prime Minister's attack on Brigadier Garland, his cowardly slurs on why this flag was given to him, the reference to our British heritage and the denigration of our history is something that makes one's hair turn grey. The Prime Minister has caused the recession. Here we are with people unemployed, but he is now dividing the nation and attacking someone who had the temerity to hand him—the Prime Minister of Australia—the flag of his own nation.

The Parliament is now shutting down at the end of the session. The Government could not run a grocer shop. It put legislation on the Notice Paper and told us that it all had to go through. We are quite happy to accommodate the Government and to sit on. We make arrangements to speak, but we cannot even bring to the Government's attention—this is how stupid it is—the need to fund some of the programs affected by the legislation. We cannot even alert it to those things. The Government will now have to find out the hard way. My report card, minus 10, is a generous overestimate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mrs Silvia

TALK.START.PARA: —For the second time I would like to draw to the attention of this House an ongoing problem that I see in the electorate of Bass.
—The member!

—The problem is not the member; it is a problem relating to a bypass of the city of Launceston. It has been an ongoing problem for 30 years across governments of both parties. In the 1960s, the bypass was proposed as part of the section of ring-road around Launceston. In 1967, there was a second proposal. Ten years on, in 1977, another study was done. In 1988, the Tamar region road study was completed at long last to update the previous study. And so it went on. But no timing was shown in the works proposal for the eastern bypass other than that it was listed as the second highest priority urban road project after the East Tamar Highway extension. The East Tamar Highway extension was completed last year, following a study back in 1988.

PARA.TAB: In 1991, the Launceston City Council once again engaged consultants to look at this problem. The study found that in terms of benefit and cost and to best serve the amenity needs of both the eastern bypass area and the Glebe area of Launceston the road link south of the North Esk provided the best solution—that is, the eastern bypass. However, this solution indicated separation between regional and local needs—another excuse—so it was out of the question.

In 1991, the council extended the brief to consultants, and the finding in that study involved the Launceston City Council taking up the issue of the Glebe bypass. Once again this year the Department of Roads and Transport is funding a further study of the Tamar region to reassess construction priorities and to review the functional use of classified roads.

It has gone on and on for 30 years. On behalf of constituents in my seat of Bass, I will continue to bring this to the attention of the House. The road element costings amount to $20 million, and a further subsection worth $2.5 million has now been undertaken by the local government. It will provide a bypass, an alternative truck route, away from the Launceston central business district. The road component of the proposal—namely, the eastern connector and the Henry Street upgrading—is listed in the Tamar regional road study as the next highest priority after the East Tamar outlet which is now completed.

The council has funded two studies; the Glebe study has been completed. I ask this Government to seriously consider the next study by the council regarding these two issues. I draw to the Government's attention the fact that the bypass is needed to divert traffic—up to 40 log trucks per day—from going through a high residential area. This is causing major structural problems in the area, not only to the roads but also to the housing development. It is a very serious problem with a priority need that is No. 1. The transport economy favours the movement of forest based products in our State and in my electorate, but we certainly need to be looking at those roads. I bring to the attention of honourable members an article in the Australian Automobile Association newsletter on the role of roads in our future:

SPEECH.PARA: For people and freight alike, roads are vital to meet everyday transport needs and will continue to play an important role . . .
Vans and trucks perform the same task for freight. All goods start and finish their journeys by road, even if they are transported by rail, sea or air.
There is no viable alternative. I commend the forthcoming proposal for the eastern bypass for Launceston.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with other members in this House tonight who have spoken about the democratisation of this Parliament to express concern—whilst we are heading for a recess of some 2 1/2 months with our jobs here finished and a lot of people going overseas or going back to their electorates—that over the next 2 1/2 months the tragedy in rural Australia will continue and deepen, particularly in the drought areas.

PARA.TAB: I regret that in this Parliament we are not able to express some concern that might engender in our fellow citizens the need for some cooperative effort to help these people in their task. During the last week I spent a few days in the back of my electorate—areas which have had 2 1/2 inches of rain this year and which are now looking at their third year of drought. The struggle facing people on a daily basis on cattle properties where no green grass has been available for the last seven or eight months is unimaginable to the person in the street.

For instance, how do we try to relate a story about a person living for 24 hours a day with a diminishing security and increasing debt and higher interest? How do we relate to a family that gets to bed at midnight and up at four o'clock in the morning to distribute hay and to get the waters ready and then at nine o'clock puts its children into a school where they are their own schoolteachers? How do we describe to a person who is not actually living in those conditions 24 hours a day the fact that cattle are dying, that cattle are being put to death at the hands of their owners just to save them the agony of what is before them?

Unfortunately, as we leave this House, 95 per cent of Australia will not know how the five per cent are suffering. I believe there are means by which we could address many of the problems out there. I know that the problem of commodity prices is not within the realms of this Government to consider. But what about the problems that are occasioned at an abattoir where, in the midst of this despair, there is a 24-hour stoppage by the union movement over some trivial claim which means that somebody's cattle have not been slaughtered that day, will not be slaughtered but will die in the paddock?

TALK.START.PARA: —Totally irresponsible.

—It is totally irresponsible, but it also shows a lack of concern by the 95 per cent of people who are living quite comfortably. Other ways can be considered, involving Federal and State governments and local authorities as well as the people themselves. I am very happy to report that in my own region of Mackay the need has been seen to establish a committee to try to get hay, fodder and similar things and funds for daily living to the people in the hinterland. During those two days I saw the donations of hay from the coast going inland.

PARA.TAB: I believe that in the next 2 1/2 months we as members should try to engender some sense of feeling in the community—tender, loving care is all that is needed in some cases. In a debate two weeks ago in this House I urged the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) to consider returning drought to the list of natural disasters. It is quite unfair that a cyclone, flood or fire like we had on Black Friday in Victoria and South Australia can command the attention of Australian people and allow the government to make contributions over and above those made for drought, yet drought is not regarded as a natural diaster. Many of the things associated with help under those previous conditions are no longer available.

It is important that we should be able to express in this House the concerns of the people we represent. Question Time today would have been a grand opportunity to have asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy what his government proposes in this regard. I am not being critical. The Government has laid down guidelines which the public servants are adhering to. But there is a need for the bankers to show a bit of compassion, people to open their hearts and governments to try to do something. Members should think beyond themselves and their own electorates and should realise the despair of this five per cent of Australians on which the other 95 per cent depend to a large extent for Australia's export trade. If we let these people go, there will be no bringing them back, and Australia will be the loser.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wished to speak about a company in my electorate, Glaxo Australia Pty Ltd, which has entered into a terrific new research and development agreement with the University of Melbourne which will provide benefits for the company, for research and development in Australia and for all Australians through new product development. Quite frankly, I find that I am unable to continue with that subject because of my absolute disgust at the way this Government treats with disrespect this house of representatives of the people of this great nation.

PARA.TAB: I am reminded that brought into this place and into the public arena today is the so-called republicanism issue that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) wants us to debate. He says that we should be done with all things monarchical, with all things British, and with all things to do with our heritage. I remind you, Mr Speaker, that I wear on my lapel the flag that represents this great nation. It represents our heritage and tells where we came from. It gives us value in the systems which have developed over centuries, which give this country relevance and have made us one of the truly great democracies in the world.

We have a problem: this Government has made this House of Representatives irrelevant and superfluous. In the community we are a laughing stock, a joke. Time after time we come into this place and we debate irrelevant legislation and then the Government brings in important Bills which need major consideration. What does the Government do? It gags debate over and over again.

Today there was no Question Time. The Prime Minister was out having a nap or lunch. Who knows? He did not want to come into the House and face the questions of the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) or the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer). Yesterday the Prime Minister launched a scurrilous, unwanted, scumbag attack on the president of a great organisation, the Returned Services League of Australia, that has stood by our nation well. It was cowardice in the extreme to do that and then deny representatives of the people the opportunity to question him today.

But that is what we have come to expect from this Government—legislation that leads us nowhere. This House of Representatives is irrelevant because we are not given the opportunity to affect even the worst Bill. I have participated in debate in this place on bad legislation, which had no political input whatsoever. There was nothing whatsoever for the Government to lose by considering changes proposed by me from this side of the House to a bad Bill. Would the Government consider it? The answer is no. It was wasted breath and wasted words on a piece of paper. We wasted the time of these wonderful, cooperative Hansard reporters and the Clerks of the House sat here hour after hour while we debated the issue.

What cognisance does the Government take of comments made from this side of the House? None. So when we look at whether or not Australia should be a so-called republic, we are looking at whether we should become Paul Keating's monarchy—a true monarchy in a true monarchist fashion. We are heading in that direction, are we not? Today the House of Representatives is irrelevant and superfluous.

TALK.START.PARA: —The divine right of kings.

—If we let that man have his way we will have no Senate whatsoever, no check and balance on this place. Then, for good measure, let us get rid of the States. Let us get rid of federalism which gives us another check on executive power by this Government which has run away with itself. It is like a wagon going downhill and the oxen cannot stop it; they cannot stop it because they are dead.

—I am inspired by the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) who quite rightly pointed out how, over the last couple of weeks of this session of this Parliament, we find that democracy is dead and buried. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was running scared today. He was frightened to come in here. He was frightened to face the questions that we had for him. He was frightened that we were starting to see through his so-called minimalist approach to constitutional reform.

PARA.TAB: We know he has a hidden agenda. We all heard the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) in his maiden speech call for the abolition of the States. Those on the government benches—which are now vacant—said `Hear, hear!'. This Government has absolutely no respect for the rule of law. As the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) interjected a moment ago, we have the divine right of kings. Over the years, while the monarch has lost effective power, the parliament has become supreme and a democratic system has evolved. But in this place we now have a new king: it is `King Paul the First' or `Emperor Paul'. Indeed, he basically wants to continue to concentrate all power in his own hands. Tonight it was not my intention to dwell at length on Labor's lack of respect for the parliament, but I have been motivated by the honourable member for La Trobe to draw the attention of the House to the Government's disgraceful conduct.

I now turn to a very major problem suffered by a constituent in the electorate of Fisher. Following the Liberal Party's superb win in Fisher—we gained a swing of 10 per cent on 13 March—I received a number of letters from various people, including Mr John Thompson of Beachmere. He bemoaned the fact that the Labor Party had crawled back into office and complained to me that over the last number of years he has failed to obtain a renewal of his Australian passport.

This man has been in Australia for 55 years. When the Second World War came along, he joined up and served in the AIF. He went to Syria in the Middle East and to New Guinea where he fought on the Kokoda trail. We all remember the Prime Minister kissing the ground when he went to New Guinea. What about a fair go for Mr John Thompson? His problem is that, despite obtaining Australian citizenship on 26 January 1949 by virtue of an Act of Parliament, he has been denied an Australian passport.

TALK.START.PARA: —An outrage.

—It is an outrage. He served in the Second World War. He put his life on the line so that we can enjoy the freedoms that we should enjoy in this country—the freedoms that the Labor Party and the Prime Minister want to destroy.

PARA.TAB: He applied for a passport in 1989 and was told that he could not get one. His Australian citizen dates from 1949, but this 76-year-old man has been denied his right to a passport. He has already proven his loyalty to this country. When serving as part of our Australian armed forces in the Middle East he was left behind by his ship, along with Australian equipment possibly worth hundres of thousands of dollars in today's terms. Apparently and amazingly, it was never discovered that he was left behind. Yet he managed to follow that ship over a number of months, ultimately arriving back in Fremantle, complete with equipment, I might add.

TALK.START.PARA: —He deserves a medal.
—Yes, he deserves a medal. At the very least he certainly deserves an Australian passport.

PARA.TAB: My colleague Senator O'Chee in the other place drew to the attention of the Senate the problems experienced by Mr Thompson. He said he hoped the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs could do something for Mr Thompson. Indeed, there must be many other people in the same position whose rights are not recognised by this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where was he born?

—He was born in the United Kingdom. We know what an Anglophobe the Prime Minister is. We know how much he wants to encourage multiculturalism for every group in this country other than the 70 or 80 per cent of people whose families emanate from the United Kingdom. Mr Thompson has a major problem. I have written to the Minister but have received no reply and Senator O'Chee has raised this matter in the Senate. There is no question that Mr Thompson is an Australian citizen. He has been here for 55 years and risked his life so that we could enjoy the freedoms that the Prime Minister and the Government are now trying to extinguish.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister wants us to be bipartisan, but we are not going to be bipartisan on his republican issue because he wants to gut the Constitution of this country; he wants to destroy it. We will not offer him a bipartisan approach and nor will the Australian people. However, I do, in a bipartisan way, ask for help for Mr Thompson. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As many of my colleagues have said, three things have been highlighted by this Government since 13 March. Firstly, it has shown a large degree of parliamentary irresponsibility; secondly, it has shown a very high degree of arrogance; and, finally, it has shown a complete disregard for the little people of Australia.

PARA.TAB: I think the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) hit the nail on the head when he talked about the situation in the drought-ridden areas of northern New South Wales and southern Queensland.

I think the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) should take notice of what happened in the city of Toowoomba last Tuesday morning when 1,100 people sat down to a prayer breakfast, the proceeds of which were going to drought relief. The Prime Minister should understand that a lot of little people out there—particularly those in the bush—are hurting. But this has been mentioned in the House before. In Charleville, in the electorate of my colleague the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott), 40 people receive food parcels every fortnight. Quite recently one lady rang the appeal in which I have been involved and said, `Thank you very much for the food parcel, but do you think that my husband could have a pair of boots so that he can work the farm?'. That is the extent to which people in the bush are experiencing problems at the moment.

Bishop Wicks, a retired Anglican Bishop, said at the prayer breakfast on Tuesday morning that people out there should get angry. I agree with him; I hope they will. They should get angry with the parliamentary processes which we have seen prostituted this week and in the weeks leading up to this final two days of sitting.

But I would like to comment not only in terms of the Government's irresponsibility inside this House, but also in terms of its irresponsibility outside this House. This is epitomised in a letter I received quite recently; I am sure a lot of my colleagues have received similar letters. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's methodology in promoting so-called safe sexual practices among homosexuals has in the past caused me grave misgivings. Whilst recognising that steps must be taken to minimise the spread of the AIDS virus and acknowledging that homosexuals constitute 95 per cent or more of the identified cases of fully developed AIDS, the program was flawed in my opinion in that it failed to recognise, even implicitly, that homosexual activity involving multiple partners was a grossly irresponsible practice, all moral considerations aside.
It went on to say:

The advertising, particularly on television, used fear of contracting the disease as a means of promoting safer practices without in any way suggesting that by this very activity these people were ultimately putting the wider population at grave risk. No attempt was made to discourage such practices, not doubt due at least in part to the fear that the people responsible would be accused wrongly of being discriminatory. No attempt in fact was made in any way to suggest that the practice was anything than normal, a point of view to which a very large proportion of our population, normally very tolerant, would not subscribe.
The letter continued:

Be that as it may, I am frankly outraged to find that the Government is now permitting taxpayer funds to be used to promote homosexuality as a way of life. I refer to the recent advertising carried by the national press and funded by the Department of Health portraying a mother with her homosexual son. Not only is she depicted as being quite reconciled to his homosexual bent but also as being quite favourably disposed towards it. This advertisement is much more about homosexuality as a lifestyle than it is about disease prevention. No government has a right to use taxpayers' funds for this purpose and I suspect it was probably not intended to be used as such. At the bottom it makes a few suggestions about information and where to obtain it, but essentially it is selling the product homosexuality.
It concludes by saying:
In permitting and contributing to this mischievous and quite misleading advertisement, the Government and your Department—
the letter was written to Senator Richardson—
in particular has been grossly inept and irresponsible.

PARA.EMPHASIS: (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to see the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence (Mr Punch) at the table. I had the pleasure of joining him on the parliamentary delegation to the European Institutions and the Netherlands, but I am not going to spare him one bit on this particular issue. I want him to take note of this very important issue that I wish to raise in the House concerning federal funding for Victoria and the terrible situation that the Commonwealth has placed it in with respect to road funding.

PARA.TAB: Victoria contributes 27 per cent of total fuel excise receipts in that State. When I look at the indicative federal funding for roads in Victoria over the next three years, I find that of the 27 per cent of fuel excise collected by the Commonwealth in the 1993-94 financial year only 19.1 per cent will be returned to Victoria. Victoria's roads are in dire need of upgrading. In my own electorate I have many bridges that need replacing—one that immediately comes to mind is at Newbridge on the way to St Arnaud. But we have a shortfall in the return which Victorian motorists are contributing to the federal coffers by way of fuel excise. Out of a total of 27 per cent, only 19.1 per cent will be returned to Victoria in the year 1993-94—a total of $234.1 million—when in fact more than $300 million in road funding should be returned to that State.

The situation does not improve; in fact, over the next two years it will deteriorate even further. The indicative federal funding for Victoria in 1994-95 will drop to 17.1 per cent of the total excise contribution which Victorian motorists make. They are being short-changed by 10 per cent in the actual collection of fuel excise in Victoria. The total figure in dollar terms is $199.7 million. There is another startling reduction in 1995-96, when the figure will drop to 16.2 per cent, with total receipts for fuel excise returned to the Commonwealth at a level of 27 per cent.

That situation cannot be allowed to continue. It is causing tremendous problems for local and state governments in Victoria which are trying to finance the roads and keep them in good condition. One of my major concerns is that the Calder Highway—which runs from Melbourne to Bendigo, proceeds north to Mildura, links up with the national highway at Mildura and with the Sturt Highway to Adelaide—may not be upgraded to national highway standard because of the shortfall in funds. Since it is the main road between Melbourne and Bendigo—Bendigo being the second largest manufacturing area in Victoria—it is imperative that there be a four-lane highway between those two cities. If federal funding continues to diminish, that four-lane highway between Bendigo and Melbourne will not be completed until the year 2000.

The situation should be redressed by returning the fuel excise tax to Victoria at the appropriate level of 27 per cent. That would enable the highway to be duplicated all the way from Melbourne to Bendigo at a satisfactory national highway standard. The road is one of the most important arteries or links between those cities, although there is a very good rail link. Road transport generally needs to be kept at a high level and the quality of the roads between Melbourne and Bendigo needs to be upgraded. We should also remember that this particular road leads to the northern areas of Mildura, where much of the State's produce comes from. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 5 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did the Government establish an interdepartmental committee to develop Australia's national plan of action for implementing Australia's commitments to the 1990 World Summit for Children.

(3) If the plan has not been completed, (a) why not and (b) when will it be completed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. The Interdepartmental Committee (IDC) met on six occasions between November 1991 and August 1992 and established the processes by which the Department of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services would develop the National Program of Action. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 10 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: Has the Reserve Bank of Australia inquired into or reported on the activities of any building society or credit union which is required by the Financial Corporations Act 1974 to register with and provide statistics to the bank; if so, (a) when were the inquiries first held and reports first made and (b) how frequently have inquiries been held and reports made.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The Financial Corporations Act, under which building societies and credit unions provide statistics to the Reserve Bank, does not provide, nor was it ever intended to provide, a basis for the prudential supervision of their activities. The Reserve Bank has no supervisory role in respect of building societies and credit unions; their supervision is undertaken by State authorities.

The statistics collected under the Financial Corporations Act are published monthly in aggregate form by the Reserve Bank. They are also used by it in analysing trends and developments in the financial system. To ensure that the statistics collected are of high quality and to aid analysis, Bank officers make enquiries from time to time about the data provided by individual corporations. However, the Bank does not formally inquire into, or report on, the activities of institutions registered under the Act.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 10 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: Has the Reserve Bank of Australia inquired into or reported on the activities of any State bank or its subsidiaries extending beyond the limits of the State concerned; if so, (a) when were the inquiries first held and reports first made and (b) how frequently have inquiries been held and reports made.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The Australian Constitution precludes the Commonwealth from making laws in respect of State banking, except where State banking extends beyond the limits of the State concerned. However, no laws have been enacted in respect of out-of-State activities for State banks. The Banking Act exempts the entire operation of State banks from those of its provisions related to prudential supervision of banks.

Notwithstanding its lack of statutory power to supervise State banks, the Reserve Bank and State banks entered into a voluntary relationship in the mid 1980s. These arrangements covered those banks as a whole, including their activities extending beyond the limits of the States concerned. More recently, the Reserve Bank has moved to put these arrangements onto a more formal, contractual, footing. Agreements have been entered into with the Government of South Australia and Western Australia in respect of the State Bank of South Australia and the R&I Bank of Western Australia.

The State Government of New South Wales passed legislation which cedes its constitutional power over State banking to the Commonwealth Parliament, and the Banking Legislation Amendment Act 1992 amended the Banking Act to bring the State Bank of New South Wales under the Banking Act.

The State Government of South Australia has also agreed that the State Bank of South Australia be brought under the prudential supervision of the Reserve Bank no later than 1 January 1994 by legislation. This will require South Australia to cede banking powers to the Commonwealth as has already been done in New South Wales.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Pensions: Effect of Value of Shares

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 10 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: Are pensions affected by fluctuations in the value of shares; if so, what would be the effect on a pension if the recipient had bought shares at $5.00 in June 1990 and the market value fell to $3.00 on 23 September 1992 and then rose to $4.00 on 23 September 1993.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Under current rules, shares are assessed under both the income and asset test:
for income test purposes, a current rate of income is established based on the dividends paid on the shares over the previous 12 months; and
for asset test purposes, the number of shares held is multiplied by the last sale price of the shares at the time of the assessment, with the resulting value being counted as the person's asset.

From September 1993, the treatment of shares under the income test will change. From that date, a current rate of return will be established for all listed shares by taking into account changes in share values and dividends paid over the previous 12 months.
This return may be negative or positive. Negative returns will be offset against positive returns on other shares or managed investments.

The rates of return will be updated on a fortnightly basis to take into account share market fluctuations. To ensure consistency of assessment, pensioners will have their shareholdings reassessed quarterly against the current rates of return, commencing in September 1993.
There is no change to the asset treatment of shares.

If a pensioner bought shares at $5.00 in June 1990, their value was $3.00 on 23 September 1992 and then $4.00 on 23 September 1993, the effect under the income test at 23 September 1993 would be as follows:
a rate of return of 33.33% would be assessed against the shares held by the person (assuming no dividends were paid in the 12 months to 23 September 1993);
the rate of return is calculated by looking at the difference between the share price at September 1992 and September 1993 and representing this as a percentage. (ie. [$4.00—$3.00]/ $3.00 x 100)
the pension will be adjusted on a regular basis to reflect changes in the rate of return.

The purchase price is not taken into account because it would lead to different rates of pension being paid to pensioners who have identical current shareholdings. Most pensioners would be worse off if the purchase price was taken into account because their shares would have increased in value since they bought them.

A rate of return based on the performance of shares over the previous 12 months treats all investors in a given type of share the same, irrespective of whether they have just bought the shares or have held them for some time. This means that the pension income test is even-handed in measuring the ability of different pensioners to support themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, upon notice, on 13 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has his Department established targets by which time Austudy offices should answer telephone calls; if so, what are they.
(2) Does his Department monitor the performance of Austudy offices.
(3) What is the average time taken by an Austudy office to answer a telephone call.

(4) Is it a fact that the Austudy office in Blacktown, NSW, can take up to an hour to answer a telephone call; if so, (a) is this performance satisfactory and (b) what action will he take to improve it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Department of Employment, Education and Training has set the following standard for answering Student Assistance enquiries:
At least 85% of all calls to Student Assistance Centre (Austudy) general enquiries lines, including 008 lines, to be answered within 300 seconds.

The waiting time is measured from the time an incoming call reaches the PABX to the instant when a Departmental officer answers the call. In most Student Assistance Centres while the enquirer is waiting recorded messages provide background information on the Austudy program and answer commonly-asked questions.
(2) The Department monitors the performance of Student Assistance Centres against the Service Standards. Fortnightly reports are prepared.

(3) A recent survey of waiting times conducted by the Department for the annual review of National Client Service Standards indicates that the average waiting time for a client to be connected to an enquiries officer during 1993 has been 1 minute 23 seconds.

(4)(a) During 1993 to date, the Blacktown Student Assistance Centre has answered 85.8% of calls within the time set in the National Standard (85% within 300 seconds). The difficulties experienced by some clients during the 1993 peak enquiries period (January—April) in accessing Student Assistance telephone services at the Blacktown Student Assistance Centre were related to technical problems with the PABX telephone system and the high number of telephone enquiries received by the centre.
(b) The Department is upgrading its PABX equipment at the Blacktown Student Assistance Centre. This will improve the telephone enquiry services available to clients.
